   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Italy
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>
    <div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
     Jump to:
     <a href="#mw-head">
      navigation
     </a>

     <a href="#p-search">
      search
     </a>
    </div>
    <div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en">
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      This article is about the republic. For other uses, see
      <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Italy_(disambiguation)" title="Italy (disambiguation)">
       Italy (disambiguation)
      </a>
      .
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      "Italia" and "Italian Republic" redirect here. For the short-lived 19th-century state, see
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Republic_(Napoleonic)" title="Italian Republic (Napoleonic)">
       Italian Republic (Napoleonic)
      </a>
      . For other uses, see
      <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Italia_(disambiguation)" title="Italia (disambiguation)">
       Italia (disambiguation)
      </a>
      .
     </div>

       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="mergedbottomrow">
       <td style="width:1.0em;padding:0 0 0 0.6em;">
        •
       </td>
       <td style="padding-left:0;">
        <span class="nowrap">
         <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union#Founding_members" title="Enlargement of the European Union">
          Founded
         </a>
         the
         <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">
          EEC
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="nowrap">
         (now the
         <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
          European Union
         </a>
         )
        </span>
       </td>
       <td>
        1 January 1958
       </td>
      </tr>

        </a>
        )
        <br/>

       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;">

         <a href="/wiki/Aosta_Valley" title="Aosta Valley">
          Aosta Valley
         </a>
         ;
         <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">
          Slovene
         </a>
         is co-official in the
         <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Trieste" title="Province of Trieste">
          province of Trieste
         </a>
         and the
         <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Gorizia" title="Province of Gorizia">
          province of Gorizia
         </a>
         ; German and
         <a href="/wiki/Ladin_language" title="Ladin language">
          Ladin
         </a>
         are co-official in
         <a href="/wiki/South_Tyrol" title="South Tyrol">
          South Tyrol
         </a>
         .
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="mergedrow" style="font-size:85%;">
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        <span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;">
         <sup>
          b.
         </sup>
        </span>
       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;">
        <span style="font-size:100%;">
         Before 2002, the
         <a href="/wiki/Italian_lira" title="Italian lira">
          Italian Lira
         </a>
         . The euro is accepted in
         <a href="/wiki/Campione_d%27Italia" title="Campione d'Italia">
          Campione d'Italia
         </a>
         , but the official currency there is the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Swiss_Franc" title="Swiss Franc">
          Swiss Franc
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6">
          <a href="#cite_note-6">
           [6]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="mergedrow" style="font-size:85%;">
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        <span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;">
         <sup>
          c.
         </sup>
        </span>
       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;">
        <span style="font-size:100%;">
         To call
         <a href="/wiki/Campione_d%27Italia" title="Campione d'Italia">
          Campione d'Italia
         </a>
         , it is necessary to use the Swiss code
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%2B41" title="+41">
          +41
         </a>
         .
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="mergedbottomrow" style="font-size:85%;">
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        <span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;">
         <sup>
          d.
         </sup>
        </span>
       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;">
        <span style="font-size:100%;">
         The
         <a href="/wiki/.eu" title=".eu">
          .eu
         </a>
         domain is also used, as it is shared with other
         <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
          European Union
         </a>
         member states.
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      <b>
       Italy
      </b>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
       Italian
      </a>
      :
      <span lang="it">
       <i>
        Italia
       </i>
      </span>
      <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
       <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_Italian" title="Help:IPA for Italian">
        [iˈtaːlja]
       </a>
      </span>
      <small class="nowrap metadata">
       (
       <a href="/wiki/File:It-Italia.ogg" title="File:It-Italia.ogg">
        <img alt="" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="500" height="13" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Speaker_Icon.svg/13px-Speaker_Icon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Speaker_Icon.svg/20px-Speaker_Icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Speaker_Icon.svg/26px-Speaker_Icon.svg.png 2x" width="13"/>
       </a>
       <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1d/It-Italia.ogg" title="It-Italia.ogg">
        listen
       </a>
       )
      </small>
      ), officially the
      <b>
       Italian Republic
      </b>
      (Italian:
      <span lang="it">
       <i>
        Repubblica Italiana
       </i>
      </span>
      ),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-7">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-8">
        [8]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-9">
        [9]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
       <a href="#cite_note-10">
        [10]
       </a>
      </sup>
      is a
      <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
       unitary
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">
       parliamentary republic
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
       Europe
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
       <a href="#cite_note-11">
        [note 1]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Located in the heart of the
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
       Mediterranean Sea
      </a>
      , Italy shares
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Open_borders" title="Open borders">
       open land borders
      </a>
      with
      <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">
       France
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">
       Switzerland
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">
       Austria
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">
       Slovenia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/San_Marino" title="San Marino">
       San Marino
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">
       Vatican City
      </a>
      . Italy covers an area of 301,338 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      (116,347 sq mi) and has a largely
      <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">
       temperate seasonal climate
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">
       Mediterranean climate
      </a>
      ; due to its shape, it is often referred to in Italy as
      <i>
       lo Stivale
      </i>
      (the
      <a href="/wiki/Boot" title="Boot">
       Boot
      </a>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
       <a href="#cite_note-12">
        [11]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
       <a href="#cite_note-13">
        [12]
       </a>
      </sup>
      With 61 million inhabitants, it is the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_Union_member_states_by_population" title="List of European Union member states by population">
       third most populous EU member state
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Since
      <a href="/wiki/Classical_antiquity" title="Classical antiquity">
       classical times
      </a>
      , ancient
      <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">
       Phoenicians
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia">
       Greeks
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Etruscan_civilization" title="Etruscan civilization">
       Etruscans
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">
       Celts
      </a>
      have inhabited the south, centre and north of the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">
       Italian Peninsula
      </a>
      respectively, with various
      <a href="/wiki/Italic_peoples" title="Italic peoples">
       Italic peoples
      </a>
      dispersed throughout Italy alongside other
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_peoples_of_Italy" title="List of ancient peoples of Italy">
       ancient Italian tribes
      </a>
      and Greek,
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Carthage" title="Ancient Carthage">
       Carthaginian
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phoenician_colonies" title="Phoenician colonies">
       Phoenician colonies
      </a>
      . The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italic_tribe" title="Italic tribe">
       Italic tribe
      </a>
      known as the
      <a href="/wiki/Latins" title="Latins">
       Latins
      </a>
      formed the
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Kingdom" title="Roman Kingdom">
       Roman Kingdom
      </a>
      , which eventually spread throughout Italy,
      <a href="/wiki/Romanization_(cultural)" title="Romanization (cultural)">
       assimilating
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_conquest_of_Italy" title="Roman conquest of Italy">
       conquering other nearby civilisations
      </a>
      and forming the
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">
       Roman Republic
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
       Rome
      </a>
      ultimately emerged as the
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
       dominant power
      </a>
      , conquering much of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ecumene" title="Ecumene">
       ancient world
      </a>
      and becoming the leading cultural, political, and religious
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caput_mundi" title="Caput mundi">
       centre
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">
       Western civilisation
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Legacy_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Legacy of the Roman Empire">
       legacy of the Roman Empire
      </a>
      is widespread and can be observed in the global distribution of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civilian_law" title="Civilian law">
       civilian law
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republican_government" title="Republican government">
       republican governments
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
       Christianity
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Latin_script" title="Latin script">
       Latin script
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      During the
      <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
       Middle Ages
      </a>
      , Italy suffered
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Collapse_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Collapse of the Roman Empire">
       sociopolitical collapse
      </a>
      amid calamitous
      <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">
       barbarian invasions
      </a>
      , but by the 11th century, numerous rival
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_city-states" title="Italian city-states">
       city-states
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Maritime_republics" title="Maritime republics">
       maritime republics
      </a>
      rose to great prosperity through shipping, commerce, and banking, and even laid the groundwork for
      <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">
       capitalism
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
       <a href="#cite_note-14">
        [13]
       </a>
      </sup>
      These independent city-states and regional republics, acting as Europe's main port of entry for
      <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">
       Asian
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">
       Near Eastern
      </a>
      imported goods, often enjoyed a greater degree of
      <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">
       democracy
      </a>
      in comparison to the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monarchies" title="Monarchies">
       monarchies
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">
       feudal
      </a>
      states found throughout Europe at the time, though much of
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Italy" title="Central Italy">
       central Italy
      </a>
      remained under the control of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theocratic" title="Theocratic">
       theocratic
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">
       Papal States
      </a>
      , while
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">
       Southern Italy
      </a>
      remained largely feudal, partially as a result of a succession of
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
       Byzantine
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_Islam_in_southern_Italy" title="History of Islam in southern Italy">
       Arab
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_southern_Italy" title="Norman conquest of southern Italy">
       Norman
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Aragon" title="Crown of Aragon">
       Spanish
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/House_of_Bourbon" title="House of Bourbon">
       Bourbon
      </a>
      conquests of the region.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-natgeo_15-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-natgeo-15">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">
       Renaissance
      </a>
      began in Italy and spread to the rest of Europe, bringing a renewed interest in
      <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_humanism" title="Renaissance humanism">
       humanism
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Renaissance_science" title="Renaissance science">
       science
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Renaissance_exploration" title="Renaissance exploration">
       exploration
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_art" title="Renaissance art">
       art
      </a>
      with the start of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modern_era" title="Modern era">
       modern era
      </a>
      . Italian culture flourished at this time, producing famous scholars, artists, and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polymaths" title="Polymaths">
       polymaths
      </a>
      such as
      <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">
       Leonardo da Vinci
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Galilei" title="Galileo Galilei">
       Galileo
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Michelangelo" title="Michelangelo">
       Michelangelo
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli" title="Niccolò Machiavelli">
       Machiavelli
      </a>
      . Explorers from Italy such as
      <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo" title="Marco Polo">
       Marco Polo
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">
       Christopher Columbus
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Amerigo_Vespucci" title="Amerigo Vespucci">
       Amerigo Vespucci
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_da_Verrazzano" title="Giovanni da Verrazzano">
       Giovanni da Verrazzano
      </a>
      discovered new routes to the
      <a href="/wiki/Far_East" title="Far East">
       Far East
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">
       New World
      </a>
      , helping to usher in the European
      <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">
       Age of Discovery
      </a>
      . Nevertheless, Italy's importance as a hub of commercial and political power significantly waned with the opening of trade routes from the New World, as New World imports and trade routes became more influential in Europe and bypassed the East Asian and Mediterranean trade routes that the Italian city-states had dominated.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-natgeo_15-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-natgeo-15">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
       <a href="#cite_note-16">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bouchard_17-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-bouchard-17">
        [16]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Furthermore, the Italian city-states constantly engaged one another in bloody
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Warfare" title="Warfare">
       warfare
      </a>
      , with this tension and violent rivalry culminating in the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Wars" title="Italian Wars">
       Italian Wars
      </a>
      of the 15th and 16th centuries, a series of wars and foreign invasions that left the Italian states vulnerable to
      <a href="/wiki/Annexation" title="Annexation">
       annexation
      </a>
      by neighbouring European powers. Italy would remain politically fragmented and fall prey to
      <a href="/wiki/Conquest_(military)" title="Conquest (military)">
       conquest
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Military_occupation" title="Military occupation">
       occupation
      </a>
      , and general
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_domination" title="Foreign domination">
       foreign domination
      </a>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Power_(international_relations)#Modern_Age_European_powers" title="Power (international relations)">
       European powers
      </a>
      such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_First_Empire" title="French First Empire">
       France
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">
       Spain
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Empire" title="Austrian Empire">
       Austria
      </a>
      , subsequently entering a long period of decline.
     </p>
     <p>
      By the mid-19th century, a rising movement in support of
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_nationalism" title="Italian nationalism">
       Italian nationalism
      </a>
      and Italian independence from foreign control lead to a period of
      <a href="/wiki/Revolutionary" title="Revolutionary">
       revolutionary
      </a>
      political upheaval known as the
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Risorgimento" title="Risorgimento">
        Risorgimento
       </a>
      </i>
      , which sought to bring about a rebirth of Italian cultural and economic prominence by liberating and consolidating the Italian peninsula and
      <a href="/wiki/Insular_Italy" title="Insular Italy">
       insular Italy
      </a>
      into an independent and unified nation-state. After various unsuccessful attempts, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_Wars_of_Independence" title="Italian Wars of Independence">
       Italian Wars of Independence
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Expedition_of_the_Thousand" title="Expedition of the Thousand">
       Expedition of the Thousand
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_Rome" title="Capture of Rome">
       capture of Rome
      </a>
      resulted in the eventual
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_unification" title="Italian unification">
       unification
      </a>
      of the country, now a
      <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">
       great power
      </a>
      after centuries of foreign domination and political division.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
       <a href="#cite_note-18">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      From the late 19th century to the early 20th century, the new
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">
       Kingdom of Italy
      </a>
      rapidly
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrialized" title="Industrialized">
       industrialised
      </a>
      , especially in the so-called
      <i>
       Industrial Triangle
      </i>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">
       Milan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Turin" title="Turin">
       Turin
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Genoa" title="Genoa">
       Genoa
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Italy" title="Northern Italy">
       the north
      </a>
      , and soon acquired a small
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Empire" title="Italian Empire">
       colonial empire
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allempires.com_19-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-allempires.com-19">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However,
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">
       the southern
      </a>
      areas of the country remained largely impoverished and
      <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Italy#North.E2.80.93South_divide" title="Economy of Italy">
       excluded from industrialisation
      </a>
      , fuelling a large and influential
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_diaspora" title="Italian diaspora">
       diaspora
      </a>
      . Despite being one of the
      <a href="/wiki/The_Big_Four_(World_War_I)" title="The Big Four (World War I)">
       main victors
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
       World War I
      </a>
      , Italy entered a period of economic crisis and social turmoil, leading the way to the rise of a
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Fascism" title="Italian Fascism">
       Fascist
      </a>
      dictatorship in 1922. The subsequent participation in
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
       World War II
      </a>
      on the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Axis_Powers" title="Axis Powers">
       Axis
      </a>
      side ended in military defeat, economic destruction, and a
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Civil_War" title="Italian Civil War">
       civil war
      </a>
      following the rise of the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_resistance_movement" title="Italian resistance movement">
       Italian resistance movement
      </a>
      . In the years that followed, Italy abolished the
      <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Italy" title="Monarchy of Italy">
       Italian monarchy
      </a>
      , reinstated democracy, enjoyed a prolonged
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_economic_miracle" title="Italian economic miracle">
       economic boom
      </a>
      , and, despite periods of sociopolitical turmoil (e.g.
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Years_of_Lead_(Italy)" title="Years of Lead (Italy)">
        Anni di piombo
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Mani_pulite" title="Mani pulite">
        Mani pulite
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Second_Mafia_War" title="Second Mafia War">
       Second Mafia War
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Maxi_Trial" title="Maxi Trial">
       Maxi Trial
      </a>
      ), became one of the world's most
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developed_nations" title="Developed nations">
       developed nations
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI_5-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-HDI-5">
        [5]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist.com_21-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-economist.com-21">
        [20]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
       <a href="#cite_note-22">
        [21]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
       <a href="#cite_note-23">
        [22]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy has the third largest economy in the
      <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
       Eurozone
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">
       eighth largest
      </a>
      economy in the world. It has a very high level of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_development_index" title="Human development index">
       human development
      </a>
      and enjoys the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">
       highest life expectancy
      </a>
      in the EU.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        [23]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italy plays a prominent role in regional and global economic, military, cultural and diplomatic affairs, and the country is both a
      <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">
       regional power
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
       <a href="#cite_note-25">
        [24]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
       <a href="#cite_note-26">
        [25]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and a
      <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">
       great power
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canada_Among_Nations_27-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Canada_Among_Nations-27">
        [26]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Milena_Sterio_28-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Milena_Sterio-28">
        [27]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italy is a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inner_six" title="Inner six">
       founding
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EU_big_four" title="EU big four">
       leading
      </a>
      member of the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
       European Union
      </a>
      and the member of numerous international institutions, including the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN" title="UN">
       UN
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
       NATO
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
       OECD
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OSCE" title="OSCE">
       OSCE
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WTO" title="WTO">
       WTO
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">
       G7
      </a>
      /
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G8" title="G8">
       G8
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">
       G20
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Union_for_the_Mediterranean" title="Union for the Mediterranean">
       Union for the Mediterranean
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
       Council of Europe
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Uniting_for_Consensus" title="Uniting for Consensus">
       Uniting for Consensus
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Italy#International_institutions" title="Foreign relations of Italy">
       many more
      </a>
      . As a reflection of its vast cultural wealth, Italy is home to 51
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites" title="World Heritage Sites">
       World Heritage Sites
      </a>
      , the most in the world, and is one of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Most_visited_countries" title="Most visited countries">
       most visited countries
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <div class="toclimit-3">

          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-13">

            </span>

              </span>

        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-24">
         <a href="#Demographics">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           6
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Demographics
          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-25">
           <a href="#Metropolitan_cities.5B177.5D_and_Functional_urban_areas.5B178.5D">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             6.1
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Metropolitan cities
             <sup>
              [177]
             </sup>
             and Functional urban areas
             <sup>
              [178]
             </sup>
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-26">
           <a href="#Ethnic_groups">
            <span class="tocnumber">

            </span>

            </span>
           </a>
          </li>

            </span>
            <span class="toctext">

            </span>

          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-28">
           <a href="#Religion">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             6.4
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Religion
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-29">
           <a href="#Education">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             6.5
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Education
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-30">
           <a href="#Health">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             6.6
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Health
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-31">
         <a href="#Culture">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           7
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Culture
          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-32">
           <a href="#Architecture">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.1
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Architecture
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-33">
           <a href="#Visual_art">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.2
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Visual art
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-34">
           <a href="#Literature_and_theatre">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.3
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Literature and theatre
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-35">
           <a href="#Music">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.4
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Music
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-36">
           <a href="#Cinema">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.5
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Cinema
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-37">
           <a href="#Sport">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.6
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Sport
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-38">
           <a href="#Fashion_and_design">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.7
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Fashion and design
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-39">
           <a href="#Cuisine">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.8
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Cuisine
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-40">
         <a href="#See_also">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           8
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           See also
          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-41">
         <a href="#Notes">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           9
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Notes
          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-42">
         <a href="#References">
          <span class="tocnumber">

          </span>

          </span>
         </a>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-43">

        </li>

         </a>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
       Etymology
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      <span id="Etymology">
      </span>
     </p>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Italy" title="Name of Italy">
       Name of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The assumptions on the etymology of the name "Italia" are very numerous and the corpus of the solutions proposed by historians and linguists is very wide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Manco_29-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Manco-29">
        [28]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to one of the more common explanations, the term
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italia_(Roman_Empire)" title="Italia (Roman Empire)">
        Italia
       </a>
      </i>
      , from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">
       Latin
      </a>
      :
      <span lang="la">
       <i>
        Italia
       </i>
      </span>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
       <a href="#cite_note-30">
        [29]
       </a>
      </sup>
      was borrowed through
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">
       Greek
      </a>
      from the
      <a href="/wiki/Oscan_language" title="Oscan language">
       Oscan
      </a>
      <i>
       Víteliú
      </i>
      , meaning "land of young cattle" (
      <i>
       cf.
      </i>
      <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">
       Lat
      </a>
      <i>
       vitulus
      </i>
      "calf",
      <a href="/wiki/Umbrian_language" title="Umbrian language">
       Umb
      </a>
      <i>
       vitlo
      </i>
      "calf").
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
       <a href="#cite_note-31">
        [30]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The bull was a symbol of the southern Italic tribes and was often depicted goring the Roman wolf as a defiant symbol of free Italy during the
      <a href="/wiki/Social_War_(91%E2%80%9388_BC)" title="Social War (91–88 BC)">
       Social War
      </a>
      . Greek historian
      <a href="/wiki/Dionysius_of_Halicarnassus" title="Dionysius of Halicarnassus">
       Dionysius of Halicarnassus
      </a>
      states this account together with the legend that Italy was named after
      <a href="/wiki/Italus" title="Italus">
       Italus
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
       <a href="#cite_note-32">
        [31]
       </a>
      </sup>
      mentioned also by
      <a href="/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle">
       Aristotle
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
       <a href="#cite_note-33">
        [32]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Thucydides" title="Thucydides">
       Thucydides
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
       <a href="#cite_note-34">
        [33]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The name
      <i>
       Italia
      </i>
      originally applied only to a part of what is now
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">
       Southern Italy
      </a>
      – according to
      <a href="/wiki/Antiochus_of_Syracuse" title="Antiochus of Syracuse">
       Antiochus of Syracuse
      </a>
      , the southern portion of the Bruttium peninsula (modern
      <a href="/wiki/Calabria" title="Calabria">
       Calabria
      </a>
      : province of
      <a href="/wiki/Reggio_Calabria" title="Reggio Calabria">
       Reggio
      </a>
      , and part of the provinces of
      <a href="/wiki/Catanzaro" title="Catanzaro">
       Catanzaro
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Vibo_Valentia" title="Vibo Valentia">
       Vibo Valentia
      </a>
      ). But by his time
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oenotria" title="Oenotria">
       Oenotria
      </a>
      and Italy had become synonymous, and the name also applied to most of
      <a href="/wiki/Lucania" title="Lucania">
       Lucania
      </a>
      as well. The Greeks gradually came to apply the name "Italia" to a larger region, but it was during the reign of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Emperor" title="Roman Emperor">
       Emperor
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Augustus" title="Augustus">
       Augustus
      </a>
      (end of the 1st century BC) that the term was expanded to cover the entire peninsula until the Alps.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
       <a href="#cite_note-35">
        [34]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
       History
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_Italy" title="History of Italy">
       History of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_antiquity">
       Prehistory and antiquity
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Italy" title="Prehistoric Italy">
       Prehistoric Italy
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuragic_civilisation" title="Nuragic civilisation">
       Nuragic civilisation
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Etruscan_civilisation" title="Etruscan civilisation">
       Etruscan civilisation
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia">
       Magna Graecia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Italy" title="Roman Italy">
       Roman Italy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
       Ancient Rome
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Kingdom" title="Roman Kingdom">
       Roman Kingdom
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">
       Roman Republic
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
       Roman Empire
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Colosseum_in_Rome,_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2833" data-file-width="4827" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg/250px-Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg/375px-Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg/500px-Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Colosseum_in_Rome,_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Colosseum" title="Colosseum">
         Colosseum
        </a>
        in Rome, built c. 70 – 80 AD, is considered one of the greatest works of
        <a href="/wiki/Architecture" title="Architecture">
         architecture
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Engineering" title="Engineering">
         engineering
        </a>
        of ancient history.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Excavations throughout Italy revealed a
      <a href="/wiki/Neanderthal" title="Neanderthal">
       Neanderthal
      </a>
      presence dating back to the
      <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">
       Palaeolithic
      </a>
      period, some 200,000 years ago,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
       <a href="#cite_note-36">
        [35]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatomically_modern_humans" title="Anatomically modern humans">
       modern Humans
      </a>
      arrived about 40,000 years ago. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_peoples_of_Italy" title="Ancient peoples of Italy">
       Ancient peoples
      </a>
      of pre-Roman Italy – such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Umbri" title="Umbri">
       Umbrians
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Latins" title="Latins">
       Latins
      </a>
      (from which the
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
       Romans
      </a>
      emerged),
      <a href="/wiki/Volsci" title="Volsci">
       Volsci
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oscans" title="Oscans">
       Oscans
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Samnites" title="Samnites">
       Samnites
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sabines" title="Sabines">
       Sabines
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">
       Celts
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Ligures" title="Ligures">
       Ligures
      </a>
      , and many others – were
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-European" title="Indo-European">
       Indo-European
      </a>
      peoples; the main historic peoples of possible non-Indo-European heritage include the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Etruscans" title="Etruscans">
       Etruscans
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Elymians" title="Elymians">
       Elymians
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sicani" title="Sicani">
       Sicani
      </a>
      in Sicily and the
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_Sardinia" title="History of Sardinia">
       prehistoric
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sardinians" title="Sardinians">
       Sardinians
      </a>
      , which includes the
      <a href="/wiki/Nuragic_civilization" title="Nuragic civilization">
       Nuragic civilisation
      </a>
      . Other ancient Italian peoples of undetermined language families but of possible non-Indo-European origins include the
      <a href="/wiki/Rhaetian_people" title="Rhaetian people">
       Rhaetian people
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cammuni" title="Cammuni">
       Cammuni
      </a>
      , known for their
      <a href="/wiki/Rock_Drawings_in_Valcamonica" title="Rock Drawings in Valcamonica">
       rock carvings
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Agrigent_BW_2012-10-07_13-09-13.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2512" data-file-width="3714" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Agrigent_BW_2012-10-07_13-09-13.jpg/200px-Agrigent_BW_2012-10-07_13-09-13.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Agrigent_BW_2012-10-07_13-09-13.jpg/300px-Agrigent_BW_2012-10-07_13-09-13.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Agrigent_BW_2012-10-07_13-09-13.jpg/400px-Agrigent_BW_2012-10-07_13-09-13.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Agrigent_BW_2012-10-07_13-09-13.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Concordia,_Agrigento" title="Temple of Concordia, Agrigento">
         temple of Concordia
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Agrigento" title="Agrigento">
         Agrigento
        </a>
        , the largest and one of the best-preserved
        <a href="/wiki/Doric_order" title="Doric order">
         Doric
        </a>
        temples.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
         <a href="#cite_note-37">
          [36]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Between the 17th and the 11th centuries BC
      <a href="/wiki/Mycenaean_Greece" title="Mycenaean Greece">
       Mycenaean Greeks
      </a>
      established contacts with Italy
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
       <a href="#cite_note-38">
        [37]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
       <a href="#cite_note-39">
        [38]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
       <a href="#cite_note-40">
        [39]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
       <a href="#cite_note-41">
        [40]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and in the 8th and 7th centuries BC
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greek_colonies" title="Greek colonies">
       Greek colonies
      </a>
      were established all along the coast of
      <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">
       Sicily
      </a>
      and the southern part of the Italian Peninsula became known as
      <a href="/wiki/Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia">
       Magna Graecia
      </a>
      . Also the
      <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">
       Phoenicians
      </a>
      established colonies on the coasts of Sardinia and Sicily.
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
       Rome
      </a>
      , a settlement around a ford on the river
      <a href="/wiki/Tiber" title="Tiber">
       Tiber
      </a>
      conventionally
      <a href="/wiki/Founding_of_Rome" title="Founding of Rome">
       founded
      </a>
      in 753 BC, grew over the course of centuries into a massive
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_empire" title="Roman empire">
       empire
      </a>
      , stretching from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Britannia_(Roman_province)" title="Britannia (Roman province)">
       Britain
      </a>
      to the borders of
      <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia_(Roman_province)" title="Mesopotamia (Roman province)">
       Persia
      </a>
      , and engulfing the whole
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean" title="Mediterranean">
       Mediterranean
      </a>
      basin, in which Greek and Roman and many other cultures merged into a unique
      <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_world" title="Greco-Roman world">
       civilisation
      </a>
      . The Roman
      <a href="/wiki/Legacy_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Legacy of the Roman Empire">
       legacy
      </a>
      has deeply influenced the Western civilisation, shaping most of the modern world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
       <a href="#cite_note-42">
        [41]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In a slow
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Decline of the Roman Empire">
       decline
      </a>
      since the third century AD, the Empire split in two in 395 AD. The
      <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">
       Western Empire
      </a>
      , under the pressure of the
      <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">
       barbarian invasions
      </a>
      , eventually dissolved in 476 AD, when its
      <a href="/wiki/Romulus_Augustulus" title="Romulus Augustulus">
       last Emperor
      </a>
      was deposed by the Germanic chief
      <a href="/wiki/Odoacer" title="Odoacer">
       Odoacer
      </a>
      , while the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" title="Eastern Roman Empire">
       Eastern
      </a>
      half of the Empire survived for another thousand years.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">
       Middle Ages
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Italy_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Italy in the Middle Ages">
       Italy in the Middle Ages
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iron_Crown.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="1154" data-file-width="1890" height="122" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Iron_Crown.JPG/200px-Iron_Crown.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Iron_Crown.JPG/300px-Iron_Crown.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Iron_Crown.JPG/400px-Iron_Crown.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Iron_Crown_of_Lombardy" title="Iron Crown of Lombardy">
          Iron Crown of Lombardy
         </a>
         , for centuries symbol of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kings_of_Italy" title="Kings of Italy">
          Kings of Italy
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Puglia_CdM_veduta_2.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3456" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Puglia_CdM_veduta_2.JPG/200px-Puglia_CdM_veduta_2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Puglia_CdM_veduta_2.JPG/300px-Puglia_CdM_veduta_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Puglia_CdM_veduta_2.JPG/400px-Puglia_CdM_veduta_2.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         <a href="/wiki/Castel_del_Monte,_Apulia" title="Castel del Monte, Apulia">
          Castel del Monte
         </a>
         , built by German Emperor
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frederick_II_of_the_Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Frederick II of the Holy Roman Empire">
          Frederick II
         </a>
         ,
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Educational,_Scientific_and_Cultural_Organization" title="United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization">
          UNESCO
         </a>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Heritage_site" title="World Heritage site">
          World Heritage site
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      After the
      <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">
       fall of the Western Roman Empire
      </a>
      , Italy was seized by the
      <a href="/wiki/Ostrogoths" title="Ostrogoths">
       Ostrogoths
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
       <a href="#cite_note-43">
        [42]
       </a>
      </sup>
      followed in the 6th century by a brief
      <a href="/wiki/Gothic_War_(535%E2%80%93554)" title="Gothic War (535–554)">
       reconquest
      </a>
      under
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine" title="Byzantine">
       Byzantine
      </a>
      Emperor
      <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">
       Justinian
      </a>
      . The invasion of another
      <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">
       Germanic tribe
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Lombards" title="Lombards">
       Lombards
      </a>
      , late in the same century, reduced the Byzantine presence to a rump realm (the
      <a href="/wiki/Exarchate_of_Ravenna" title="Exarchate of Ravenna">
       Exarchate of Ravenna
      </a>
      ) and started the end of political unity of the peninsula for the next 1,300 years. The Lombard kingdom was subsequently absorbed into the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frankish_Empire" title="Frankish Empire">
       Frankish Empire
      </a>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">
       Charlemagne
      </a>
      in the late 8th century. The Franks also helped the formation of the
      <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">
       Papal States
      </a>
      in central Italy. Until the 13th century, Italian politics was dominated by the relations between the
      <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Holy Roman Emperor">
       Holy Roman Emperors
      </a>
      and the Papacy, with most of the Italian city-states siding for the former (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghibellines" title="Ghibellines">
       Ghibellines
      </a>
      ) or for the latter (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guelphs" title="Guelphs">
       Guelphs
      </a>
      ) from momentary convenience.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
       <a href="#cite_note-44">
        [43]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marco_Polo_-_costume_tartare.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1528" data-file-width="1095" height="251" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Marco_Polo_-_costume_tartare.jpg/180px-Marco_Polo_-_costume_tartare.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Marco_Polo_-_costume_tartare.jpg/270px-Marco_Polo_-_costume_tartare.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Marco_Polo_-_costume_tartare.jpg/360px-Marco_Polo_-_costume_tartare.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marco_Polo_-_costume_tartare.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Painting of
        <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo" title="Marco Polo">
         Marco Polo
        </a>
        , the
        <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">
         Venetian
        </a>
        explorer of the
        <a href="/wiki/13th_century" title="13th century">
         13th century
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      It was during this chaotic era that Italian towns saw the rise of a peculiar institution, the
      <a href="/wiki/Medieval_commune" title="Medieval commune">
       medieval commune
      </a>
      . Given the power vacuum caused by extreme territorial fragmentation and the struggle between the Empire and the
      <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">
       Holy See
      </a>
      , local communities sought autonomous ways to maintain law and order.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
       <a href="#cite_note-45">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1176 a league of city-states, the
      <a href="/wiki/Lombard_League" title="Lombard League">
       Lombard League
      </a>
      , defeated the German emperor
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frederick_Barbarossa" title="Frederick Barbarossa">
       Frederick Barbarossa
      </a>
      at the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Legnano" title="Battle of Legnano">
       Battle of Legnano
      </a>
      , thus ensuring effective independence for most of northern and central Italian cities. In coastal and southern areas, the
      <a href="/wiki/Maritime_republics" title="Maritime republics">
       maritime republics
      </a>
      , the most notable being
      <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">
       Venice
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">
       Genoa
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Pisa" title="Republic of Pisa">
       Pisa
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Amalfi" title="Amalfi">
       Amalfi
      </a>
      , heavily involved in the
      <a href="/wiki/Crusades" title="Crusades">
       Crusades
      </a>
      , grew to eventually dominate the Mediterranean and monopolise trade routes to the
      <a href="/wiki/Orient" title="Orient">
       Orient
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
       <a href="#cite_note-46">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the south, Sicily had become an
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_conquest_of_Sicily" title="Islamic conquest of Sicily">
       Islamic emirate
      </a>
      in the 9th century, thriving until the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italo-Normans" title="Italo-Normans">
       Italo-Normans
      </a>
      conquered it in the late 11th century together with most of the Lombard and Byzantine principalities of southern Italy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
       <a href="#cite_note-47">
        [46]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Through a complex series of events, southern Italy developed as a unified kingdom, first under the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/House_of_Hohenstaufen" title="House of Hohenstaufen">
       House of Hohenstaufen
      </a>
      , then under the
      <a href="/wiki/Capetian_House_of_Anjou" title="Capetian House of Anjou">
       Capetian House of Anjou
      </a>
      and, from the 15th century, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/House_of_Aragon" title="House of Aragon">
       House of Aragon
      </a>
      . In
      <a href="/wiki/Sardinia" title="Sardinia">
       Sardinia
      </a>
      , the former Byzantine provinces became independent states known as
      <a href="/wiki/Giudicati" title="Giudicati">
       Giudicati
      </a>
      , although some parts of the island were under Genoese or Pisan control until the Aragonese conquered it in the 15th century. The
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">
       Black Death
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Pandemic" title="Pandemic">
       pandemic
      </a>
      of 1348 left its mark on Italy by killing perhaps one third of the population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
       <a href="#cite_note-48">
        [47]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
       <a href="#cite_note-49">
        [48]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, the recovery from the plague led to a resurgence of cities, trade and economy which allowed the bloom of
      <a href="/wiki/Humanism" title="Humanism">
       Humanism
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">
       Renaissance
      </a>
      , that later spread in Europe.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Modern">
       Early Modern
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_presumed_self-portrait_-_WGA12798.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1153" data-file-width="740" height="265" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_presumed_self-portrait_-_WGA12798.jpg/170px-Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_presumed_self-portrait_-_WGA12798.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_presumed_self-portrait_-_WGA12798.jpg/255px-Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_presumed_self-portrait_-_WGA12798.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_presumed_self-portrait_-_WGA12798.jpg/340px-Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_presumed_self-portrait_-_WGA12798.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Leonardo_da_Vinci_-_presumed_self-portrait_-_WGA12798.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">
         Leonardo da Vinci
        </a>
        , the quintessential
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Renaissance_man" title="Renaissance man">
         Renaissance man
        </a>
        (self portrait, c. 1512).
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Landing_of_Columbus_(2).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1971" data-file-width="3000" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Landing_of_Columbus_%282%29.jpg/220px-Landing_of_Columbus_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Landing_of_Columbus_%282%29.jpg/330px-Landing_of_Columbus_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Landing_of_Columbus_%282%29.jpg/440px-Landing_of_Columbus_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Landing_of_Columbus_(2).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Explorer
        <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">
         Christopher Columbus
        </a>
        discovering
        <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">
         Americas
        </a>
        and paving the way to trade roads and the conquistadors conquests.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In the 14th and 15th centuries, northern-central Italy was divided into a number of warring
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_city-states" title="Italian city-states">
       city-states
      </a>
      , the rest of the peninsula being occupied by the larger Papal States and the
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sicily" title="Kingdom of Sicily">
       Kingdom of Sicily
      </a>
      , referred to here as Naples. Though many of these city-states were often formally subordinate to foreign rulers, as in the case of the
      <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Milan" title="Duchy of Milan">
       Duchy of Milan
      </a>
      , which was officially a
      <a href="/wiki/Constituent_state" title="Constituent state">
       constituent state
      </a>
      of the mainly Germanic
      <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">
       Holy Roman Empire
      </a>
      , the city-states generally managed to maintain de facto independence from the foreign sovereigns that had seized Italian lands following the
      <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">
       collapse
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">
       Western Roman Empire
      </a>
      . The strongest among these city-states gradually absorbed the surrounding territories giving birth to the
      <a href="/wiki/Signoria" title="Signoria">
       Signorie
      </a>
      , regional states often led by merchant families which founded local dynasties. War between the city-states was endemic, and primarily fought by armies of mercenaries known as
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Condottiere" title="Condottiere">
        condottieri
       </a>
      </i>
      , bands of soldiers drawn from around Europe, especially Germany and Switzerland, led largely by Italian captains.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
       <a href="#cite_note-50">
        [49]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Decades of fighting eventually saw
      <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Florence" title="Republic of Florence">
       Florence
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Milan" title="Duchy of Milan">
       Milan
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">
       Venice
      </a>
      emerged as the dominant players that agreed to the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peace_of_Lodi" title="Peace of Lodi">
       Peace of Lodi
      </a>
      in 1454, which saw relative calm brought to the region for the first time in centuries. This peace would hold for the next forty years.
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">
       Renaissance
      </a>
      , a period of vigorous revival of the arts and culture, originated in Italy thanks to a number of factors, as the great wealth accumulated by merchant cities, the
      <a href="/wiki/Patronage" title="Patronage">
       patronage
      </a>
      of its dominant families like the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Medici" title="Medici">
       Medici
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">
       Florence
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-strathern_51-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-strathern-51">
        [50]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
       <a href="#cite_note-52">
        [51]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the migration of
      <a href="/wiki/Greek_scholars_in_the_Renaissance" title="Greek scholars in the Renaissance">
       Greek scholars
      </a>
      and texts to Italy following the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conquest_of_Constantinople" title="Conquest of Constantinople">
       Conquest of Constantinople
      </a>
      at the hands of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_Turks" title="Ottoman Turks">
       Ottoman Turks
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica1_53-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Britannica1-53">
        [52]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harris_54-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Harris-54">
        [53]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norwich_55-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Norwich-55">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Renaissance" title="Italian Renaissance">
       Italian Renaissance
      </a>
      peaked in the mid-16th century as foreign invasions plunged the region into the turmoil of the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Wars" title="Italian Wars">
       Italian Wars
      </a>
      . The ideas and ideals of the Renaissance soon spread into
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Renaissance" title="Northern Renaissance">
       Northern Europe
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/French_Renaissance" title="French Renaissance">
       France
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/English_Renaissance" title="English Renaissance">
       England
      </a>
      and much of Europe. In the meantime, the
      <a href="/wiki/Voyages_of_Christopher_Columbus" title="Voyages of Christopher Columbus">
       discovery of the Americas
      </a>
      , the new routes to Asia discovered by the Portuguese and the rise of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman Empire
      </a>
      , all factors which eroded the traditional Italian dominance in trade with the East, caused a long economic decline in the peninsula.
     </p>
     <p>
      Following the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Wars" title="Italian Wars">
       Italian Wars
      </a>
      (1494 to 1559), ignited by the rivalry between France and Spain, the city-states gradually lost their independence and came under foreign domination, first under
      <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Spain" title="Habsburg Spain">
       Spain
      </a>
      (1559 to 1713) and then
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habsburg_Austria" title="Habsburg Austria">
       Austria
      </a>
      (1713 to 1796). In 1629–1631, a new outburst of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_plague_of_1629%E2%80%9331" title="Italian plague of 1629–31">
       plague
      </a>
      claimed about 14% of Italy's population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
       <a href="#cite_note-56">
        [55]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In addition, as the Spanish Empire started to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_decline_of_Hapsburg_Spain_in_the_seventeenth_century" title="The decline of Hapsburg Spain in the seventeenth century">
       decline
      </a>
      in the 17th century, so did its possessions in Naples, Sicily, Sardinia, and Milan. In particular,
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">
       Southern Italy
      </a>
      was impoverished and cut off from the mainstream of events in Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
       <a href="#cite_note-57">
        [56]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 18th century, as a result of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_of_Spanish_Succession" title="War of Spanish Succession">
       War of Spanish Succession
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Empire_of_Austria" title="Empire of Austria">
       Austria
      </a>
      replaced Spain as the dominant foreign power, while the
      <a href="/wiki/House_of_Savoy" title="House of Savoy">
       House of Savoy
      </a>
      emerged as a regional power expanding to
      <a href="/wiki/Piedmont" title="Piedmont">
       Piedmont
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sardinia" title="Sardinia">
       Sardinia
      </a>
      . In the same century, the two-century long decline was interrupted by the economic and state reforms pursued in several states by the ruling élites.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
       <a href="#cite_note-58">
        [57]
       </a>
      </sup>
      During the
      <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">
       Napoleonic Wars
      </a>
      , northern-central Italy was invaded and reorganised as a new
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy_(Napoleonic)" title="Kingdom of Italy (Napoleonic)">
       Kingdom of Italy
      </a>
      , a
      <a href="/wiki/Client_state" title="Client state">
       client state
      </a>
      of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Napoleonic_France" title="Napoleonic France">
       French Empire
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
       <a href="#cite_note-59">
        [58]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while the southern half of the peninsula was administered by
      <a href="/wiki/Joachim_Murat" title="Joachim Murat">
       Joachim Murat
      </a>
      , Napoleon's brother-in-law, who was crowned as
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Naples" title="Kingdom of Naples">
       King of Naples
      </a>
      . The 1814
      <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">
       Congress of Vienna
      </a>
      restored the situation of the late 18th century, but the ideals of the
      <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">
       French Revolution
      </a>
      could not be eradicated, and soon re-surfaced during the
      <a href="/wiki/Political_revolution" title="Political revolution">
       political upheavals
      </a>
      that characterised the first part of the 19th century.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Italian_unification">
       Italian unification
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_unification" title="Italian unification">
       Italian unification
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">
       Kingdom of Italy
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Italy_during_World_War_I" title="Military history of Italy during World War I">
       Military history of Italy during World War I
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:With_Victor_Emmanuel.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="423" data-file-width="672" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/With_Victor_Emmanuel.jpg/220px-With_Victor_Emmanuel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/With_Victor_Emmanuel.jpg/330px-With_Victor_Emmanuel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/With_Victor_Emmanuel.jpg/440px-With_Victor_Emmanuel.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:With_Victor_Emmanuel.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_II_of_Italy" title="Victor Emmanuel II of Italy">
         Victor Emmanuel
        </a>
        meets
        <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Garibaldi" title="Giuseppe Garibaldi">
         Giuseppe Garibaldi
        </a>
        near Teano.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Altar_della_Patria_September_2015-1.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4232" data-file-width="7324" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Altar_della_Patria_September_2015-1.jpg/220px-Altar_della_Patria_September_2015-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Altar_della_Patria_September_2015-1.jpg/330px-Altar_della_Patria_September_2015-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Altar_della_Patria_September_2015-1.jpg/440px-Altar_della_Patria_September_2015-1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Altar_della_Patria_September_2015-1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Altare_della_Patria" title="Altare della Patria">
         Altare della Patria
        </a>
        in Rome,
        <a href="/wiki/Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier" title="Tomb of the Unknown Soldier">
         resting place of the Unknown Soldier
        </a>
        . More than 650,000 Italian soldiers died on the battlefields of
        <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
         World War I
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The birth of the
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">
       Kingdom of Italy
      </a>
      was the result of efforts by Italian nationalists and monarchists loyal to the
      <a href="/wiki/House_of_Savoy" title="House of Savoy">
       House of Savoy
      </a>
      to establish a united kingdom encompassing the entire
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">
       Italian Peninsula
      </a>
      . In the context of the
      <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1848" title="Revolutions of 1848">
       1848 liberal revolutions
      </a>
      that swept through Europe, an unsuccessful
      <a href="/wiki/First_Italian_War_of_Independence" title="First Italian War of Independence">
       war
      </a>
      was declared on
      <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
       Austria
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sardinia" title="Kingdom of Sardinia">
       Kingdom of Sardinia
      </a>
      again attacked the Austrian Empire in the
      <a href="/wiki/Second_Italian_War_of_Independence" title="Second Italian War of Independence">
       Second Italian War of Independence
      </a>
      of 1859, with the aid of
      <a href="/wiki/Second_French_Empire" title="Second French Empire">
       France
      </a>
      , resulting in liberating Lombardy.
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1860–61, general
      <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Garibaldi" title="Giuseppe Garibaldi">
       Giuseppe Garibaldi
      </a>
      led the drive for unification in Naples and Sicily,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
       <a href="#cite_note-60">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
      allowing the Sardinian government led by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Camillo_Benso" title="Camillo Benso">
       Count of Cavour
      </a>
      to declare a united Italian kingdom on 17 March 1861. In 1866,
      <a href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_II_of_Italy" title="Victor Emmanuel II of Italy">
       Victor Emmanuel II
      </a>
      allied with
      <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">
       Prussia
      </a>
      during the
      <a href="/wiki/Austro-Prussian_War" title="Austro-Prussian War">
       Austro-Prussian War
      </a>
      , waging the
      <a href="/wiki/Third_Italian_War_of_Independence" title="Third Italian War of Independence">
       Third Italian War of Independence
      </a>
      which allowed Italy to annex
      <a href="/wiki/Veneto" title="Veneto">
       Venetia
      </a>
      . Finally, as France during the disastrous
      <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">
       Franco-Prussian War
      </a>
      of 1870 abandoned its garrisons in Rome, the Italians rushed to fill the power gap by
      <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_Rome" title="Capture of Rome">
       taking over the Papal States
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      The Constitutionl Law of the Kingdom of Sardinia the
      <a href="/wiki/Statuto_Albertino" title="Statuto Albertino">
       Albertine Statute
      </a>
      of 1848, was extended to the whole Kingdom of Italy in 1861, and provided for basic freedoms of the new State, but electoral laws excluded the non-propertied and uneducated classes from voting. The government of the new kingdom took place in a framework of parliamentary constitutional monarchy dominated by liberal forces. In 1913, male universal suffrage was adopted. As
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Italy" title="Northern Italy">
       Northern Italy
      </a>
      quickly industrialised, the South and rural areas of North remained underdeveloped and overpopulated, forcing millions of people to migrate abroad, while the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Socialist_Party" title="Italian Socialist Party">
       Italian Socialist Party
      </a>
