      constantly increased in strength, challenging the traditional liberal and conservative establishment. Starting from the last two decades of the 19th century, Italy developed into a colonial power by forcing
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_Somalia" title="Italian Somalia">
       Somalia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Eritrea" title="Italian Eritrea">
       Eritrea
      </a>
      and later
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Libya" title="Italian Libya">
       Libya
      </a>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_Dodecanese" title="Italian Dodecanese">
       Dodecanese
      </a>
      under its rule.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        [60]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy, nominally allied with the
      <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">
       German Empire
      </a>
      and the Empire of
      <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">
       Austria-Hungary
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Triple_Alliance_(1882)" title="Triple Alliance (1882)">
       Triple Alliance
      </a>
      , in 1915 joined the
      <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">
       Allies
      </a>
      into the war with a
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1915)" title="Treaty of London (1915)">
       promise
      </a>
      of substantial territorial gains, that included western
      <a href="/wiki/Inner_Carniola" title="Inner Carniola">
       Inner Carniola
      </a>
      , former
      <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Littoral" title="Austrian Littoral">
       Austrian Littoral
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">
       Dalmatia
      </a>
      as well as parts of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
       Ottoman Empire
      </a>
      . The war was initially inconclusive, as the Italian army get struck in a long
      <a href="/wiki/Trench_warfare" title="Trench warfare">
       attrition war
      </a>
      in the Alps, making little progress and suffering very heavy losses. Eventually, in October 1918, the Italians launched a massive offensive, culminating in the victory of
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vittorio_Veneto" title="Battle of Vittorio Veneto">
       Vittorio Veneto
      </a>
      . The Italian victory
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        [61]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
       <a href="#cite_note-63">
        [62]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
       <a href="#cite_note-64">
        [63]
       </a>
      </sup>
      marked the end of the war on the Italian Front, secured the dissolution of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire" title="Austro-Hungarian Empire">
       Austro-Hungarian Empire
      </a>
      and was chiefly instrumental in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armistice_with_Germany" title="Armistice with Germany">
       ending
      </a>
      the First World War less than two weeks later.
     </p>
     <p>
      During the war, more than 650,000 Italian soldiers and as many civilians died
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
       <a href="#cite_note-65">
        [64]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the kingdom went to the brink of bankruptcy. Under the Peace Treaties of
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Saint-Germain-en-Laye_(1919)" title="Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye (1919)">
       Saint-Germain
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rapallo,_1920" title="Treaty of Rapallo, 1920">
       Rapallo
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome,_1924" title="Treaty of Rome, 1924">
       Rome
      </a>
      , Italy obtained most of the promised territories, but not Dalmatia (except
      <a href="/wiki/Zadar" title="Zadar">
       Zara
      </a>
      ), allowing nationalists to define the victory as "
      <a href="/wiki/Mutilated_victory" title="Mutilated victory">
       mutilated
      </a>
      ". Moreover, Italy annexed the Hungarian harbour of
      <a href="/wiki/Rijeka" title="Rijeka">
       Fiume
      </a>
      , that was not part of territories promised at London but
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Impresa_di_Fiume" title="Impresa di Fiume">
       had been occupied
      </a>
      after the end of the war by
      <a href="/wiki/Gabriele_D%27Annunzio" title="Gabriele D'Annunzio">
       Gabriele D'Annunzio
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Fascist_regime">
       Fascist regime
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Fascism" title="Italian Fascism">
       Italian Fascism
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Italy_during_World_War_II" title="Military history of Italy during World War II">
       Military history of Italy during World War II
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Benito_Mussolini_Duce.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2015" height="253" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Benito_Mussolini_Duce.jpg/170px-Benito_Mussolini_Duce.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Benito_Mussolini_Duce.jpg/255px-Benito_Mussolini_Duce.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Benito_Mussolini_Duce.jpg/340px-Benito_Mussolini_Duce.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Benito_Mussolini_Duce.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">
         Benito Mussolini
        </a>
        ,
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Duce" title="Duce">
          Duce
         </a>
        </i>
        of
        <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy#Fascist_regime_.281922.E2.80.931943.29" title="Kingdom of Italy">
         Fascist Italy
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Biennio_Rosso" title="Biennio Rosso">
       socialist agitations
      </a>
      that followed the devastation of the Great War, inspired by the
      <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">
       Russian Revolution
      </a>
      , led to counter-revolution and repression throughout Italy. The liberal establishment, fearing a Soviet-style revolution, started to endorse the small
      <a href="/wiki/National_Fascist_Party" title="National Fascist Party">
       National Fascist Party
      </a>
      , led by
      <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">
       Benito Mussolini
      </a>
      . In October 1922 the
      <a href="/wiki/Blackshirts" title="Blackshirts">
       Blackshirts
      </a>
      of the National Fascist Party attempted a
      <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">
       coup
      </a>
      (the "
      <a href="/wiki/March_on_Rome" title="March on Rome">
       March on Rome
      </a>
      ") which failed but at the last minute, King
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III" title="Victor Emmanuel III">
       Victor Emmanuel III
      </a>
      refused to proclaim a state of siege and appointed Mussolini prime minister. Over the next few years, Mussolini banned all political parties and curtailed personal liberties, thus forming a
      <a href="/wiki/Totalitarianism" title="Totalitarianism">
       dictatorship
      </a>
      . These actions attracted international attention and eventually inspired similar dictatorships such as
      <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">
       Nazi Germany
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Francoist_Spain" title="Francoist Spain">
       Francoist Spain
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1935, Mussolini
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Italo-Abyssinian_War" title="Second Italo-Abyssinian War">
       invaded Ethiopia
      </a>
      , resulting in an international alienation and leading to Italy's withdrawal from the
      <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">
       League of Nations
      </a>
      ; Italy
      <a href="/wiki/Pact_of_Steel" title="Pact of Steel">
       allied with Nazi Germany
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Tripartite_Pact" title="Tripartite Pact">
       Empire of Japan
      </a>
      and strongly supported
      <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Franco" title="Francisco Franco">
       Francisco Franco
      </a>
      in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_civil_war" title="Spanish civil war">
       Spanish civil war
      </a>
      . In 1939, Italy
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_invasion_of_Albania" title="Italian invasion of Albania">
       annexed Albania
      </a>
      , a
      <i>
       de facto
      </i>
      protectorate for decades. Italy entered World War II on 10 June 1940. After initially advancing in
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_conquest_of_British_Somaliland" title="Italian conquest of British Somaliland">
       British Somaliland
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_invasion_of_Egypt" title="Italian invasion of Egypt">
       Egypt
      </a>
      , the Italians were defeated in East Africa,
      <a href="/wiki/Greco-Italian_War" title="Greco-Italian War">
       Greece
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_participation_in_the_Eastern_Front" title="Italian participation in the Eastern Front">
       Russia
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Second_Battle_of_El_Alamein" title="Second Battle of El Alamein">
       North Africa
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      After the attack on Yugoslavia by Germany and Italy, suppression of the
      <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisans" title="Yugoslav Partisans">
       Yugoslav Partisans
      </a>
      resistance and attempts to
      <a href="/wiki/Italianization" title="Italianization">
       Italianisation
      </a>
      resulted in the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_war_crimes" title="Italian war crimes">
       Italian war crimes
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JamesBurgwyn_2004_66-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-JamesBurgwyn_2004-66">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and deportation of about 25,000 people to the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_concentration_camps" title="List of Italian concentration camps">
       Italian concentration camps
      </a>
      , such as
      <a href="/wiki/Rab_concentration_camp" title="Rab concentration camp">
       Rab
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Gonars_concentration_camp" title="Gonars concentration camp">
       Gonars
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Monigo" title="Monigo">
       Monigo
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Renicci_di_Anghiari" title="Renicci di Anghiari">
       Renicci di Anghiari
      </a>
      and elsewhere. After the war, due to the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cold_war" title="Cold war">
       Cold war
      </a>
      , a long period of censorship, disinterest and denial occurred about the Italian war crimes and the Yugoslav's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foibe_killings" title="Foibe killings">
       foibe killings
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RoryCarroll_2001_67-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RoryCarroll_2001-67">
        [66]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pedaliu_JContHistory_68-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Pedaliu_JContHistory-68">
        [67]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oliva06_69-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-oliva06-69">
        [68]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blpp2004_70-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-blpp2004-70">
        [69]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Meanwhile, about 250,000 Italians and anti-communist Slavs fled to Italy in the
      <a href="/wiki/Istrian_exodus" title="Istrian exodus">
       Istrian exodus
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      An
      <a href="/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_Sicily" title="Allied invasion of Sicily">
       Allied invasion of Sicily
      </a>
      began in July 1943, leading to the collapse of the Fascist regime and the fall of Mussolini on
      <a href="/wiki/25_Luglio" title="25 Luglio">
       25 July
      </a>
      . On 8 September, Italy
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armistice_between_Italy_and_Allied_armed_forces" title="Armistice between Italy and Allied armed forces">
       surrendered
      </a>
      . The Germans shortly succeeded in taking control of northern and central Italy. The country remained a
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Campaign_(World_War_II)" title="Italian Campaign (World War II)">
       battlefield
      </a>
      for the rest of the war, as the Allies were slowly moving up from the south.
     </p>
     <p>
      In the north, the Germans set up the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Social_Republic" title="Italian Social Republic">
       Italian Social Republic
      </a>
      (RSI), a Nazi
      <a href="/wiki/Puppet_state" title="Puppet state">
       puppet state
      </a>
      with Mussolini installed as leader. The post-armistice period saw the rise of a large
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-fascist" title="Anti-fascist">
       anti-fascist
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Resistance_movement" title="Resistance movement">
       resistance movement
      </a>
      , the
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Resistenza" title="Resistenza">
        Resistenza
       </a>
      </i>
      . Hostilities ended on 29 April 1945, when the German forces in Italy surrendered.
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">
       Nearly half a million Italians (including civilians) died
      </a>
      in the conflict,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica.com_71-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-britannica.com-71">
        [70]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the Italian economy had been all but destroyed; per capita income in 1944 was at its lowest point since the beginning of the 20th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
       <a href="#cite_note-72">
        [71]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Republican_Italy">
       Republican Italy
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Italian_Republic" title="History of the Italian Republic">
       History of the Italian Republic
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="672" data-file-width="506" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg/170px-Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg/255px-Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg/340px-Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Alcide_De_Gasperi" title="Alcide De Gasperi">
         Alcide De Gasperi
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Italy" title="List of Prime Ministers of Italy">
         first
        </a>
        republican
        <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Italy" title="Prime Minister of Italy">
         Prime Minister of Italy
        </a>
        and one of the
        <a href="/wiki/Founding_fathers_of_the_European_Union" title="Founding fathers of the European Union">
         Founding Fathers
        </a>
        of the
        <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
         European Union
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy became a republic after a
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_constitutional_referendum,_1946" title="Italian constitutional referendum, 1946">
       referendum
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        [72]
       </a>
      </sup>
      held on 2 June 1946, a day celebrated since as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_Day_(Italy)" title="Republic Day (Italy)">
       Republic Day
      </a>
      . This was also the first time that Italian women were entitled to vote.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        [73]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III" title="Victor Emmanuel III">
       Victor Emmanuel III
      </a>
      's son,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Umberto_II" title="Umberto II">
       Umberto II
      </a>
      , was forced to abdicate and exiled. The
      <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy" title="Constitution of Italy">
       Republican Constitution
      </a>
      was approved on 1 January 1948. Under the
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Peace_with_Italy,_1947" title="Treaty of Peace with Italy, 1947">
       Treaty of Peace with Italy
      </a>
      of 1947, most of
      <a href="/wiki/Julian_March" title="Julian March">
       Julian March
      </a>
      was lost to
      <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">
       Yugoslavia
      </a>
      and, later, the
      <a href="/wiki/Free_Territory_of_Trieste" title="Free Territory of Trieste">
       Free Territory of Trieste
      </a>
      was divided between the two states. Italy also lost all its colonial possessions, formally ending the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Empire" title="Italian Empire">
       Italian Empire
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Fears in the Italian electorate of a possible Communist takeover proved crucial for the first universal suffrage electoral outcome on
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_general_election,_1948" title="Italian general election, 1948">
       18 April 1948
      </a>
      , when the
      <a href="/wiki/Christian_Democracy_(Italy)" title="Christian Democracy (Italy)">
       Christian Democrats
      </a>
      , under the leadership of
      <a href="/wiki/Alcide_De_Gasperi" title="Alcide De Gasperi">
       Alcide De Gasperi
      </a>
      , obtained a landslide victory. Consequently, in 1949 Italy became a member of
      <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
       NATO
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">
       Marshall Plan
      </a>
      helped to revive the Italian economy which, until the late 1960s, enjoyed a period of sustained economic growth commonly called the "
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_economic_miracle" title="Italian economic miracle">
       Economic Miracle
      </a>
      ". In 1957, Italy was a founding member of the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">
       European Economic Community
      </a>
      (EEC), which became the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
       European Union
      </a>
      (EU) in 1993.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Rome.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="432" data-file-width="550" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/35/Treaty_of_Rome.jpg/220px-Treaty_of_Rome.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/35/Treaty_of_Rome.jpg/330px-Treaty_of_Rome.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/35/Treaty_of_Rome.jpg/440px-Treaty_of_Rome.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Rome.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        In 1957 Italy was among the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EEC" title="EEC">
         EEC
        </a>
        's six founding members in the
        <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome" title="Treaty of Rome">
         Treaty of Rome
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      From the late 1960s until the early 1980s, the country experienced the
      <a href="/wiki/Years_of_Lead_(Italy)" title="Years of Lead (Italy)">
       Years of Lead
      </a>
      , a period characterised by economic crisis (especially after the
      <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">
       1973 oil crisis
      </a>
      ), widespread social conflicts and terrorist massacres carried out by opposing extremist groups, with the alleged involvement of US and Soviet intelligence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        [74]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Docs_76-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Docs-76">
        [75]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        [76]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Years of Lead culminated in the assassination of the Christian Democrat leader
      <a href="/wiki/Aldo_Moro" title="Aldo Moro">
       Aldo Moro
      </a>
      in 1978 and the
      <a href="/wiki/Bologna_massacre" title="Bologna massacre">
       Bologna railway station massacre
      </a>
      in 1980, where 85 people died.
     </p>
     <p>
      In the 1980s, for the first time since 1945, two governments were led by non-Christian-Democrat premiers: one liberal (
      <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Spadolini" title="Giovanni Spadolini">
       Giovanni Spadolini
      </a>
      ) and one socialist (
      <a href="/wiki/Bettino_Craxi" title="Bettino Craxi">
       Bettino Craxi
      </a>
      ); the Christian Democrats remained, however, the main government party. During Craxi's government, the economy recovered and Italy became the world's fifth largest industrial nation, gaining entry into the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">
       G7
      </a>
      Group. However, as a result of his spending policies, the Italian national debt skyrocketed during the Craxi era, soon passing 100% of the GDP.
     </p>
     <p>
      In the early 1990s, Italy faced significant challenges, as voters – disenchanted with political paralysis, massive public debt and the extensive corruption system (known as
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tangentopoli" title="Tangentopoli">
        Tangentopoli
       </a>
      </i>
      ) uncovered by the '
      <a href="/wiki/Mani_pulite" title="Mani pulite">
       Clean Hands
      </a>
      ' investigation – demanded radical reforms. The scandals involved all major parties, but especially those in the government coalition: the Christian Democrats, who ruled for almost 50 years, underwent a severe crisis and eventually disbanded, splitting up into several factions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
       <a href="#cite_note-78">
        [77]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Communists reorganised as a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social-democratic" title="Social-democratic">
       social-democratic
      </a>
      force. During the 1990s and the 2000s (decade), centre-right (dominated by media magnate
      <a href="/wiki/Silvio_Berlusconi" title="Silvio Berlusconi">
       Silvio Berlusconi
      </a>
      ) and centre-left coalitions (led by university professor
      <a href="/wiki/Romano_Prodi" title="Romano Prodi">
       Romano Prodi
      </a>
      ) alternatively governed the country.
     </p>
     <p>
      In the late 2000s, Italy was severely hit by the
      <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">
       Great Recession
      </a>
      . From 2008 to 2015, the country suffered 42 months of GDP recession. The economic crisis was one of the main problems that forced Berlusconi to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Resignation_of_Silvio_Berlusconi" title="Resignation of Silvio Berlusconi">
       resign
      </a>
      in 2011. The government of the conservative Prime Minister was replaced by the technocratic cabinet of
      <a href="/wiki/Mario_Monti" title="Mario Monti">
       Mario Monti
      </a>
      . Following the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_general_election,_2013" title="Italian general election, 2013">
       2013 general election
      </a>
      , the Vice-Secretary of the
      <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Italy)" title="Democratic Party (Italy)">
       Democratic Party
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Letta" title="Enrico Letta">
       Enrico Letta
      </a>
      formed a
      <a href="/wiki/Letta_Cabinet" title="Letta Cabinet">
       new government
      </a>
      at the head of a right-left
      <a href="/wiki/Grand_coalition_(Italy)" title="Grand coalition (Italy)">
       Grand coalition
      </a>
      . In 2014, challenged by the new
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Secretaries_of_the_Democratic_Party" title="List of Secretaries of the Democratic Party">
       Secretary
      </a>
      of the PD
      <a href="/wiki/Matteo_Renzi" title="Matteo Renzi">
       Matteo Renzi
      </a>
      , Letta resigned and was replaced by Renzi. The new government started important constitutional reforms such as the abolition of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_Senate" title="Italian Senate">
       Senate
      </a>
      and a new electoral law.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
       Geography
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Italy" title="Geography of Italy">
       Geography of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2167" data-file-width="1759" height="271" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg/220px-Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg/330px-Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg/440px-Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Topographic map of Italy
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy is located in
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">
       Southern Europe
      </a>
      , between latitudes
      <a href="/wiki/35th_parallel_north" title="35th parallel north">
       35°
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/47th_parallel_north" title="47th parallel north">
       47° N
      </a>
      , and longitudes
      <a href="/wiki/6th_meridian_east" title="6th meridian east">
       6°
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/19th_meridian_east" title="19th meridian east">
       19° E
      </a>
      . To the north, Italy borders
      <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">
       France
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">
       Switzerland
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">
       Austria
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">
       Slovenia
      </a>
      , and is roughly delimited by the
      <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">
       Alpine watershed
      </a>
      , enclosing the
      <a href="/wiki/Po_Valley" title="Po Valley">
       Po Valley
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Venetian_Plain" title="Venetian Plain">
       Venetian Plain
      </a>
      . To the south, it consists of the entirety of the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">
       Italian Peninsula
      </a>
      and the two
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_islands" title="Mediterranean islands">
       Mediterranean islands
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">
       Sicily
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sardinia" title="Sardinia">
       Sardinia
      </a>
      , in addition to many smaller islands. The sovereign states of
      <a href="/wiki/San_Marino" title="San Marino">
       San Marino
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">
       Vatican City
      </a>
      are
      <a href="/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave" title="Enclave and exclave">
       enclaves
      </a>
      within Italy, while
      <a href="/wiki/Campione_d%27Italia" title="Campione d'Italia">
       Campione d'Italia
      </a>
      is an Italian
      <a href="/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave" title="Enclave and exclave">
       exclave
      </a>
      in Switzerland.
     </p>
     <p>
      The country's total area is 301,230 square kilometres (116,306 sq mi), of which 294,020 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      (113,522 sq mi) is land and 7,210 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      (2,784 sq mi) is water. Including the islands, Italy has a coastline and border of 7,600 kilometres (4,722 miles) on the
      <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">
       Adriatic
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Sea" title="Ionian Sea">
       Ionian
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tyrrhenian_Sea" title="Tyrrhenian Sea">
       Tyrrhenian
      </a>
      seas (740 km (460 mi)), and borders shared with France (488 km (303 mi)), Austria (430 km (267 mi)), Slovenia (232 km (144 mi)) and Switzerland (740 km (460 mi)). San Marino (39 km (24 mi)) and Vatican City (3.2 km (2.0 mi)), both enclaves, account for the remainder.
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Apennine_Mountains" title="Apennine Mountains">
       Apennine Mountains
      </a>
      form the peninsula's backbone and the
      <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">
       Alps
      </a>
      form most of its northern boundary, where Italy's highest point is located on
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monte_Bianco" title="Monte Bianco">
       Monte Bianco
      </a>
      (4,810 m/15,782 ft).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
       <a href="#cite_note-79">
        [note 2]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Po_river" title="Po river">
       Po
      </a>
      , Italy's longest river (652 km/405 mi), flows from the Alps on the western border with France and crosses the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Padan_plain" title="Padan plain">
       Padan plain
      </a>
      on its way to the Adriatic Sea. The five largest lakes are, in order of diminishing size:
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
       <a href="#cite_note-80">
        [78]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Lake_Garda" title="Lake Garda">
       Garda
      </a>
      (367.94 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      or 142 sq mi),
      <a href="/wiki/Lake_Maggiore" title="Lake Maggiore">
       Maggiore
      </a>
      (212.51 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      or 82 sq mi, shared with Switzerland),
      <a href="/wiki/Lake_Como" title="Lake Como">
       Como
      </a>
      (145.9 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      or 56 sq mi),
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trasimeno_Lake" title="Trasimeno Lake">
       Trasimeno
      </a>
      (124.29 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      or 48 sq mi) and
      <a href="/wiki/Lake_Bolsena" title="Lake Bolsena">
       Bolsena
      </a>
      (113.55 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      or 44 sq mi).
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mont_Blanc_from_Aosta_Valley.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1840" data-file-width="3264" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Mont_Blanc_from_Aosta_Valley.JPG/220px-Mont_Blanc_from_Aosta_Valley.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Mont_Blanc_from_Aosta_Valley.JPG/330px-Mont_Blanc_from_Aosta_Valley.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Mont_Blanc_from_Aosta_Valley.JPG/440px-Mont_Blanc_from_Aosta_Valley.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mont_Blanc_from_Aosta_Valley.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monte_Bianco" title="Monte Bianco">
         Monte Bianco/Mont Blanc
        </a>
        , on the Franco-Italian border is the highest point in the
        <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
         European Union
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The country is situated at the meeting point of the Eurasian Plate and the African Plate, leading to considerable
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_Italy" title="List of earthquakes in Italy">
       seismic
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volcanism_in_Italy" title="Volcanism in Italy">
       volcanic activity
      </a>
      . There are
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Italy" title="List of volcanoes in Italy">
       14 volcanoes in Italy
      </a>
      , four of which are active:
      <a href="/wiki/Mount_Etna" title="Mount Etna">
       Etna
      </a>
      (the traditional site of
      <a href="/wiki/Vulcan_(mythology)" title="Vulcan (mythology)">
       Vulcan
      </a>
      ’s smithy),
      <a href="/wiki/Stromboli" title="Stromboli">
       Stromboli
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Vulcano" title="Vulcano">
       Vulcano
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vesuvius" title="Vesuvius">
       Vesuvius
      </a>
      . Vesuvius is the only active volcano in mainland Europe and is most famous for the destruction of
      <a href="/wiki/Pompeii" title="Pompeii">
       Pompeii
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Herculanum" title="Herculanum">
       Herculanum
      </a>
      . Several islands and hills have been created by volcanic activity, and there is still a large active
      <a href="/wiki/Caldera" title="Caldera">
       caldera
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Campi_Flegrei" title="Campi Flegrei">
       Campi Flegrei
      </a>
      north-west of Naples.
     </p>
     <p>
      Although the country comprises the Italian peninsula and most of the southern Alpine basin, some of Italy's territory extends beyond the Alpine basin and some islands are located outside the
      <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">
       Eurasian
      </a>
      continental shelf. These territories are the
      <i>
       comuni
      </i>
      of:
      <a href="/wiki/Livigno" title="Livigno">
       Livigno
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sexten" title="Sexten">
       Sexten
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Innichen" title="Innichen">
       Innichen
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Toblach" title="Toblach">
       Toblach
      </a>
      (in part),
      <a href="/wiki/Chiusaforte" title="Chiusaforte">
       Chiusaforte
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tarvisio" title="Tarvisio">
       Tarvisio
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Graun_im_Vinschgau" title="Graun im Vinschgau">
       Graun im Vinschgau
      </a>
      (in part), which are all part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Danube#Drainage_basin" title="Danube">
       Danube's drainage basin
      </a>
      , while the
      <a href="/wiki/Lago_di_Lei" title="Lago di Lei">
       Val di Lei
      </a>
      constitutes part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">
       Rhine
      </a>
      's basin and the islands of
      <a href="/wiki/Lampedusa" title="Lampedusa">
       Lampedusa
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Lampione" title="Lampione">
       Lampione
      </a>
      are on the African
      <a href="/wiki/Continental_shelf" title="Continental shelf">
       continental shelf
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">
       Environment
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Italy" title="List of national parks of Italy">
       List of national parks of Italy
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_regional_parks_of_Italy" title="List of regional parks of Italy">
       List of regional parks of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote selfreference">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Category:Environment_of_Italy" title="Category:Environment of Italy">
       Category:Environment of Italy
      </a>
      .
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Italy_natural_parks.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="330" data-file-width="270" height="269" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Italy_natural_parks.png/220px-Italy_natural_parks.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a1/Italy_natural_parks.png 1.5x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Italy_natural_parks.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        National (green) and regional (orange) parks in Italy.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      After its quick industrial growth, Italy took a long time to confront its environmental problems. After several improvements, it now ranks 84th in the world for ecological sustainability.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dev.prenhall_81-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-dev.prenhall-81">
        [79]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">
       National parks
      </a>
      cover about 5% of the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
       <a href="#cite_note-82">
        [80]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the last decade, Italy has become one of the world's leading producers of
      <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Italy" title="Renewable energy in Italy">
       renewable energy
      </a>
      , ranking as the world’s fourth largest holder of installed
      <a href="/wiki/Solar_energy" title="Solar energy">
       solar energy
      </a>
      capacity
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-REN21_83-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-REN21-83">
        [81]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BaroPhoto2010_84-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BaroPhoto2010-84">
        [82]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the sixth largest holder of
      <a href="/wiki/Wind_power" title="Wind power">
       wind power
      </a>
      capacity in 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wwea_85-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-wwea-85">
        [83]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Renewable energies now make up about 12% of the total primary and final energy consumption in Italy, with a future target share set at 17% for the year 2020.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
       <a href="#cite_note-86">
        [84]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Panorama_vicino_certaldo.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2346" data-file-width="3737" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Panorama_vicino_certaldo.jpg/220px-Panorama_vicino_certaldo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Panorama_vicino_certaldo.jpg/330px-Panorama_vicino_certaldo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Panorama_vicino_certaldo.jpg/440px-Panorama_vicino_certaldo.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Panorama_vicino_certaldo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Hilly landscape with vineyards in
        <a href="/wiki/Tuscany" title="Tuscany">
         Tuscany
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      However, air pollution remains a severe problem, especially in the industrialised north, reaching the tenth highest level worldwide of industrial carbon dioxide emissions in the 1990s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encyclopedia_of_the_Nations_87-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Encyclopedia_of_the_Nations-87">
        [85]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italy is the twelfth largest
      <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">
       carbon dioxide
      </a>
      producer.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
       <a href="#cite_note-88">
        [86]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
       <a href="#cite_note-89">
        [87]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Extensive traffic and congestion in the largest metropolitan areas continue to cause severe environmental and health issues, even if smog levels have decreased dramatically since the 1970s and 1980s, and the presence of smog is becoming an increasingly rarer phenomenon and levels of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sulphur_dioxide" title="Sulphur dioxide">
       sulphur dioxide
      </a>
      are decreasing.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
       <a href="#cite_note-90">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Many watercourses and coastal stretches have also been contaminated by industrial and agricultural activity, while because of rising water levels,
      <a href="/wiki/Venice" title="Venice">
       Venice
      </a>
      has been regularly flooded throughout recent years. Waste from industrial activity is not always disposed of by legal means and has led to permanent health effects on inhabitants of affected areas, as in the case of the
      <a href="/wiki/Seveso_disaster" title="Seveso disaster">
       Seveso disaster
      </a>
      . The country has also operated several nuclear reactors between 1963 and 1990 but, after the
      <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl_disaster" title="Chernobyl disaster">
       Chernobyl disaster
      </a>
      and a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_nuclear_power_referendum,_1987" title="Italian nuclear power referendum, 1987">
       referendum on the issue
      </a>
      the nuclear programme was terminated, a decision that was overturned by the government in 2008, planning to build up to four nuclear power plants with French technology. This was in turn struck down by a referendum following the
      <a href="/wiki/Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster">
       Fukushima nuclear accident
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
       <a href="#cite_note-91">
        [89]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Deforestation, illegal building developments and poor land-management policies have led to significant erosion all over Italy's mountainous regions, leading to major ecological disasters like the 1963
      <a href="/wiki/Vajont_Dam" title="Vajont Dam">
       Vajont Dam
      </a>
      flood, the 1998
      <a href="/wiki/Sarno" title="Sarno">
       Sarno
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sicily_mudslide_leaves_scores_dead_92-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sicily_mudslide_leaves_scores_dead-92">
        [90]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 2009
      <a href="/wiki/2009_Messina_floods_and_mudslides" title="2009 Messina floods and mudslides">
       Messina
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mudslide" title="Mudslide">
       mudslides
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
       Climate
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Isola_di_Levanzo,_Sicilia,_Italia.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Isola_di_Levanzo%2C_Sicilia%2C_Italia.jpg/220px-Isola_di_Levanzo%2C_Sicilia%2C_Italia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Isola_di_Levanzo%2C_Sicilia%2C_Italia.jpg/330px-Isola_di_Levanzo%2C_Sicilia%2C_Italia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Isola_di_Levanzo%2C_Sicilia%2C_Italia.jpg/440px-Isola_di_Levanzo%2C_Sicilia%2C_Italia.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Isola_di_Levanzo,_Sicilia,_Italia.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Southern Italy has a Mediterranean climate.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Italy" title="Climate of Italy">
       Climate of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Thanks to the great longitudinal extension of the peninsula and the mostly mountainous internal conformation, the climate of Italy is highly diverse. In most of the inland northern and central regions, the climate ranges from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical" title="Humid subtropical">
       humid subtropical
      </a>
      to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Humid_continental" title="Humid continental">
       humid continental
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">
       oceanic
      </a>
      . In particular, the climate of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Po_valley" title="Po valley">
       Po valley
      </a>
      geographical region is mostly continental, with harsh winters and hot summers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
       <a href="#cite_note-93">
        [91]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        [92]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The coastal areas of
      <a href="/wiki/Liguria" title="Liguria">
       Liguria
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tuscany" title="Tuscany">
       Tuscany
      </a>
      and most of the
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">
       South
      </a>
      generally fit the
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">
       Mediterranean climate
      </a>
      stereotype (
      <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">
       Köppen climate classification
      </a>
      Csa). Conditions on peninsular coastal areas can be very different from the interior's higher ground and valleys, particularly during the winter months when the higher altitudes tend to be cold, wet, and often snowy. The coastal regions have mild winters and warm and generally dry summers, although lowland valleys can be quite hot in summer. Average winter temperatures vary from 0
      <a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">
       °C
      </a>
      (32
      <a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">
       °F
      </a>
      ) on the Alps to 12
      <a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">
       °C
      </a>
      (54
      <a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">
       °F
      </a>
      ) in Sicily, like so the average summer temperatures range from 20
      <a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">
       °C
      </a>
      (68
      <a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">
       °F
      </a>
      ) to over 25
      <a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">
       °C
      </a>
      (77
      <a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">
       °F
      </a>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
       <a href="#cite_note-95">
        [93]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">
       Politics
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Italy" title="Politics of Italy">
       Politics of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:323px;max-width:323px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:150px;max-width:150px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Matteo_Renzi_2015.jpeg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="578" data-file-width="443" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Matteo_Renzi_2015.jpeg/148px-Matteo_Renzi_2015.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Matteo_Renzi_2015.jpeg/222px-Matteo_Renzi_2015.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Matteo_Renzi_2015.jpeg/296px-Matteo_Renzi_2015.jpeg 2x" width="148"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         <a href="/wiki/Matteo_Renzi" title="Matteo Renzi">
          Matteo Renzi
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Italy" title="Prime Minister of Italy">
          Prime Minister
         </a>
         since 2014.
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:169px;max-width:169px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Presidente_Sergio_Mattarella.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="692" data-file-width="598" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Presidente_Sergio_Mattarella.jpg/167px-Presidente_Sergio_Mattarella.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Presidente_Sergio_Mattarella.jpg/251px-Presidente_Sergio_Mattarella.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Presidente_Sergio_Mattarella.jpg/334px-Presidente_Sergio_Mattarella.jpg 2x" width="167"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Mattarella" title="Sergio Mattarella">
          Sergio Mattarella
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/President_of_Italy" title="President of Italy">
          President of the Republic
         </a>
         since 2015.
        </div>
       </div>
       <div style="clear:left">
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy has been a
      <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
       unitary
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">
       parliamentary republic
      </a>
      since 2 June 1946, when the monarchy was abolished by a
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_constitutional_referendum,_1946" title="Italian constitutional referendum, 1946">
       constitutional referendum
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/President_of_Italy" title="President of Italy">
       President of Italy
      </a>
      (
      <i>
       Presidente della Repubblica
      </i>
      ), currently
      <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Mattarella" title="Sergio Mattarella">
       Sergio Mattarella
      </a>
      since 2015, is Italy's
      <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
       head of state
      </a>
      . The President is elected for a single seven years mandate by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Italy" title="Parliament of Italy">
       Parliament of Italy
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Joint_session" title="Joint session">
       joint session
      </a>
      . Italy has a written democratic
      <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy" title="Constitution of Italy">
       constitution
      </a>
      , resulting from the work of a
      <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_Italy" title="Constituent Assembly of Italy">
       Constituent Assembly
      </a>
      formed by the representatives of all the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-fascist" title="Anti-fascist">
       anti-fascist
      </a>
      forces that contributed to the defeat of Nazi and Fascist forces during the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Civil_War" title="Italian Civil War">
       Civil War
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
       <a href="#cite_note-96">
        [94]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Government">
       Government
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Italy has a parliamentary government based on a
      <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">
       proportional
      </a>
      voting system. The parliament is perfectly
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bicameral" title="Bicameral">
       bicameral
      </a>
      : the two houses, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_of_Italy" title="Chamber of Deputies of Italy">
       Chamber of Deputies
      </a>
      (that meets in
      <a href="/wiki/Palazzo_Montecitorio" title="Palazzo Montecitorio">
       Palazzo Montecitorio
      </a>
      ) and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senate_of_Italy" title="Senate of Italy">
       Senate of the Republic
      </a>
      (that meets in
      <a href="/wiki/Palazzo_Madama" title="Palazzo Madama">
       Palazzo Madama
      </a>
      ), have the same powers. The Prime Minister, officially
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President_of_the_Council_of_Ministers_of_Italy" title="President of the Council of Ministers of Italy">
       President of the Council of Ministers
      </a>
      (
      <i>
       Presidente del Consiglio dei Ministri
      </i>
      ), is Italy's
      <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">
       head of government
      </a>
      . The Prime Minister and the cabinet are appointed by the President of the Republic, but must pass a vote of confidence in Parliament to come into office. The incumbent Prime Minister is
      <a href="/wiki/Matteo_Renzi" title="Matteo Renzi">
       Matteo Renzi
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Italy)" title="Democratic Party (Italy)">
       Democratic Party
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="851" data-file-width="1280" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg/220px-Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg/330px-Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg/440px-Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies" title="Chamber of Deputies">
         Italian Chamber of Deputies
        </a>
        in plenary section.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The prime minister is the President of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Italy" title="Council of Ministers of Italy">
       Council of Ministers
      </a>
      —which holds effective executive power— and he must receive a vote of approval from it to execute most political activities. The office is similar to those in most other
      <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">
       parliamentary systems
      </a>
      , but the leader of the Italian government is not authorised to request the dissolution of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Italy" title="Parliament of Italy">
       Parliament of Italy
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Another difference with similar offices is that the overall political responsibility for intelligence is vested in the President of the Council of Ministers. By virtue of that, the Prime Minister has exclusive power to: Coordinate intelligence policies, determining the financial resources and strengthening national cyber security; Apply and protect State secrets; Authorise agents to carry out operations, in Italy or abroad, in violation of the law.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
       <a href="#cite_note-97">
        [95]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A peculiarity of the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Parliament" title="Italian Parliament">
       Italian Parliament
      </a>
      is the representation given to
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_nationality_law" title="Italian nationality law">
       Italian citizens
      </a>
      permanently living abroad: 12 Deputies and 6 Senators elected in four distinct
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Italy#Overseas_constituency" title="Parliament of Italy">
       overseas constituencies
      </a>
      . In addition, the Italian Senate is characterised also by a small number of
      <a href="/wiki/Senator_for_life" title="Senator for life">
       senators for life
      </a>
      , appointed by the President "for outstanding patriotic merits in the social, scientific, artistic or literary field". Former Presidents of the Republic are
      <i>
       ex officio
      </i>
      life senators.
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy's three major political parties are the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partito_Democratico" title="Partito Democratico">
       Democratic Party
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Forza_Italia_(2013)" title="Forza Italia (2013)">
       Forza Italia
      </a>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Five_Stars_Movement" title="Five Stars Movement">
       Five Stars Movement
      </a>
      . During the 2013 general election these three parties won 579 out of 630 seats available in the Chamber of Deputies and 294 out of 315 in the Senate.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
       <a href="#cite_note-98">
        [96]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Most of the remaining seats were won by a short-lived
      <a href="/wiki/With_Monti_for_Italy" title="With Monti for Italy">
       electoral bloc
      </a>
      formed to support the outgoing Prime Minister
      <a href="/wiki/Mario_Monti" title="Mario Monti">
       Mario Monti
      </a>
      , the far left party
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Left,_Ecology,_Freedom" title="Left, Ecology, Freedom">
       Left, Ecology, Freedom
      </a>
      or by parties that contest elections only in one part of Italy: the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_League_(Italy)" title="Northern League (Italy)">
       Northern League
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/South_Tyrolean_People%27s_Party" title="South Tyrolean People's Party">
       South Tyrolean People's Party
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Aosta_Valley_(political_coalition)" title="Aosta Valley (political coalition)">
       Vallée d'Aoste
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Great_South_(Italy)" title="Great South (Italy)">
       Great South
      </a>
      . On 15 November 2013, 58 splinter MPs from Forza Italia founded
      <a href="/wiki/New_Centre-Right" title="New Centre-Right">
       New Centre-Right
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_criminal_justice">
       Law and criminal justice
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Italy" title="Law of Italy">
       Law of Italy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Italy" title="Judiciary of Italy">
       Judiciary of Italy
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Organised_crime_in_Italy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Organised crime in Italy (page does not exist)">
       Organised crime in Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Roma_2011_08_07_Palazzo_di_Giustizia.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1880" data-file-width="2820" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Roma_2011_08_07_Palazzo_di_Giustizia.jpg/220px-Roma_2011_08_07_Palazzo_di_Giustizia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Roma_2011_08_07_Palazzo_di_Giustizia.jpg/330px-Roma_2011_08_07_Palazzo_di_Giustizia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Roma_2011_08_07_Palazzo_di_Giustizia.jpg/440px-Roma_2011_08_07_Palazzo_di_Giustizia.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Roma_2011_08_07_Palazzo_di_Giustizia.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Cassation_(Italy)" title="Supreme Court of Cassation (Italy)">
         Supreme Court of Cassation
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The Italian judicial system is based on
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_law" title="Roman law">
       Roman law
      </a>
      modified by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Napoleonic_code" title="Napoleonic code">
       Napoleonic code
      </a>
      and later statutes. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Court_of_Cassation_(Italy)" title="Court of Cassation (Italy)">
       Supreme Court of Cassation
      </a>
      is the highest court in Italy for both criminal and civil appeal cases. The
      <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Italy" title="Constitutional Court of Italy">
       Constitutional Court of Italy
      </a>
      (
      <i>
       Corte Costituzionale
      </i>
      ) rules on the conformity of laws with the constitution and is a post–World War II innovation. Since their appearance in the middle of the 19th century,
      <a href="/wiki/Organized_crime_in_Italy" title="Organized crime in Italy">
       Italian organised crime
      </a>
      and criminal organisations have infiltrated the social and economic life of many regions in
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">
       Southern Italy
      </a>
      , the most notorious of which being the
      <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_Mafia" title="Sicilian Mafia">
       Sicilian Mafia
      </a>
      , which would later expand into some foreign countries including the United States. The
      <a href="/wiki/Mafia" title="Mafia">
       Mafia
      </a>
      receipts may reach 9%
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
       <a href="#cite_note-99">
        [97]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
       <a href="#cite_note-100">
        [98]
       </a>
      </sup>
      of Italy's GDP.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_101-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-101">
        [99]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A 2009 report identified 610
      <a href="/wiki/Comune" title="Comune">
       comuni
      </a>
      which have a strong Mafia presence, where 13 million Italians live and 14.6% of the Italian GDP is produced.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
       <a href="#cite_note-102">
        [100]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
       <a href="#cite_note-103">
        [101]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Calabria" title="Calabria">
       Calabrian
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/%27Ndrangheta" title="'Ndrangheta">
       'Ndrangheta
      </a>
      , nowadays probably the most powerful crime syndicate of Italy, accounts alone for 3% of the country's GDP.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
       <a href="#cite_note-104">
        [102]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, at 0.013 per 1,000 people, Italy has only the 47th highest murder rate
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NationMaster.com_105-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NationMaster.com-105">
        [103]
       </a>
      </sup>
      (in a group of 62 countries) and the 43rd highest number of rapes per 1,000 people in the world (in a group of 65 countries), relatively low figures among developed countries.
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement">
       Law enforcement
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Italy" title="Law enforcement in Italy">
       Law enforcement in Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Police_Lamborghini.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2487" data-file-width="3819" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Police_Lamborghini.jpg/220px-Police_Lamborghini.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Police_Lamborghini.jpg/330px-Police_Lamborghini.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Police_Lamborghini.jpg/440px-Police_Lamborghini.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Police_Lamborghini.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Lamborghini_Gallardo" title="Lamborghini Gallardo">
         Lamborghini Gallardo
        </a>
        provided to the Polizia di Stato.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Law enforcement in Italy is provided by multiple police forces, five of which are national, Italian agencies. The
      <a href="/wiki/Polizia_di_Stato" title="Polizia di Stato">
       Polizia di Stato
      </a>
      (State Police) is the civil national police of Italy. Along with patrolling, investigative and law enforcement duties, it patrols the Autostrada (Italy's Express Highway network), and oversees the security of railways, bridges and waterways. The
      <a href="/wiki/Carabinieri" title="Carabinieri">
       Carabinieri
      </a>
      is the common name for the Arma dei Carabinieri, a
      <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie" title="Gendarmerie">
       Gendarmerie
      </a>
      -like military corps with police duties. They also serve as the military police for the Italian armed forces. The
      <a href="/wiki/Guardia_di_Finanza" title="Guardia di Finanza">
       Guardia di Finanza
      </a>
      , (English: Financial Guard) is a corps under the authority of the Minister of Economy and Finance, with a role as police force. The Corps is in charge of financial, economic, judiciary and public safety. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Corpo_Forestale_dello_Stato" title="Corpo Forestale dello Stato">
       Corpo Forestale dello Stato
      </a>
      (National Forestry Department) is responsible for law enforcement in Italian national parks and forests. Their duties include enforcing poaching laws, safeguarding protected animal species and preventing forest fires.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">
       Foreign relations
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Italy" title="Foreign relations of Italy">
       Foreign relations of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3840" data-file-width="5760" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg/220px-Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg/330px-Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg/440px-Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Inauguration_EYE2014_Parlement_europ%C3%A9en_Strasbourg_9_mai_2014.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">
         European Parliament
        </a>
        . Italy is one of the 28 EU members.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy is a founding member of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Community" title="European Community">
       European Community
      </a>
      , now the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
       European Union
      </a>
      (EU), and of
      <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
       NATO
      </a>
      . Italy was admitted to the United Nations in 1955, and it is a member and strong supporter of a wide number of international organisations, such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
       Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
      </a>
      (OECD), the
      <a href="/wiki/General_Agreement_on_Tariffs_and_Trade" title="General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade">
       General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
      </a>
      /
      <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">
       World Trade Organization
      </a>
      (GATT/WTO), the
      <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">
       Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe
      </a>
      (OSCE), the
      <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
       Council of Europe
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/Central_European_Initiative" title="Central European Initiative">
       Central European Initiative
      </a>
      . Its recent turns in the rotating presidency of international organisations include the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conference_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Conference for Security and Co-operation in Europe">
       Conference for Security and Co-operation in Europe
      </a>
      (CSCE), the forerunner of the OSCE, in 1994;
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G8" title="G8">
       G8
      </a>
      ; and the EU in 2009 and from July to December 2003.
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy strongly supports multilateral international politics, endorsing the United Nations and its
      <a href="/wiki/International_security" title="International security">
       international security
      </a>
      activities. As of 2013
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Italy&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , Italy was deploying 5,296 troops abroad, engaged in 33 UN and NATO missions in 25 countries of the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
       <a href="#cite_note-106">
        [104]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italy deployed troops in support of UN peacekeeping missions in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNITAF" title="UNITAF">
       Somalia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Operation_in_Mozambique" title="United Nations Operation in Mozambique">
       Mozambique
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Integrated_Mission_in_East_Timor" title="United Nations Integrated Mission in East Timor">
       East Timor
      </a>
      and provides support for NATO and UN operations in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IFOR" title="IFOR">
       Bosnia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Force" title="Kosovo Force">
       Kosovo
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Operation_Sunrise_(Albania)" title="Operation Sunrise (Albania)">
       Albania
      </a>
      . Italy deployed over 2,000 troops in
      <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">
       Afghanistan
      </a>
      in support of
      <a href="/wiki/Operation_Enduring_Freedom" title="Operation Enduring Freedom">
       Operation Enduring Freedom
      </a>
      (OEF) from February 2003. Italy still supports international efforts to reconstruct and stabilise
      <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">
       Iraq
      </a>
      , but it had withdrawn its
      <a href="/wiki/Multi-National_Force_%E2%80%93_Iraq#2006_withdrawals" title="Multi-National Force – Iraq">
       military contingent
      </a>
      of some 3,200 troops by November 2006, maintaining only humanitarian operators and other civilian personnel. In August 2006 Italy deployed about 2,450 troops in Lebanon for the United Nations'
      <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">
       peacekeeping
      </a>
      mission
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNIFIL" title="UNIFIL">
       UNIFIL
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NewsMax_107-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NewsMax-107">
        [105]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italy is one of the largest financiers of the
      <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority" title="Palestinian National Authority">
       Palestinian National Authority
      </a>
      , contributing €60 million in 2013 alone.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
       <a href="#cite_note-108">
        [106]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
       Military
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Armed_Forces" title="Italian Armed Forces">
       Italian Armed Forces
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cavour_(550).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2176" data-file-width="3264" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cavour_%28550%29.jpg/220px-Cavour_%28550%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cavour_%28550%29.jpg/330px-Cavour_%28550%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cavour_%28550%29.jpg/440px-Cavour_%28550%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cavour_(550).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The aircraft carrier
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_aircraft_carrier_Cavour_(550)" title="Italian aircraft carrier Cavour (550)">
         <i>
          MM Cavour
         </i>
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Army" title="Italian Army">
       Italian Army
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Navy" title="Italian Navy">
       Navy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Air_Force" title="Italian Air Force">
       Air Force
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Carabinieri" title="Carabinieri">
       Carabinieri
      </a>
      collectively form the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Armed_Forces" title="Italian Armed Forces">
       Italian Armed Forces
      </a>
      , under the command of the Supreme Defence Council, presided over by the
      <a href="/wiki/President_of_Italy" title="President of Italy">
       President of Italy
      </a>
      . From 2005, military service is entirely voluntary.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
       <a href="#cite_note-109">
        [107]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2010, the Italian military had 293,202 personnel on active duty,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IISS_110-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IISS-110">
        [108]
       </a>
      </sup>
      of which 114,778 are Carabinieri.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
       <a href="#cite_note-111">
        [109]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Total Italian military spending in 2010 ranked
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">
       tenth
      </a>
      in the world, standing at $35.8 billion, equal to 1.7% of national GDP. As part of
      <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_sharing" title="Nuclear sharing">
       NATO's nuclear sharing strategy
      </a>
      Italy also hosts 90 United States
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_bombs" title="Nuclear bombs">
       nuclear bombs
      </a>
      , located in the
      <a href="/wiki/Ghedi" title="Ghedi">
       Ghedi
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Aviano_Air_Base" title="Aviano Air Base">
       Aviano
      </a>
      air bases.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
       <a href="#cite_note-112">
        [110]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Italian Army is the national ground defence force, numbering 109,703 in 2008. Its best-known combat vehicles are the
      <a href="/wiki/Dardo_IFV" title="Dardo IFV">
       Dardo
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Infantry_fighting_vehicle" title="Infantry fighting vehicle">
       infantry fighting vehicle
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centauro" title="Centauro">
       Centauro
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Tank_destroyer" title="Tank destroyer">
       tank destroyer
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Ariete" title="Ariete">
       Ariete
      </a>
