      <a href="/wiki/Tank" title="Tank">
       tank
      </a>
      , and among its aircraft the
      <a href="/wiki/Agusta_A129_Mangusta" title="Agusta A129 Mangusta">
       Mangusta
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Attack_helicopter" title="Attack helicopter">
       attack helicopter
      </a>
      , recently deployed in UN missions. It also has at its disposal a large number of
      <a href="/wiki/Leopard_1" title="Leopard 1">
       Leopard 1
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/M113_armored_personnel_carrier" title="M113 armored personnel carrier">
       M113
      </a>
      armoured vehicles.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eurofighter_Typhoon_02.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="508" data-file-width="816" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Eurofighter_Typhoon_02.jpg/220px-Eurofighter_Typhoon_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Eurofighter_Typhoon_02.jpg/330px-Eurofighter_Typhoon_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Eurofighter_Typhoon_02.jpg/440px-Eurofighter_Typhoon_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eurofighter_Typhoon_02.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Eurofighter_Typhoon" title="Eurofighter Typhoon">
         Eurofighter Typhoon
        </a>
        operated by the
        <a href="/wiki/Italian_Air_Force" title="Italian Air Force">
         Italian Air Force
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The Italian Navy in 2008 had 35,200 active personnel with 85 commissioned ships and 123 aircraft.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
       <a href="#cite_note-113">
        [111]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It is now equipping itself with a bigger
      <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">
       aircraft carrier
      </a>
      (the
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_aircraft_carrier_Cavour_(550)" title="Italian aircraft carrier Cavour (550)">
        Cavour
       </a>
      </i>
      ), new
      <a href="/wiki/Destroyer" title="Destroyer">
       destroyers
      </a>
      , submarines and multipurpose
      <a href="/wiki/Frigate" title="Frigate">
       frigates
      </a>
      . In modern times the Italian Navy, being a member of the NATO, has taken part in many coalition peacekeeping operations around the world.
     </p>
     <p>
      The Italian Air Force in 2008 had a strength of 43,882 and operated 585 aircraft, including 219 combat jets and 114 helicopters. As a stopgap and as replacement for leased
      <a href="/wiki/Panavia_Tornado" title="Panavia Tornado">
       Tornado
      </a>
      ADV interceptors, the AMI has leased 30
      <a href="/wiki/General_Dynamics_F-16_Fighting_Falcon" title="General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon">
       F-16
      </a>
      A Block 15 ADF and four F-16B Block 10 Fighting Falcons, with an option for more. The coming years will also see the introduction of 121
      <a href="/wiki/Eurofighter_Typhoon" title="Eurofighter Typhoon">
       EF2000 Eurofighter Typhoons
      </a>
      , replacing the leased F-16 Fighting Falcons. Further updates are foreseen in the Tornado IDS/IDT and
      <a href="/wiki/AMX_International_AMX" title="AMX International AMX">
       AMX
      </a>
      fleets. A transport capability is guaranteed by a fleet of 22
      <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_Martin_C-130J_Super_Hercules" title="Lockheed Martin C-130J Super Hercules">
       C-130Js
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Aeritalia_G.222" title="Aeritalia G.222">
       Aeritalia G.222s
      </a>
      of which 12 are being replaced with the newly developed G.222 variant called the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/C-27J_Spartan" title="C-27J Spartan">
       C-27J Spartan
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      An autonomous corps of the military, the Carabinieri are the
      <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie" title="Gendarmerie">
       gendarmerie
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Military_police" title="Military police">
       military police
      </a>
      of Italy, policing the military and civilian population alongside
      <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Italy" title="Law enforcement in Italy">
       Italy's other police forces
      </a>
      . While the different branches of the Carabinieri report to separate ministries for each of their individual functions, the corps reports to the Ministry of Internal Affairs when maintaining public order and security.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
       <a href="#cite_note-114">
        [112]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">
       Administrative divisions
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Italy" title="Regions of Italy">
       Regions of Italy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_cities_of_Italy" title="Metropolitan cities of Italy">
       Metropolitan cities of Italy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Italy" title="Provinces of Italy">
       Provinces of Italy
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Italy" title="Municipalities of Italy">
       Municipalities of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy is subdivided into 20 regions (
      <i>
       regioni
      </i>
      ), five of these regions having a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Autonomous_regions_with_special_statute" title="Autonomous regions with special statute">
       special autonomous status
      </a>
      that enables them to enact legislation on some of their local matters. The country is further divided into 14 metropolitan cities (
      <i>
       città metropolitane
      </i>
      ) and 96 provinces (
      <i>
       province
      </i>
      ), which in turn are subdivided in 8,047 municipalities (
      <i>
       comuni
      </i>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
       <a href="#cite_note-115">
        [113]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div style="text-shadow:white 0em 0em 0.4em; font-family:Cambria, Georgia, Times, 'Times New Roman', serif;">
      <div role="img" style="width: 455px; float: left; clear: left; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;">
       <img alt="" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="1200" height="569" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Italian_regions_provinces_white_no_labels.svg/455px-Italian_regions_provinces_white_no_labels.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Italian_regions_provinces_white_no_labels.svg/683px-Italian_regions_provinces_white_no_labels.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Italian_regions_provinces_white_no_labels.svg/910px-Italian_regions_provinces_white_no_labels.svg.png 2x" width="455"/>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:354px; top:307px">
        <a href="/wiki/Apulia" title="Apulia">
         Apulia
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:340.5px; top:338.5px">
        <a href="/wiki/Basilicata" title="Basilicata">
         Basilicata
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:332.8px; top:379.2px">
        <a href="/wiki/Calabria" title="Calabria">
         Calabria
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:256.3px; top:447.8px">
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">
          Sicily
         </a>
        </i>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:277.5px; top:275.5px">
        <a href="/wiki/Molise" title="Molise">
         Molise
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:275.6px; top:308.8px">
        <a href="/wiki/Campania" title="Campania">
         Campania
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:255px; top:239.5px">
        <a href="/wiki/Abruzzo" title="Abruzzo">
         Abruzzo
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:210px; top:262px">
        <a href="/wiki/Lazio" title="Lazio">
         Lazio
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:205.5px; top:212.5px">
        <a href="/wiki/Umbria" title="Umbria">
         Umbria
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:232.5px; top:185.5px">
        <a href="/wiki/Marche" title="Marche">
         Marche
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:160.5px; top:194.5px">
        <a href="/wiki/Tuscany" title="Tuscany">
         Tuscany
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:84px; top:352px">
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Sardinia" title="Sardinia">
          Sardinia
         </a>
        </i>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:142.5px; top:140.5px">
        <a href="/wiki/Emilia-Romagna" title="Emilia-Romagna">
         Emilia-Romagna
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:79.5px; top:153.5px">
        <a href="/wiki/Liguria" title="Liguria">
         Liguria
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:34.5px; top:118px">
        <a href="/wiki/Piedmont" title="Piedmont">
         Piedmont
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:226.5px; top:52.45px">
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Friuli-Venezia_Giulia" title="Friuli-Venezia Giulia">
          Friuli
          <br/>
          Venezia Giulia
         </a>
        </i>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:32.4px; top:78.4px">
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Aosta_Valley" title="Aosta Valley">
          Aosta
          <br/>
          Valley
         </a>
        </i>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:151.885px; top:37.5px">
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/South_Tyrol" title="South Tyrol">
          South Tyrol
         </a>
        </i>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:155.525px; top:64.8px">
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Trentino" title="Trentino">
          Trentino
         </a>
        </i>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:187.5px; top:82px">
        <a href="/wiki/Veneto" title="Veneto">
         Veneto
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:102px; top:86.5px">
        <a href="/wiki/Lombardy" title="Lombardy">
         Lombardy
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:294px; top:212px">
        <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">
         <span style="font-style: italic; color: #48A3B5;">
          Adriatic Sea
         </span>
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:386px; top:428px">
        <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Sea" title="Ionian Sea">
         <span style="font-style: italic; color: #48A3B5;">
          Ionian Sea
         </span>
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:66px; top:468px">
        <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
         <span style="font-style: italic; color: #48A3B5;">
          Mediterranean Sea
         </span>
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:146px; top:348px">
        <a href="/wiki/Tyrrhenian_Sea" title="Tyrrhenian Sea">
         <span style="font-style: italic; color: #48A3B5;">
          Tyrrhenian Sea
         </span>
        </a>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:68.8px; top:190px">
        <a href="/wiki/Ligurian_Sea" title="Ligurian Sea">
         <span style="font-style: italic; color: #48A3B5;">
          Ligurian Sea
         </span>
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <br/>
     </p>
     <table class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:45%; float:right;">
      <tr>
       <th>
        Region
       </th>
       <th>
        Capital
       </th>
       <th>
        Area (km²)
       </th>
       <th>
        Area (sq mi)
       </th>
       <th>
        Population
       </th>
      </tr>

     </table>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
       Economy
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Italy" title="Economy of Italy">
       Economy of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2015-03-03_Geneva_Motor_Show_3908.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/2015-03-03_Geneva_Motor_Show_3908.JPG/220px-2015-03-03_Geneva_Motor_Show_3908.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/2015-03-03_Geneva_Motor_Show_3908.JPG/330px-2015-03-03_Geneva_Motor_Show_3908.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/2015-03-03_Geneva_Motor_Show_3908.JPG/440px-2015-03-03_Geneva_Motor_Show_3908.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2015-03-03_Geneva_Motor_Show_3908.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Ferrari_488" title="Ferrari 488">
         Ferrari 488
        </a>
        . Italy maintains an innovative
        <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry" title="Automotive industry">
         automotive industry
        </a>
        , and is one of the world's largest exporters of manufactured goods.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy has a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Capitalist" title="Capitalist">
       capitalist
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">
       mixed economy
      </a>
      , ranking as the third-largest in the
      <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
       Eurozone
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">
       eighth-largest
      </a>
      in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMF2014_116-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IMF2014-116">
        [114]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The country is a founding member of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">
       G7
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Eight" title="Group of Eight">
       G8
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
       Eurozone
      </a>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
       OECD
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy is regarded as one of the world's most industrialised nations and a leading country in
      <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">
       world trade and exports
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
       <a href="#cite_note-117">
        [115]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
       <a href="#cite_note-118">
        [116]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
       <a href="#cite_note-119">
        [117]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It is a highly
      <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">
       developed country
      </a>
      , with the world's 8th highest
      <a href="/wiki/Quality_of_life" title="Quality of life">
       quality of life
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist.com_21-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-economist.com-21">
        [20]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the 25th
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">
       Human Development Index
      </a>
      . The country is well known for its creative and innovative business,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
       <a href="#cite_note-120">
        [118]
       </a>
      </sup>
      a large and competitive agricultural sector
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
       <a href="#cite_note-121">
        [119]
       </a>
      </sup>
      (Italy is the world's largest wine producer),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
       <a href="#cite_note-122">
        [120]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and for its influential and high-quality automobile, machinery, food, design and fashion industry.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
       <a href="#cite_note-123">
        [121]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
       <a href="#cite_note-124">
        [122]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
       <a href="#cite_note-125">
        [123]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nutella_ak.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1004" data-file-width="1514" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Nutella_ak.jpg/220px-Nutella_ak.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Nutella_ak.jpg/330px-Nutella_ak.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Nutella_ak.jpg/440px-Nutella_ak.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nutella_ak.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Nutella" title="Nutella">
         Nutella
        </a>
        , manufactured by
        <a href="/wiki/Ferrero_SpA" title="Ferrero SpA">
         Ferrero SpA
        </a>
        . Italy is the largest chocolate making country in the world.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
         <a href="#cite_note-126">
          [124]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy is the world's sixth largest
      <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">
       manufacturing
      </a>
      country,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
       <a href="#cite_note-127">
        [125]
       </a>
      </sup>
      characterised by a smaller number of global multinational corporations than other economies of comparable size and a large number of dynamic
      <a href="/wiki/Small_and_medium-sized_enterprises" title="Small and medium-sized enterprises">
       small and medium-sized enterprises
      </a>
      , notoriously clustered in several
      <a href="/wiki/Industrial_district" title="Industrial district">
       industrial districts
      </a>
      , which are the backbone of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_industry" title="Italian industry">
       Italian industry
      </a>
      . This has produced a manufacturing sector often focused on the export of
      <a href="/wiki/Niche_market" title="Niche market">
       niche market
      </a>
      and luxury products, that if on one side is less capable to compete on the quantity, on the other side is more capable of facing the competition from China and other emerging Asian economies based on lower labour costs, with higher quality products.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
       <a href="#cite_note-128">
        [126]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The country was the world's 7th largest exporter in 2009.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
       <a href="#cite_note-129">
        [127]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italy's closest trade ties are with the other countries of the European Union, with whom it conducts about 59% of its total trade. Its largest EU trade partners, in order of market share, are Germany (12.9%), France (11.4%), and Spain (7.4%).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia.gov_130-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-130">
        [128]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Finally, tourism is one of the fastest growing and profitable sectors of the national economy: with 48.6 million international tourist arrivals and total receipts estimated at $45.5 billion in 2014, Italy was the fifth most visited country and the sixth highest tourism earner in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
       <a href="#cite_note-131">
        [129]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eurozone.svg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="456" data-file-width="450" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/220px-Eurozone.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/330px-Eurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/440px-Eurozone.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eurozone.svg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Italy is part of a monetary union, the
        <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
         Eurozone
        </a>
        (dark blue), and of the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internal_Market_(European_Union)" title="Internal Market (European Union)">
         EU single market
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy is part of the European single market which represents more than 500 million consumers. Several domestic commercial policies are determined by agreements among European Union (EU) members and by EU legislation. Italy introduced the common European currency, the
      <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">
       Euro
      </a>
      in 2002.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-euroc_132-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-euroc-132">
        [130]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
       <a href="#cite_note-133">
        [131]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It is a member of the Eurozone which represents around 330 million citizens. Its monetary policy is set by the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">
       European Central Bank
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy has been hit very hard by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%9308" title="Financial crisis of 2007–08">
       Financial crisis of 2007–08
      </a>
      and the subsequent
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_sovereign-debt_crisis" title="European sovereign-debt crisis">
       European sovereign-debt crisis
      </a>
      , that exacerbated the country's structural problems.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
       <a href="#cite_note-134">
        [132]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Effectively, after a strong GDP growth of 5–6% per year from the 1950s to the early 1970s,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
       <a href="#cite_note-135">
        [133]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and a progressive slowdown in the 1980-90s, the country virtually stagnated in the 2000s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
       <a href="#cite_note-136">
        [134]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
       <a href="#cite_note-137">
        [135]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The political efforts to revive growth with massive government spending eventually produced a severe rise in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_debt" title="Public debt">
       public debt
      </a>
      , that stood at over 135% of GDP in 2014, ranking second in the EU only after the Greek one (at 174%).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
       <a href="#cite_note-138">
        [136]
       </a>
      </sup>
      For all that, the largest chunk of
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_government_debt" title="Italian government debt">
       Italian public debt
      </a>
      is owned by national subjects, a major difference between Italy and Greece,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
       <a href="#cite_note-139">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the level of
      <a href="/wiki/Household_debt" title="Household debt">
       household debt
      </a>
      is much lower than the OECD average.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
       <a href="#cite_note-140">
        [138]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A gaping
      <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Italy#North.E2.80.93South_divide" title="Economy of Italy">
       North–South divide
      </a>
      is a major factor of socio-economic weakness.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
       <a href="#cite_note-141">
        [139]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It can be noted by the huge difference in statistical income between the northern and southern regions and municipalities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
       <a href="#cite_note-142">
        [140]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The richest region, Lombardy, earns 127% of the national GDP per capita, while the poorest, Calabria, only 61%
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
       <a href="#cite_note-143">
        [141]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The unemployment rate (11.9%) stands slightly above the Eurozone average,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
       <a href="#cite_note-144">
        [142]
       </a>
      </sup>
      however the average figure is 7.9% in the North and 20.2% in the South.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
       <a href="#cite_note-145">
        [143]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Agricolture">
       Agricolture
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Toscana_igt_wine.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="1936" height="201" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Toscana_igt_wine.jpg/150px-Toscana_igt_wine.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Toscana_igt_wine.jpg/225px-Toscana_igt_wine.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Toscana_igt_wine.jpg/300px-Toscana_igt_wine.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Toscana_igt_wine.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Tuscan_wine" title="Tuscan wine">
         Tuscan wine
        </a>
        ; Italy is the largest producer of wine in the world
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chianti-colline2-2.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="869" data-file-width="1153" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Chianti-colline2-2.jpg/220px-Chianti-colline2-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Chianti-colline2-2.jpg/330px-Chianti-colline2-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Chianti-colline2-2.jpg/440px-Chianti-colline2-2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chianti-colline2-2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Vineyards in the
        <a href="/wiki/Chianti" title="Chianti">
         Chianti
        </a>
        region. The Italian food industry is well known for the high quality and variety of its products.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      According to the last national agricultural census, there were 1.6 million farms in 2010 (-32.4% since 2000) covering 12.7 million hectares (63% of which are located in
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">
       Southern Italy
      </a>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-agrocensus_146-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-agrocensus-146">
        [144]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The vast majority (99%) are family-operated and small, averaging only 8 hectares in size.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-agrocensus_146-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-agrocensus-146">
        [144]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Of the total surface area in agricultural use (forestry excluded),
      <a href="/wiki/Grain" title="Grain">
       grain
      </a>
      fields take up 31%,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Olive_tree" title="Olive tree">
       olive tree
      </a>
      orchards 8.2%,
      <a href="/wiki/Vineyard" title="Vineyard">
       vineyards
      </a>
      5.4%,
      <a href="/wiki/Citrus" title="Citrus">
       citrus
      </a>
      orchards 3.8%,
      <a href="/wiki/Sugar_beet" title="Sugar beet">
       sugar beets
      </a>
      1.7%, and
      <a href="/wiki/Horticulture" title="Horticulture">
       horticulture
      </a>
      2.4%. The remainder is primarily dedicated to pastures (25.9%) and feed grains (11.6%).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-agrocensus_146-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-agrocensus-146">
        [144]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy is the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_wine-producing_countries" title="List of wine-producing countries">
       first largest producer of wine
      </a>
      in the world,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OIVstats_147-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-OIVstats-147">
        [145]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and one of the leading in
      <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">
       olive oil
      </a>
      , fruits (
      <a href="/wiki/Apple" title="Apple">
       apples
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Olive" title="Olive">
       olives
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Grape" title="Grape">
       grapes
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Orange_(fruit)" title="Orange (fruit)">
       oranges
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Lemon" title="Lemon">
       lemons
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Pear" title="Pear">
       pears
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Apricot" title="Apricot">
       apricots
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Hazelnut" title="Hazelnut">
       hazelnuts
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Peach" title="Peach">
       peaches
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Cherry" title="Cherry">
       cherries
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Plum" title="Plum">
       plums
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Strawberry" title="Strawberry">
       strawberries
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Kiwifruit" title="Kiwifruit">
       kiwifruits
      </a>
      ), and vegetables (especially
      <a href="/wiki/Artichoke" title="Artichoke">
       artichokes
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Tomato" title="Tomato">
       tomatoes
      </a>
      ). The most famous
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_wine" title="Italian wine">
       Italian wines
      </a>
      are probably the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tuscany_(wine)" title="Tuscany (wine)">
       Tuscan
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Chianti" title="Chianti">
       Chianti
      </a>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Piedmont_(wine)" title="Piedmont (wine)">
       Piedmontese
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Barolo" title="Barolo">
       Barolo
      </a>
      . Other famous wines are
      <a href="/wiki/Barbaresco" title="Barbaresco">
       Barbaresco
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Barbera_d%27Asti" title="Barbera d'Asti">
       Barbera d'Asti
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Brunello_di_Montalcino" title="Brunello di Montalcino">
       Brunello di Montalcino
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Frascati_DOC" title="Frascati DOC">
       Frascati
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Montepulciano_d%27Abruzzo" title="Montepulciano d'Abruzzo">
       Montepulciano d'Abruzzo
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Morellino_di_Scansano" title="Morellino di Scansano">
       Morellino di Scansano
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/Sparkling_wine" title="Sparkling wine">
       sparkling wines
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Franciacorta_DOCG" title="Franciacorta DOCG">
       Franciacorta
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Prosecco" title="Prosecco">
       Prosecco
      </a>
      . Quality goods in which Italy specialises, particularly the already mentioned wines and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_DOP_cheeses" title="List of Italian DOP cheeses">
       regional cheeses
      </a>
      , are often protected under the quality assurance labels
      <a href="/wiki/Denominazione_di_origine_controllata" title="Denominazione di origine controllata">
       DOC/DOP
      </a>
      . This
      <a href="/wiki/Geographical_indications_and_traditional_specialities_in_the_European_Union" title="Geographical indications and traditional specialities in the European Union">
       geographical indication certificate
      </a>
      , which is attributed by the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
       European Union
      </a>
      , is considered important in order to avoid confusion with low-quality mass-produced
      <a href="/wiki/Ersatz_good" title="Ersatz good">
       ersatz products
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">
       Tourism
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Italy" title="Tourism in Italy">
       Tourism in Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rom_fountain_of_Trevi.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Rom_fountain_of_Trevi.jpg/220px-Rom_fountain_of_Trevi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Rom_fountain_of_Trevi.jpg/330px-Rom_fountain_of_Trevi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Rom_fountain_of_Trevi.jpg/440px-Rom_fountain_of_Trevi.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rom_fountain_of_Trevi.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Tourists at the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trevi_fountain" title="Trevi fountain">
         Trevi fountain
        </a>
        , Rome.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      With 50.7 million
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tourist" title="Tourist">
       tourists
      </a>
      a year (2015), Italy is the fifth
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Most_visited_countries" title="Most visited countries">
       most visited country
      </a>
      in international tourism arrivals, and the sixth highest tourism earner in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
       <a href="#cite_note-148">
        [146]
       </a>
      </sup>
      People mainly visit Italy for its rich
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_art" title="Italian art">
       art
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">
       cuisine
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_Italy" title="History of Italy">
       history
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_fashion" title="Italian fashion">
       fashion
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Italy" title="Culture of Italy">
       culture
      </a>
      , its beautiful coastline and beaches, its mountains, and priceless ancient monuments. Italy is also home to
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Italy" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Italy">
       fifty
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
       UNESCO
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
       World Heritage Sites
      </a>
      , the most in the world. Tourism is one of Italy's fastest growing and most profitable industrial sectors, with an estimated revenue of €189.1 billion.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2016_Edition_149-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2016_Edition-149">
        [147]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">
       Infrastructure
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Italy" title="Transport in Italy">
       Transport in Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Frecciarossa_1000_at_InnoTrans_2014.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1707" data-file-width="2560" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Frecciarossa_1000_at_InnoTrans_2014.jpg/220px-Frecciarossa_1000_at_InnoTrans_2014.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Frecciarossa_1000_at_InnoTrans_2014.jpg/330px-Frecciarossa_1000_at_InnoTrans_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Frecciarossa_1000_at_InnoTrans_2014.jpg/440px-Frecciarossa_1000_at_InnoTrans_2014.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Frecciarossa_1000_at_InnoTrans_2014.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Ferrovie_dello_Stato_Italiane" title="Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane">
         FS
        </a>
        '
        <a href="/wiki/Frecciarossa_1000" title="Frecciarossa 1000">
         Frecciarossa 1000
        </a>
        high speed train, with a maximum speed of 400 km/h (249 mph),
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
         <a href="#cite_note-150">
          [148]
         </a>
        </sup>
        is the fastest train in Italy and Europe.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 2004 the transport sector in Italy generated a turnover of about 119.4 billion euros, employing 935,700 persons in 153,700 enterprises. Regarding the national road network, in 2002 there were 668,721 km (415,524 mi) of serviceable roads in Italy, including 6,487 km (4,031 mi) of motorways, state-owned but privately operated by
      <a href="/wiki/Atlantia_(company)" title="Atlantia (company)">
       Atlantia
      </a>
      . In 2005, about 34,667,000
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Automobile" title="Automobile">
       passenger cars
      </a>
      (590 cars per 1,000 people) and 4,015,000 goods vehicles circulated on the national road network.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-European_Commission_151-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-European_Commission-151">
        [149]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Italy" title="Rail transport in Italy">
       national railway network
      </a>
      , state-owned and operated by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ferrovie_dello_Stato" title="Ferrovie dello Stato">
       Ferrovie dello Stato
      </a>
      , in 2008 totalled 16,529 km (10,271 mi) of which 11,727 km (7,287 mi) is electrified, and on which 4,802 locomotives and railcars run.
     </p>
     <p>
      The national inland
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Waterways" title="Waterways">
       waterways
      </a>
      network comprised 1,477 km (918 mi) of navigable rivers and channels in 2002. In 2004 there were approximately 30 main airports (including the two
      <a href="/wiki/Airline_hub" title="Airline hub">
       hubs
      </a>
      of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malpensa_International_Airport" title="Malpensa International Airport">
       Malpensa International
      </a>
      in Milan and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci_International_Airport" title="Leonardo da Vinci International Airport">
       Leonardo da Vinci International
      </a>
      in Rome) and 43 major seaports (including the seaport of
      <a href="/wiki/Genoa" title="Genoa">
       Genoa
      </a>
      , the country's largest and second largest in the
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
       Mediterranean Sea
      </a>
      ). In 2005 Italy maintained a civilian air fleet of about 389,000 units and a merchant fleet of 581 ships.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-European_Commission_151-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-European_Commission-151">
        [149]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy needs to import about 80% of its energy requirements.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
       <a href="#cite_note-152">
        [150]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
       <a href="#cite_note-153">
        [151]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
       <a href="#cite_note-154">
        [152]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Italy" title="Water supply and sanitation in Italy">
       Water supply and sanitation in Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy does not invest enough to maintain its drinking water supply and sanitation infrastructure, while water and sanitation tariffs are among the lowest in the European Union. The Galli Law, passed in 1993, aimed at raising the level of investment and to improve service quality by consolidating service providers, making them more efficient and increasing the level of cost recovery through tariff revenues. Despite these reforms, investment levels have declined and remain far from sufficient.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
       <a href="#cite_note-155">
        [153]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
       <a href="#cite_note-156">
        [154]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
       <a href="#cite_note-157">
        [155]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">
       Science and technology
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Italy" title="Science and technology in Italy">
       Science and technology in Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1010" data-file-width="1010" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg/220px-Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg/330px-Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg/440px-Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Clockwise from left:
        <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Volta" title="Alessandro Volta">
         Alessandro Volta
        </a>
        , inventor of the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electric_battery" title="Electric battery">
         electric battery
        </a>
        ;
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wmnqsy_158-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-wmnqsy-158">
          [156]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Galilei" title="Galileo Galilei">
         Galileo Galilei
        </a>
        , recognized as the Father of modern science, physics and observational astronomy;
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Einstein_159-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Einstein-159">
          [157]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <a href="/wiki/Guglielmo_Marconi" title="Guglielmo Marconi">
         Guglielmo Marconi
        </a>
        , inventor of the long-distance radio transmission;
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
         <a href="#cite_note-160">
          [158]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Fermi" title="Enrico Fermi">
         Enrico Fermi
        </a>
        , creator of the first
        <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">
         nuclear reactor
        </a>
        , the
        <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Pile-1" title="Chicago Pile-1">
         Chicago Pile-1
        </a>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
         <a href="#cite_note-161">
          [159]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Through the centuries, Italy has fostered the scientific community that produced many major discoveries in physics and the other sciences. During the
      <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">
       Renaissance
      </a>
      Italian polymaths such as
      <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">
       Leonardo da Vinci
      </a>
      (1452–1519),
      <a href="/wiki/Michelangelo" title="Michelangelo">
       Michelangelo
      </a>
      (1475–1564) and
      <a href="/wiki/Leon_Battista_Alberti" title="Leon Battista Alberti">
       Leon Battista Alberti
      </a>
      (1404–72) made important contributions to a variety of fields, including biology, architecture, and engineering.
      <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Galilei" title="Galileo Galilei">
       Galileo Galilei
      </a>
      (1564–1642), a physicist, mathematician and astronomer, played a major role in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scientific_Revolution" title="Scientific Revolution">
       Scientific Revolution
      </a>
      . His achievements include key improvements to the
      <a href="/wiki/Telescope" title="Telescope">
       telescope
      </a>
      and consequent astronomical observations, and ultimately the triumph of
      <a href="/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus" title="Nicolaus Copernicus">
       Copernicanism
      </a>
      over the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_model" title="Ptolemaic model">
       Ptolemaic model
      </a>
      .
      <br/>
      Other astronomers suchs as
      <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Domenico_Cassini" title="Giovanni Domenico Cassini">
       Giovanni Domenico Cassini
      </a>
      (1625–1712) and
      <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Schiaparelli" title="Giovanni Schiaparelli">
       Giovanni Schiaparelli
      </a>
      (1835–1910) made many important discoveries about the
      <a href="/wiki/Solar_System" title="Solar System">
       Solar System
      </a>
      . In mathematics,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joseph_Louis_Lagrange" title="Joseph Louis Lagrange">
       Joseph Louis Lagrange
      </a>
      (born Giuseppe Lodovico Lagrangia, 1736–1813) was active before leaving Italy.
      <a href="/wiki/Fibonacci" title="Fibonacci">
       Fibonacci
      </a>
      (c. 1170 – c. 1250), and
      <a href="/wiki/Gerolamo_Cardano" title="Gerolamo Cardano">
       Gerolamo Cardano
      </a>
      (1501–76) made fundamental advances in mathematics.
      <a href="/wiki/Luca_Pacioli" title="Luca Pacioli">
       Luca Pacioli
      </a>
      established
      <a href="/wiki/Accounting" title="Accounting">
       accounting
      </a>
      to the world. Physicist
      <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Fermi" title="Enrico Fermi">
       Enrico Fermi
      </a>
      (1901–54), a Nobel prize laureate, led the team in Chicago that developed the
      <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Pile-1" title="Chicago Pile-1">
       first nuclear reactor
      </a>
      and is also noted for his many other contributions to physics, including the co-development of the
      <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">
       quantum theory
      </a>
      and was one of the key figures in the creation of the
      <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">
       nuclear weapon
      </a>
      . He,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emilio_G._Segr%C3%A8" title="Emilio G. Segrè">
       Emilio G. Segrè
      </a>
      , and a number of Italian physicists were forced to leave Italy in the 1930s by
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Racial_Laws" title="Italian Racial Laws">
       Fascist laws against Jews
      </a>
      , including
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emilio_G._Segr%C3%A8" title="Emilio G. Segrè">
       Emilio G. Segrè
      </a>
      (1905–89) (who discovered the elements
      <a href="/wiki/Technetium" title="Technetium">
       technetium
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Astatine" title="Astatine">
       astatine
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/Antiproton" title="Antiproton">
       antiproton
      </a>
      ),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
       <a href="#cite_note-162">
        [160]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Bruno_Rossi" title="Bruno Rossi">
       Bruno Rossi
      </a>
      (1905–93), a pioneer in Cosmic Rays and X-ray astronomy.
     </p>
     <p>
      Other prominent physicists include:
      <a href="/wiki/Amedeo_Avogadro" title="Amedeo Avogadro">
       Amedeo Avogadro
      </a>
      (most noted for his contributions to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Molecular_theory" title="Molecular theory">
       molecular theory
      </a>
      , in particular the
      <a href="/wiki/Avogadro%27s_law" title="Avogadro's law">
       Avogadro's law
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Avogadro_constant" title="Avogadro constant">
       Avogadro constant
      </a>
      ),
      <a href="/wiki/Evangelista_Torricelli" title="Evangelista Torricelli">
       Evangelista Torricelli
      </a>
      (inventor of
      <a href="/wiki/Barometer" title="Barometer">
       barometer
      </a>
      ),
      <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Volta" title="Alessandro Volta">
       Alessandro Volta
      </a>
      (inventor of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electric_battery" title="Electric battery">
       electric battery
      </a>
      ),
      <a href="/wiki/Guglielmo_Marconi" title="Guglielmo Marconi">
       Guglielmo Marconi
      </a>
      (inventor of
      <a href="/wiki/Radio" title="Radio">
       radio
      </a>
      ),
      <a href="/wiki/Ettore_Majorana" title="Ettore Majorana">
       Ettore Majorana
      </a>
      (who discovered the
      <a href="/wiki/Majorana_fermion" title="Majorana fermion">
       Majorana fermions
      </a>
      ),
      <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Rubbia" title="Carlo Rubbia">
       Carlo Rubbia
      </a>
      (1984 Nobel Prize in Physics for work leading to the discovery of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/W_and_Z_particles" title="W and Z particles">
       W and Z particles
      </a>
      at
      <a href="/wiki/CERN" title="CERN">
       CERN
      </a>
      ). In biology,
      <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Redi" title="Francesco Redi">
       Francesco Redi
      </a>
      has been the first to challenge the theory of spontaneous generation by demonstrating that maggots come from eggs of flies and he described 180 parasites in details and
      <a href="/wiki/Marcello_Malpighi" title="Marcello Malpighi">
       Marcello Malpighi
      </a>
      founded
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Microscopic_anatomy" title="Microscopic anatomy">
       microscopic anatomy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Lazzaro_Spallanzani" title="Lazzaro Spallanzani">
       Lazzaro Spallanzani
      </a>
      conducted important research in bodily functions, animal reproduction, and cellular theory,
      <a href="/wiki/Camillo_Golgi" title="Camillo Golgi">
       Camillo Golgi
      </a>
      , whose many achievements include the discovery of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Golgi_complex" title="Golgi complex">
       Golgi complex
      </a>
      , paved the way to the acceptance of the
      <a href="/wiki/Neuron_doctrine" title="Neuron doctrine">
       Neuron doctrine
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Rita_Levi-Montalcini" title="Rita Levi-Montalcini">
       Rita Levi-Montalcini
      </a>
      discovered the
      <a href="/wiki/Nerve_growth_factor" title="Nerve growth factor">
       nerve growth factor
      </a>
      (awarded 1986 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine). In chemistry,
      <a href="/wiki/Giulio_Natta" title="Giulio Natta">
       Giulio Natta
      </a>
      received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1963 for his work on high
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polymers" title="Polymers">
       polymers
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Occhialini" title="Giuseppe Occhialini">
       Giuseppe Occhialini
      </a>
      received the
      <a href="/wiki/Wolf_Prize_in_Physics" title="Wolf Prize in Physics">
       Wolf Prize in Physics
      </a>
      for the discovery of the
      <a href="/wiki/Pion" title="Pion">
       pion
      </a>
      or pi-
      <a href="/wiki/Meson" title="Meson">
       meson
      </a>
      decay in 1947.
      <a href="/wiki/Ennio_de_Giorgi" title="Ennio de Giorgi">
       Ennio de Giorgi
      </a>
      , a
      <a href="/wiki/Wolf_Prize_in_Mathematics" title="Wolf Prize in Mathematics">
       Wolf Prize in Mathematics
      </a>
      recipient in 1990, solved
      <a href="/wiki/Bernstein%27s_problem" title="Bernstein's problem">
       Bernstein's problem
      </a>
      about
      <a href="/wiki/Minimal_surface" title="Minimal surface">
       minimal surfaces
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Hilbert%27s_nineteenth_problem" title="Hilbert's nineteenth problem">
       19th Hilbert problem
      </a>
      on the regularity of solutions of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Elliptic_partial_differential_equations" title="Elliptic partial differential equations">
       Elliptic partial differential equations
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
       Demographics
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Italy" title="Demographics of Italy">
       Demographics of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_Italy_2011_census.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="438" data-file-width="321" height="273" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Population_density_Italy_2011_census.png/200px-Population_density_Italy_2011_census.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Population_density_Italy_2011_census.png/300px-Population_density_Italy_2011_census.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/24/Population_density_Italy_2011_census.png 2x" width="200"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_Italy_2011_census.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Map of population density in Italy as at the 2011 census.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      At the end of 2013, Italy had 60,782,668 inhabitants.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
       <a href="#cite_note-163">
        [161]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The resulting population density, at 202 inhabitants per square kilometre (520/sq mi), is higher than that of most Western European countries. However, the distribution of the population is widely uneven. The most densely populated areas are the Po Valley (that accounts for almost a half of the national population) and the metropolitan areas of Rome and Naples, while vast regions such as the Alps and Apennines highlands, the plateaus of Basilicata and the island of Sardinia are very sparsely populated.
     </p>
     <p>
      The population of Italy almost doubled during the 20th century, but the pattern of growth was extremely uneven because of large-scale internal migration from the rural South to the industrial cities of the North, a phenomenon which happened as a consequence of the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_economic_miracle" title="Italian economic miracle">
       Italian economic miracle
      </a>
      of the 1950–1960s. High fertility and birth rates persisted until the 1970s, after which they start to dramatically decline, leading to rapid population ageing. At the end of the 2000s (decade), one in five Italians was over 65 years old.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
       <a href="#cite_note-164">
        [162]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, in recent years Italy experienced a significant growth in birth rates.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
       <a href="#cite_note-165">
        [163]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The total fertility rate has also climbed from an all-time low of 1.18 children per woman in 1995 to 1.41 in 2008.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
       <a href="#cite_note-166">
        [164]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">
       TFR
      </a>
      is expected to reach 1.6–1.8 in 2030.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
       <a href="#cite_note-167">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      From the late 19th century until the 1960s Italy was a country of mass
      <a href="/wiki/Emigration" title="Emigration">
       emigration
      </a>
      . Between 1898 and 1914, the peak years of
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_diaspora" title="Italian diaspora">
       Italian diaspora
      </a>
      , approximately 750,000 Italians emigrated each year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
       <a href="#cite_note-168">
        [166]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The diaspora concerned more than 25 million Italians and it is considered the biggest mass migration of contemporary times.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
       <a href="#cite_note-169">
        [167]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As a result, today more than 4.1 million Italian citizens are living abroad,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aire_170-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-aire-170">
        [168]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while at least 60 million people of full or part Italian ancestry live outside of Italy, most notably in Argentina,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
       <a href="#cite_note-171">
        [169]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Brazil,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
       <a href="#cite_note-172">
        [170]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Uruguay,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
       <a href="#cite_note-173">
        [171]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Venezuela,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
       <a href="#cite_note-174">
        [172]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the United States,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
       <a href="#cite_note-175">
        [173]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Canada,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
       <a href="#cite_note-176">
        [174]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Australia,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
       <a href="#cite_note-177">
        [175]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and France.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
       <a href="#cite_note-178">
        [176]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <br/>
     </p>
     <table class="navbox">
      <tr>

          </a>
          estimates for 31 December 2014
         </span>
        </div>

       </td>
       <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">

       <td style="text-align:left;">
        <a href="/wiki/Taranto" title="Taranto">

        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:left;">
        <a href="/wiki/Apulia" title="Apulia">
         Apulia
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        202,016
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
        7
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:left;">
        <a href="/wiki/Bologna" title="Bologna">
         Bologna
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:left;">
        <a href="/wiki/Emilia-Romagna" title="Emilia-Romagna">
         Emilia-Romagna
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:right;">

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Metropolitan_cities.5B177.5D_and_Functional_urban_areas.5B178.5D">

       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">
       Ethnic groups
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Italy" title="Immigration to Italy">
       Immigration to Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:COB_data_Italy.PNG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="628" data-file-width="1357" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/COB_data_Italy.PNG/350px-COB_data_Italy.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/COB_data_Italy.PNG/525px-COB_data_Italy.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/COB_data_Italy.PNG/700px-COB_data_Italy.PNG 2x" width="350"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:COB_data_Italy.PNG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Italy is home to a large population of migrants from Eastern Europe and North Africa.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 2014, Italy had about 4.9 million foreign residents,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
       <a href="#cite_note-181">
        [179]
       </a>
      </sup>
      making up some 8.1% of the total population. The figures include more than half a million children born in Italy to foreign nationals—second generation immigrants, but exclude foreign nationals who have subsequently acquired Italian nationality; this applies to about 130,000 people a year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
       <a href="#cite_note-182">
        [180]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The official figures also exclude
      <a href="/wiki/Illegal_immigration" title="Illegal immigration">
       illegal immigrants
      </a>
      , that were estimated in 2008 to number at least 670,000.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
       <a href="#cite_note-183">
        [181]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Starting from the early 1980s, until then a linguistically and culturally homogeneous society, Italy begun to attract substantial flows of foreign immigrants.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
       <a href="#cite_note-184">
        [182]
       </a>
      </sup>
      After the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Berlin_Wall" title="Fall of the Berlin Wall">
       fall of the Berlin Wall
      </a>
      and, more recently, the
      <a href="/wiki/2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2004 enlargement of the European Union">
       2004
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2004 enlargement of the European Union">
       2007
      </a>
      enlargements of the European Union, large waves of migration originated from the former socialist countries of
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">
       Eastern Europe
      </a>
      (especially
      <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">
       Romania
      </a>
      , Albania,
      <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">
       Ukraine
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">
       Poland
      </a>
      ). An equally important source of immigration is neighbouring North Africa (in particular,
      <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">
       Morocco
      </a>
      , Egypt and
      <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">
       Tunisia
      </a>
      ), with soaring arrivals as a consequence of the
      <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">
       Arab Spring
      </a>
      . Furthermore, in recent years, growing migration fluxes from Asia-Pacific (notably
      <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
       China
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
       <a href="#cite_note-185">
        [183]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">
       Philippines
      </a>
      ) and Latin America have been recorded.
     </p>
     <p>
      Currently, about one million
      <a href="/wiki/Romanian_diaspora" title="Romanian diaspora">
       Romanian
      </a>
      citizens (around one tenth of them being
      <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">
       Roma
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
       <a href="#cite_note-186">
        [184]
       </a>
      </sup>
      ) are officially registered as living in Italy, representing thus the most important individual country of origin, followed by
      <a href="/wiki/Albanians" title="Albanians">
       Albanians
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Moroccans" title="Moroccans">
       Moroccans
      </a>
      with about 500,000 people each. The number of unregistered Romanians is difficult to estimate, but the Balkan Investigative Reporting Network suggested in 2007 that there might have been half a million or more.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
       <a href="#cite_note-187">
        [185]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
       <a href="#cite_note-189">
        [note 3]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Overall, at the end of the 2000s (decade) the foreign born population of Italy was from: Europe (54%), Africa (22%), Asia (16%), the Americas (8%) and Oceania (0.06%). The distribution of immigrants is largely uneven in Italy: 87% of immigrants live in the northern and central parts of the country (the most economically developed areas), while only 13% live in the southern half of the peninsula.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
       Languages
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Italy" title="Languages of Italy">
       Languages of Italy
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
       Italian language
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_Italophone_World.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="577" data-file-width="1365" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Map_Italophone_World.png/350px-Map_Italophone_World.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Map_Italophone_World.png/525px-Map_Italophone_World.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Map_Italophone_World.png/700px-Map_Italophone_World.png 2x" width="350"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_Italophone_World.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Geographic distribution of the Italian language in the world:
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #0c5eb1; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         native language
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #9fceff; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         secondary or non-official language
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #00ff00; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         Italophone minorities
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy's official language is
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
       Italian
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
       <a href="#cite_note-190">
        [187]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It is estimated that there are about 64 million native Italian speakers
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
       <a href="#cite_note-191">
        [188]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-europa2006_192-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-europa2006-192">
        [189]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
       <a href="#cite_note-193">
        [190]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while the total number of Italian speakers, including those who use it as a second language, is about 85 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Italian_language_194-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Italian_language-194">
        [191]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italy has numerous regional dialects,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
       <a href="#cite_note-195">
        [192]
       </a>
      </sup>
      however, the establishment of a national education system has led to decrease in variation in the languages spoken across the country during the 20th century. Standardisation was further expanded in the 1950s and 1960s thanks to economic growth and the rise of mass media and television (the state broadcaster
      <a href="/wiki/RAI" title="RAI">
       RAI
      </a>
      helped set a standard Italian).
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5122" data-file-width="4022" height="191" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg/150px-Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg/225px-Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg/300px-Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg.png 2x" width="150"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        All the minority language groups officially recognised by Italy.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
         <a href="#cite_note-196">
          [193]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Twelve historical
      <a href="/wiki/Minority_language" title="Minority language">
       minority languages
      </a>
      are legally recognised:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arberesh_language" title="Arberesh language">
       Albanian
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">
       Catalan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">
       German
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">
       Greek
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">
       Slovene
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">
       Croatian
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
       French
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Franco-Proven%C3%A7al_language" title="Franco-Provençal language">
       Franco-Provençal
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Friulian" title="Friulian">
       Friulian
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ladin_language" title="Ladin language">
       Ladin
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occitan" title="Occitan">
       Occitan
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
       Sardinian
      </a>
      (Law number 482 of 15 December 1999).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parl_197-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-parl-197">
        [194]
       </a>
      </sup>
      French is co-official in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Valle_d%E2%80%99Aosta" title="Valle d’Aosta">
       Valle d’Aosta
      </a>
      —although in fact
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Franco-Provencal" title="Franco-Provencal">
       Franco-Provencal
      </a>
      is more commonly spoken there.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
       <a href="#cite_note-198">
        [195]
       </a>
      </sup>
      German has the same status in
      <a href="/wiki/South_Tyrol" title="South Tyrol">
       South Tyrol
      </a>
      as, in some parts of that province and in parts of the neighbouring
      <a href="/wiki/Trentino" title="Trentino">
       Trentino
      </a>
      , does
      <a href="/wiki/Ladin_language" title="Ladin language">
       Ladin
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">
       Slovene
      </a>
      is officially recognised in the provinces of
      <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Trieste" title="Province of Trieste">
       Trieste
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Gorizia" title="Province of Gorizia">
       Gorizia
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Udine" title="Province of Udine">
       Udine
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Because of significant recent immigration, Italy has sizeable populations whose native language is not Italian. According to the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Statistics_(Italy)" title="National Institute of Statistics (Italy)">
       Italian National Institute of Statistics
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romanian_people" title="Romanian people">
       Romanian
      </a>
      is the most common mother tongue among foreign residents in Italy: almost 800,000 people speak Romanian as their first language (21.9% of the foreign residents aged 6 and over). Other prevalent mother tongues are
      <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">
       Arabic
      </a>
      (spoken by over 475,000 people; 13.1% of foreign residents),
      <a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">
       Albanian
      </a>
      (380,000 people) and
      <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
       Spanish
      </a>
      (255,000 people). Other languages spoken in Italy are
      <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">
       Ukrainian
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">
       Hindi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">
       Polish
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">
       Tamil
      </a>
      amongst others.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
       <a href="#cite_note-199">
        [196]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      According to the 2015
      <a href="/wiki/EF_Education_First" title="EF Education First">
       EF Education First
      </a>
      report, Italy is ranked 28th out of 70 countries in all around the world, registering a medium competence level of English attributed to the value of 54,02.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
       <a href="#cite_note-200">
        [197]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
       Religion
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Italy" title="Religion in Italy">
       Religion in Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Basilica_Sancti_Petri_blue_hour.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2514" data-file-width="3530" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Basilica_Sancti_Petri_blue_hour.jpg/220px-Basilica_Sancti_Petri_blue_hour.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Basilica_Sancti_Petri_blue_hour.jpg/330px-Basilica_Sancti_Petri_blue_hour.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Basilica_Sancti_Petri_blue_hour.jpg/440px-Basilica_Sancti_Petri_blue_hour.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Basilica_Sancti_Petri_blue_hour.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica" title="St. Peter's Basilica">
         St. Peter's Basilica
        </a>
        , the largest church of Christendom.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" title="Roman Catholicism">
       Roman Catholicism
      </a>
      is, by far, the largest religion in the country, although Catholicism is no longer officially the
      <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">
       state religion
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
       <a href="#cite_note-201">
        [198]
       </a>
      </sup>
