      In 2010, the proportion of Italians that identify themselves as Roman Catholic was 81.2%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewresearch_202-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-pewresearch-202">
        [199]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">
       Holy See
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">
       episcopal jurisdiction of Rome
      </a>
      , contains the central government of the entire
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" title="Roman Catholic Church">
       Roman Catholic Church
      </a>
      , including various
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Curia" title="Roman Curia">
       agencies
      </a>
      essential to administration. Diplomatically, it is recognised by other subjects of international law as a
      <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">
       sovereign
      </a>
      entity, headed by the
      <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">
       Pope
      </a>
      , who is also the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bishop_of_Rome" title="Bishop of Rome">
       Bishop of Rome
      </a>
      , with which
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diplomatic_relations" title="Diplomatic relations">
       diplomatic relations
      </a>
      can be maintained.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
       <a href="#cite_note-203">
        [200]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
       <a href="#cite_note-204">
        [201]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Often incorrectly referred to as "the Vatican", the Holy See is not the same entity as the
      <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">
       Vatican City
      </a>
      State, which came into existence only in 1929; the Holy See dates back to early Christian times. Ambassadors are officially accredited not to the Vatican City State but to "the Holy See", and papal representatives to states and international organisations are recognised as representing the Holy See, not the Vatican City State.
     </p>
     <p>
      Minority Christian faiths in Italy include
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">
       Eastern Orthodox
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Waldensians" title="Waldensians">
       Waldensians
      </a>
      and other
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">
       Protestant
      </a>
      communities. In 2011, there were an estimated 1.5 million Orthodox Christians in Italy, or 2.5% of the population;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
       <a href="#cite_note-205">
        [202]
       </a>
      </sup>
      0.5 million
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pentecostals" title="Pentecostals">
       Pentecostals
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelicals" title="Evangelicals">
       Evangelicals
      </a>
      (of whom 0.4 million are members of the
      <a href="/wiki/Assemblies_of_God" title="Assemblies of God">
       Assemblies of God
      </a>
      ), 235,685
      <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">
       Jehovah's Witnesses
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
       <a href="#cite_note-206">
        [203]
       </a>
      </sup>
      30,000 Waldensians,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
       <a href="#cite_note-207">
        [204]
       </a>
      </sup>
      25,000
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventists" title="Seventh-day Adventists">
       Seventh-day Adventists
      </a>
      , 22,000
      <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">
       Latter-day Saints
      </a>
      , 15,000 Baptists (plus some 5,000 Free Baptists), 7,000
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lutherans" title="Lutherans">
       Lutherans
      </a>
      , 4,000
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Methodists" title="Methodists">
       Methodists
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Methodist_and_Waldensian_Churches" title="Union of Methodist and Waldensian Churches">
       affiliated with the Waldensian Church
      </a>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
       <a href="#cite_note-208">
        [205]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      One of the longest-established minority religious faiths in Italy is
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Jews" title="Italian Jews">
       Judaism
      </a>
      , Jews having been present in
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
       Ancient Rome
      </a>
      since before the birth of Christ. Italy has for centuries welcomed Jews expelled from other countries, notably Spain. However, as a result of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust">
       Holocaust
      </a>
      , about 20% of Italian Jews lost their lives.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isbn0553343025_209-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-isbn0553343025-209">
        [206]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This, together with the emigration that preceded and followed World War II, has left only a small community of around 28,400 Jews in Italy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
       <a href="#cite_note-210">
        [207]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Soaring immigration in the last two decades has been accompanied by an increase in non-Christian faiths. In 2010, there were 1.6 million Muslims in Italy, forming 2.6% of population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewresearch_202-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-pewresearch-202">
        [199]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In addition, there are more than 200,000 followers of faiths originating in the Indian subcontinent with some 70,000
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sikhs" title="Sikhs">
       Sikhs
      </a>
      with 22
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gurdwaras" title="Gurdwaras">
       gurdwaras
      </a>
      across the country,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
       <a href="#cite_note-211">
        [208]
       </a>
      </sup>
      70,000
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus">
       Hindus
      </a>
      , and 50,000
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhists" title="Buddhists">
       Buddhists
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
       <a href="#cite_note-212">
        [209]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There were an estimated 4,900
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%ADs" title="Bahá'ís">
       Bahá'ís
      </a>
      in Italy in 2005.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WCE-05_213-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WCE-05-213">
        [210]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Italian state, as a measure to protect religious freedom, devolves shares of income tax to recognised religious communities, under a regime known as
      <a href="/wiki/Eight_per_thousand" title="Eight per thousand">
       Eight per thousand
      </a>
      (
      <i>
       Otto per mille
      </i>
      ). Donations are allowed to Christian, Jewish, Buddhist and Hindu communities; however, Islam remains excluded, since no Muslim communities have yet signed a concordat with the Italian state.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
       <a href="#cite_note-214">
        [211]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Taxpayers who do not wish to fund a religion contribute their share to the state welfare system.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
       <a href="#cite_note-215">
        [212]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
       Education
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Italy" title="Education in Italy">
       Education in Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Archiginnasio-bologna02.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="411" data-file-width="618" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Archiginnasio-bologna02.png/220px-Archiginnasio-bologna02.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Archiginnasio-bologna02.png/330px-Archiginnasio-bologna02.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Archiginnasio-bologna02.png/440px-Archiginnasio-bologna02.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Archiginnasio-bologna02.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bologna_University" title="Bologna University">
         Bologna University
        </a>
        is the oldest academic institution of the world, founded in AD 1088.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Borromini_SantIvo.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="1536" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Borromini_SantIvo.jpg/220px-Borromini_SantIvo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Borromini_SantIvo.jpg/330px-Borromini_SantIvo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Borromini_SantIvo.jpg/440px-Borromini_SantIvo.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Borromini_SantIvo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Sapienza_University_of_Rome" title="Sapienza University of Rome">
         Sapienza University of Rome
        </a>
        is the largest university by enrollments in Europe.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
         <a href="#cite_note-216">
          [213]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Education in Italy is free and mandatory from ages six to sixteen,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
       <a href="#cite_note-217">
        [214]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and consists of five stages: kindergarten (
      <i>
       scuola dell'infanzia
      </i>
      ), primary school (
      <i>
       scuola primaria
      </i>
      ),
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lower_secondary_school" title="Lower secondary school">
       lower secondary school
      </a>
      (
      <i>
       scuola secondaria di primo grado
      </i>
      ),
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upper_secondary_school" title="Upper secondary school">
       upper secondary school
      </a>
      (
      <i>
       scuola secondaria di secondo grado
      </i>
      ) and university (
      <i>
       università
      </i>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
       <a href="#cite_note-218">
        [215]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Primary education lasts eight years. The students are given a basic education in Italian, English, mathematics, natural sciences, history, geography, social studies, physical education and visual and musical arts. Secondary education lasts for five years and includes three traditional types of schools focused on different academic levels: the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Italy#liceo" title="Secondary education in Italy">
        liceo
       </a>
      </i>
      prepares students for university studies with a classical or scientific curriculum, while the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Italy#Istituto_tecnico" title="Secondary education in Italy">
        istituto tecnico
       </a>
      </i>
      and the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Italy#Istituto_professionale" title="Secondary education in Italy">
        Istituto professionale
       </a>
      </i>
      prepare pupils for vocational education. In 2012, the Italian secondary education has been evalued as slightly below the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
       OECD
      </a>
      average, with a strong and steady improvement in science and mathematics results since 2003;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
       <a href="#cite_note-219">
        [216]
       </a>
      </sup>
      however, a wide gap exists between
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Italy" title="Northern Italy">
       northern
      </a>
      schools, which performed significantly better than the national average (among the best in the world in some subjects), and schools in the
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">
       South
      </a>
      , that had much poorer results.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
       <a href="#cite_note-220">
        [217]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Italy" title="Education in Italy">
       Tertiary education
      </a>
      in Italy is divided between
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Italy" title="List of universities in Italy">
       public universities
      </a>
      , private universities and the prestigious and selective
      <a href="/wiki/Superior_Graduate_Schools_in_Italy" title="Superior Graduate Schools in Italy">
       superior graduate schools
      </a>
      , such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Scuola_Normale_Superiore_di_Pisa" title="Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa">
       Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa
      </a>
      . The university system in Italy is generally regarded as poor for a world cultural powerhouse, with no universities ranked among the 100 world best and only 20 among the top 500.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
       <a href="#cite_note-221">
        [218]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, the current government has scheduled major reforms and investments in order to improve the overall internationalisation and quality of the system.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
       <a href="#cite_note-222">
        [219]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DIETA_MEDITERRANEA_ITALIA.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2116" data-file-width="3051" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/DIETA_MEDITERRANEA_ITALIA.JPG/220px-DIETA_MEDITERRANEA_ITALIA.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/DIETA_MEDITERRANEA_ITALIA.JPG/330px-DIETA_MEDITERRANEA_ITALIA.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/DIETA_MEDITERRANEA_ITALIA.JPG/440px-DIETA_MEDITERRANEA_ITALIA.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:DIETA_MEDITERRANEA_ITALIA.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        In 2013,
        <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
         UNESCO
        </a>
        added the
        <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_diet" title="Mediterranean diet">
         Mediterranean diet
        </a>
        to the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Representative_List_of_the_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_of_Humanity" title="Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity">
         Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity
        </a>
        of Italy (promoter),
        <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">
         Morocco
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
         Spain
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">
         Portugal
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">
         Greece
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">
         Cyprus
        </a>
        , and
        <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">
         Croatia
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
         <a href="#cite_note-223">
          [220]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
         <a href="#cite_note-224">
          [221]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Health">
       Health
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Italy" title="Healthcare in Italy">
       Healthcare in Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The Italian state runs a universal public healthcare system since 1978.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dev.prenhall_a_225-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-dev.prenhall_a-225">
        [222]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, healthcare is provided to all citizens and residents by a mixed public-private system. The public part is the
      <i>
       Servizio Sanitario Nazionale
      </i>
      , which is organised under the Ministry of Health and administered on a devolved regional basis. Healthcare spending in Italy accounted for 9.2% of the national GDP in 2012, very close the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
       OECD
      </a>
      countries' average of 9.3%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_226-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-OECD-226">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy in 2000 ranked as having the world's 2nd best healthcare system,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dev.prenhall_a_225-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-dev.prenhall_a-225">
        [222]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-photius.com_227-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-photius.com-227">
        [224]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the world's
      <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization_ranking_of_health_systems_in_2000" title="World Health Organization ranking of health systems in 2000">
       2nd best healthcare performance
      </a>
      . Life expectancy in Italy is 80 for males and 85 for females, placing the country
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">
       6th in the world for life expectancy
      </a>
      . In comparison to other Western countries, Italy has a relatively low rate of adult obesity (below 10%
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IOTF2008_228-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IOTF2008-228">
        [225]
       </a>
      </sup>
      ), probably thanks to the health benefits of the
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_diet" title="Mediterranean diet">
       mediterranean diet
      </a>
      . The proportion of daily smokers was 22% in 2012, down from 24.4% in 2000 but still slightly above the OECD average.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_226-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-OECD-226">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Smoking in public places including bars, restaurants, night clubs and offices has been restricted to specially ventilated rooms since 2005.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Deutsche_Welle_10_01_229-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Deutsche_Welle_10_01-229">
        [226]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
       Culture
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Italy" title="Culture of Italy">
       Culture of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:194px;max-width:194px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:192px;max-width:192px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7307" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg/190px-Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg/285px-Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg/380px-Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg 2x" width="190"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The city of
         <a href="/wiki/Venice" title="Venice">
          Venice
         </a>
         , built on 117 islands.
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:192px;max-width:192px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cathedral_and_Campanary_-_Pisa_2014_(2).JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="1738" data-file-width="2632" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Cathedral_and_Campanary_-_Pisa_2014_%282%29.JPG/190px-Cathedral_and_Campanary_-_Pisa_2014_%282%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Cathedral_and_Campanary_-_Pisa_2014_%282%29.JPG/285px-Cathedral_and_Campanary_-_Pisa_2014_%282%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Cathedral_and_Campanary_-_Pisa_2014_%282%29.JPG/380px-Cathedral_and_Campanary_-_Pisa_2014_%282%29.JPG 2x" width="190"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Leaning_Tower_of_Pisa" title="Leaning Tower of Pisa">
          Leaning Tower
         </a>
         and the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Duomo_di_Pisa" title="Duomo di Pisa">
          Duomo
         </a>
         of
         <a href="/wiki/Pisa" title="Pisa">
          Pisa
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:192px;max-width:192px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CasertaNorthernAspect.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/CasertaNorthernAspect.jpg/190px-CasertaNorthernAspect.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/CasertaNorthernAspect.jpg/285px-CasertaNorthernAspect.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/CasertaNorthernAspect.jpg/380px-CasertaNorthernAspect.jpg 2x" width="190"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Caserta" title="Royal Palace of Caserta">
          Royal Palace of Caserta
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      For centuries divided by politics and geography until its eventual unification in 1861, Italy has developed a unique culture, shaped by a multitude of regional customs and local centres of power and
      <a href="/wiki/Patronage" title="Patronage">
       patronage
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
       <a href="#cite_note-230">
        [227]
       </a>
      </sup>
      During the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, a number of magnificent
      <a href="/wiki/Court_(royal)" title="Court (royal)">
       courts
      </a>
      competed for attracting the best architects, artistis and scholars, thus producing an immense legacy of monuments, paintings, music and literature.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
       <a href="#cite_note-231">
        [228]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy has more
      <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
       UNESCO
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Italy" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Italy">
       World Heritage Sites
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Table_of_World_Heritage_Sites_by_country" title="Table of World Heritage Sites by country">
       51
      </a>
      ) than any other country in the world, and has rich collections of art, culture and literature from many different periods. The country has had a broad cultural influence worldwide, also because numerous Italians emigrated to other places during the
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_diaspora" title="Italian diaspora">
       Italian diaspora
      </a>
      . Furthermore, the nation has, overall, an estimated 100,000 monuments of any sort (museums, palaces, buildings, statues, churches, art galleries, villas, fountains, historic houses and archaeological remains).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eyewitness_Travel_2005.2C_pg._19_232-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Eyewitness_Travel_2005.2C_pg._19-232">
        [229]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">
       Architecture
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Italy" title="Architecture of Italy">
       Architecture of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy has a very broad and diverse architectural style, which cannot be simply classified by period, but also by region, because of Italy's division into several regional states until 1861. This has created a highly diverse and eclectic range in architectural designs.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Santa_Maria_del_Fiore.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="344" data-file-width="463" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Santa_Maria_del_Fiore.jpg/170px-Santa_Maria_del_Fiore.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Santa_Maria_del_Fiore.jpg/255px-Santa_Maria_del_Fiore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Santa_Maria_del_Fiore.jpg/340px-Santa_Maria_del_Fiore.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Santa_Maria_del_Fiore.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Florence_cathedral" title="Florence cathedral">
         Florence cathedral
        </a>
        has the largest brick dome in the world,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
         <a href="#cite_note-233">
          [230]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
         <a href="#cite_note-234">
          [231]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and is considered a masterpiece of world architecture.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy is known for its considerable architectural achievements,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
       <a href="#cite_note-235">
        [232]
       </a>
      </sup>
      such as the construction of arches, domes and similar structures during
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
       ancient Rome
      </a>
      , the founding of the
      <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_architecture" title="Renaissance architecture">
       Renaissance architectural movement
      </a>
      in the late-14th to 16th centuries, and being the homeland of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palladianism" title="Palladianism">
       Palladianism
      </a>
      , a style of construction which inspired movements such as that of
      <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">
       Neoclassical architecture
      </a>
      , and influenced the designs which noblemen built their country houses all over the world, notably in the UK, Australia and the US during the late 17th to early 20th centuries. Several of the finest works in Western architecture, such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Colosseum" title="Colosseum">
       Colosseum
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Milan_Cathedral" title="Milan Cathedral">
       Milan Cathedral
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Florence_cathedral" title="Florence cathedral">
       Florence cathedral
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Leaning_Tower_of_Pisa" title="Leaning Tower of Pisa">
       Leaning Tower of Pisa
      </a>
      and the building designs of
      <a href="/wiki/Venice" title="Venice">
       Venice
      </a>
      are found in Italy.
     </p>
     <p>
      Italian architecture has also widely influenced the architecture of the world. British architect
      <a href="/wiki/Inigo_Jones" title="Inigo Jones">
       Inigo Jones
      </a>
      , inspired by the designs of Italian buildings and cities, brought back the ideas of Italian Renaissance architecture to 17th-century England, being inspired by
      <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Palladio" title="Andrea Palladio">
       Andrea Palladio
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
       <a href="#cite_note-236">
        [233]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Additionally,
      <a href="/wiki/Italianate_architecture" title="Italianate architecture">
       Italianate architecture
      </a>
      , popular abroad since the 19th century, was used to describe foreign architecture which was built in an Italian style, especially modelled on
      <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_architecture" title="Renaissance architecture">
       Renaissance architecture
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_art">
       Visual art
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Art_of_Italy" title="Art of Italy">
       Art of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Leonardo_da_Vinci_(1452-1519)_-_The_Last_Supper_(1495-1498).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2645" data-file-width="5076" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg/220px-Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg/330px-Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg/440px-Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Leonardo_da_Vinci_(1452-1519)_-_The_Last_Supper_(1495-1498).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/The_Last_Supper_(Leonardo_da_Vinci)" title="The Last Supper (Leonardo da Vinci)">
          The Last Supper
         </a>
        </i>
        (1494–1499) by
        <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">
         Leonardo da Vinci
        </a>
        . Church of
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santa_Maria_delle_Grazie" title="Santa Maria delle Grazie">
         Santa Maria delle Grazie
        </a>
        , Milan.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mona_Lisa,_by_Leonardo_da_Vinci,_from_C2RMF_retouched.jpg">
        <img alt="Mona Lisa, La Joconde in the Louvre Museum" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="11146" data-file-width="7479" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Mona_Lisa%2C_by_Leonardo_da_Vinci%2C_from_C2RMF_retouched.jpg/150px-Mona_Lisa%2C_by_Leonardo_da_Vinci%2C_from_C2RMF_retouched.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Mona_Lisa%2C_by_Leonardo_da_Vinci%2C_from_C2RMF_retouched.jpg/225px-Mona_Lisa%2C_by_Leonardo_da_Vinci%2C_from_C2RMF_retouched.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Mona_Lisa%2C_by_Leonardo_da_Vinci%2C_from_C2RMF_retouched.jpg/300px-Mona_Lisa%2C_by_Leonardo_da_Vinci%2C_from_C2RMF_retouched.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mona_Lisa,_by_Leonardo_da_Vinci,_from_C2RMF_retouched.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Mona_Lisa" title="Mona Lisa">
          Mona Lisa
         </a>
        </i>
        (1501–1504) by Leonardo da Vinci, the world's best known work of art.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
         <a href="#cite_note-237">
          [234]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The history of Italian visual art is part of
      <a href="/wiki/Western_painting" title="Western painting">
       Western painting
      </a>
      history.
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_art" title="Roman art">
       Roman art
      </a>
      was influenced by Greece and can in part be taken as a descendant of ancient Greek painting. However, Roman painting does have important unique characteristics. The only surviving Roman paintings are wall paintings, many from villas in
      <a href="/wiki/Campania" title="Campania">
       Campania
      </a>
      , in Southern Italy. Such painting can be grouped into 4 main "styles" or periods
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
       <a href="#cite_note-238">
        [235]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and may contain the first examples of
      <a href="/wiki/Trompe-l%27%C5%93il" title="Trompe-l'œil">
       trompe-l'œil
      </a>
      , pseudo-perspective, and pure landscape.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
       <a href="#cite_note-239">
        [236]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Panel painting becomes more common during the
      <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_art" title="Romanesque art">
       Romanesque
      </a>
      period, under the heavy influence of Byzantine icons. Towards the middle of the 13th century,
      <a href="/wiki/Medieval_art" title="Medieval art">
       Medieval art
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gothic_painting" title="Gothic painting">
       Gothic painting
      </a>
      became more realistic, with the beginnings of interest in the depiction of volume and perspective in Italy with
      <a href="/wiki/Cimabue" title="Cimabue">
       Cimabue
      </a>
      and then his pupil
      <a href="/wiki/Giotto" title="Giotto">
       Giotto
      </a>
      . From Giotto on, the treatment of composition by the best painters also became much more free and innovative. They are considered to be the two great medieval masters of painting in western culture.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3824" data-file-width="2388" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg/150px-Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg/225px-Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg/300px-Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Michelangelo%27s_David" title="Michelangelo's David">
         Michelangelo's David
        </a>
        (1501–1504),
        <a href="/wiki/Galleria_dell%27Accademia" title="Galleria dell'Accademia">
         Galleria dell'Accademia
        </a>
        , Florence.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Renaissance" title="Italian Renaissance">
       Italian Renaissance
      </a>
      is said by many to be the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Golden_Age_(metaphor)" title="Golden Age (metaphor)">
       golden age
      </a>
      of painting; roughly spanning the 14th through the mid-17th centuries with a significant influence also out of the borders of modern Italy. In Italy artists like
      <a href="/wiki/Paolo_Uccello" title="Paolo Uccello">
       Paolo Uccello
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Fra_Angelico" title="Fra Angelico">
       Fra Angelico
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Masaccio" title="Masaccio">
       Masaccio
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Piero_della_Francesca" title="Piero della Francesca">
       Piero della Francesca
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Mantegna" title="Andrea Mantegna">
       Andrea Mantegna
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Filippo_Lippi" title="Filippo Lippi">
       Filippo Lippi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Giorgione" title="Giorgione">
       Giorgione
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tintoretto" title="Tintoretto">
       Tintoretto
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sandro_Botticelli" title="Sandro Botticelli">
       Sandro Botticelli
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">
       Leonardo da Vinci
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Michelangelo_Buonarroti" title="Michelangelo Buonarroti">
       Michelangelo Buonarroti
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Raphael" title="Raphael">
       Raphael
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Bellini" title="Giovanni Bellini">
       Giovanni Bellini
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Titian" title="Titian">
       Titian
      </a>
      took painting to a higher level through the use of
      <a href="/wiki/Perspective_(graphical)" title="Perspective (graphical)">
       perspective
      </a>
      , the study of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_anatomy" title="Human anatomy">
       human anatomy
      </a>
      and proportion, and through their development of an unprecedented refinement in drawing and painting techniques. Michelangelo was an active sculptor from about 1500 to 1520, and his great masterpieces including his
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/David_(Michelangelo)" title="David (Michelangelo)">
        David
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Piet%C3%A0_(Michelangelo)" title="Pietà (Michelangelo)">
        Pietà
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Moses_(Michelangelo)" title="Moses (Michelangelo)">
        Moses
       </a>
      </i>
      . Other prominent Renaissance sculptors include
      <a href="/wiki/Lorenzo_Ghiberti" title="Lorenzo Ghiberti">
       Lorenzo Ghiberti
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luca_Della_Robbia" title="Luca Della Robbia">
       Luca Della Robbia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Donatello" title="Donatello">
       Donatello
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Filippo_Brunelleschi" title="Filippo Brunelleschi">
       Filippo Brunelleschi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Andrea_del_Verrocchio" title="Andrea del Verrocchio">
       Andrea del Verrocchio
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      In the 15th and 16th centuries, the
      <a href="/wiki/High_Renaissance" title="High Renaissance">
       High Renaissance
      </a>
      gave rise to a stylised art known as
      <a href="/wiki/Mannerism" title="Mannerism">
       Mannerism
      </a>
      . In place of the balanced compositions and rational approach to perspective that characterised art at the dawn of the 16th century, the Mannerists sought instability, artifice, and doubt. The unperturbed faces and gestures of
      <a href="/wiki/Piero_della_Francesca" title="Piero della Francesca">
       Piero della Francesca
      </a>
      and the calm Virgins of Raphael are replaced by the troubled expressions of
      <a href="/wiki/Pontormo" title="Pontormo">
       Pontormo
      </a>
      and the emotional intensity of
      <a href="/wiki/El_Greco" title="El Greco">
       El Greco
      </a>
      . In the 17th century, among the greatest painters of
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Baroque" title="Italian Baroque">
       Italian Baroque
      </a>
      are
      <a href="/wiki/Caravaggio" title="Caravaggio">
       Caravaggio
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Annibale_Carracci" title="Annibale Carracci">
       Annibale Carracci
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Artemisia_Gentileschi" title="Artemisia Gentileschi">
       Artemisia Gentileschi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mattia_Preti" title="Mattia Preti">
       Mattia Preti
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Saraceni" title="Carlo Saraceni">
       Carlo Saraceni
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Bartolomeo_Manfredi" title="Bartolomeo Manfredi">
       Bartolomeo Manfredi
      </a>
      . Subsequently, in the 18th century,
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Rococo_art" title="Italian Rococo art">
       Italian Rococo
      </a>
      was mainly inspired by French Rococo, since France was the founding nation of that particular style, with artists such as
      <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Battista_Tiepolo" title="Giovanni Battista Tiepolo">
       Giovanni Battista Tiepolo
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Canaletto" title="Canaletto">
       Canaletto
      </a>
      . Italian Neoclassical sculpture focused, with
      <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Canova" title="Antonio Canova">
       Antonio Canova
      </a>
      's nudes, on the idealist aspect of the movement.
     </p>
     <p>
      In the 19th century, major Italian
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romantic_painting" title="Romantic painting">
       Romantic
      </a>
      painters were
      <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Hayez" title="Francesco Hayez">
       Francesco Hayez
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Bezzuoli" title="Giuseppe Bezzuoli">
       Giuseppe Bezzuoli
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Podesti" title="Francesco Podesti">
       Francesco Podesti
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">
       Impressionism
      </a>
      was brought from France to Italy by the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Macchiaioli" title="Macchiaioli">
        Macchiaioli
       </a>
      </i>
      , led by
      <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Fattori" title="Giovanni Fattori">
       Giovanni Fattori
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Boldini" title="Giovanni Boldini">
       Giovanni Boldini
      </a>
      ;
      <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">
       Realism
      </a>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Gioacchino_Toma" title="Gioacchino Toma">
       Gioacchino Toma
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Pellizza_da_Volpedo" title="Giuseppe Pellizza da Volpedo">
       Giuseppe Pellizza da Volpedo
      </a>
      . In the 20th century, with
      <a href="/wiki/Futurism" title="Futurism">
       Futurism
      </a>
      , primarily through the works of
      <a href="/wiki/Umberto_Boccioni" title="Umberto Boccioni">
       Umberto Boccioni
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Giacomo_Balla" title="Giacomo Balla">
       Giacomo Balla
      </a>
      , Italy rose again as a seminal country for artistic evolution in painting and sculpture. Futurism was succeeded by the metaphysical paintings of
      <a href="/wiki/Giorgio_de_Chirico" title="Giorgio de Chirico">
       Giorgio de Chirico
      </a>
      , who exerted a strong influence on the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Surrealists" title="Surrealists">
       Surrealists
      </a>
      and generations of artists to follow.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_theatre">
       Literature and theatre
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literature_of_Italy" title="Literature of Italy">
       Literature of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DanteDetail.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="684" data-file-width="1053" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/DanteDetail.jpg/220px-DanteDetail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/DanteDetail.jpg/330px-DanteDetail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/DanteDetail.jpg/440px-DanteDetail.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:DanteDetail.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Dante_Alighieri" title="Dante Alighieri">
         Dante
        </a>
        , poised between the mountain of
        <a href="/wiki/Purgatory" title="Purgatory">
         Purgatory
        </a>
        and the city of Florence, displays the famous incipit
        <i>
         Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita
        </i>
        in a detail of
        <a href="/wiki/Domenico_di_Michelino" title="Domenico di Michelino">
         Domenico di Michelino
        </a>
        's painting, 1465.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The basis of the modern
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
       Italian language
      </a>
      was established by the
      <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">
       Florentine
      </a>
      poet
      <a href="/wiki/Dante_Alighieri" title="Dante Alighieri">
       Dante Alighieri
      </a>
      , whose greatest work, the
      <a href="/wiki/Divine_Comedy" title="Divine Comedy">
       Divine Comedy
      </a>
      , is considered among the foremost literary statements produced in Europe during the
      <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
       Middle Ages
      </a>
      . There is no shortage of celebrated literary figures in Italy:
      <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Boccaccio" title="Giovanni Boccaccio">
       Giovanni Boccaccio
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Giacomo_Leopardi" title="Giacomo Leopardi">
       Giacomo Leopardi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Manzoni" title="Alessandro Manzoni">
       Alessandro Manzoni
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Torquato_Tasso" title="Torquato Tasso">
       Torquato Tasso
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ludovico_Ariosto" title="Ludovico Ariosto">
       Ludovico Ariosto
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Francesco_Petrarca" title="Francesco Petrarca">
       Petrarch
      </a>
      , whose best-known vehicle of expression, the
      <a href="/wiki/Sonnet" title="Sonnet">
       sonnet
      </a>
      , was created in Italy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
       <a href="#cite_note-240">
        [237]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Prominent philosophers include
      <a href="/wiki/Giordano_Bruno" title="Giordano Bruno">
       Giordano Bruno
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Marsilio_Ficino" title="Marsilio Ficino">
       Marsilio Ficino
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli" title="Niccolò Machiavelli">
       Niccolò Machiavelli
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Giambattista_Vico" title="Giambattista Vico">
       Giambattista Vico
      </a>
      . Modern literary figures and Nobel laureates are nationalist poet
      <a href="/wiki/Giosu%C3%A8_Carducci" title="Giosuè Carducci">
       Giosuè Carducci
      </a>
      in 1906, realist writer
      <a href="/wiki/Grazia_Deledda" title="Grazia Deledda">
       Grazia Deledda
      </a>
      in 1926, modern theatre author
      <a href="/wiki/Luigi_Pirandello" title="Luigi Pirandello">
       Luigi Pirandello
      </a>
      in 1936, poets
      <a href="/wiki/Salvatore_Quasimodo" title="Salvatore Quasimodo">
       Salvatore Quasimodo
      </a>
      in 1959 and
      <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Montale" title="Eugenio Montale">
       Eugenio Montale
      </a>
      in 1975, satirist and theatre author
      <a href="/wiki/Dario_Fo" title="Dario Fo">
       Dario Fo
      </a>
      in 1997.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
       <a href="#cite_note-241">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Collodi" title="Carlo Collodi">
       Carlo Collodi
      </a>
      's 1883 novel,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Pinocchio" title="The Adventures of Pinocchio">
        The Adventures of Pinocchio
       </a>
      </i>
      , is the most celebrated children's classic by an Italian author.
     </p>
     <p>
      Italian theatre can be traced back to the Roman tradition which was heavily influenced by the Greek; as with many other literary genres, Roman dramatists tended to adapt and translate from the Greek. For example, Seneca's
      <i>
       Phaedra
      </i>
      was based on that of
      <a href="/wiki/Euripides" title="Euripides">
       Euripides
      </a>
      , and many of the comedies of
      <a href="/wiki/Plautus" title="Plautus">
       Plautus
      </a>
      were direct translations of works by
      <a href="/wiki/Menander" title="Menander">
       Menander
      </a>
      . During the 16th century and on into the 18th century,
      <a href="/wiki/Commedia_dell%27arte" title="Commedia dell'arte">
       Commedia dell'arte
      </a>
      was a form of
      <a href="/wiki/Improvisational_theatre" title="Improvisational theatre">
       improvisational theatre
      </a>
      , and it is still performed today. Travelling troupes of players would set up an outdoor stage and provide amusement in the form of
      <a href="/wiki/Juggling" title="Juggling">
       juggling
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Acrobatics" title="Acrobatics">
       acrobatics
      </a>
      , and, more typically, humorous plays based on a repertoire of established characters with a rough storyline, called
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Canovaccio" title="Canovaccio">
        canovaccio
       </a>
      </i>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">
       Music
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Italy" title="Music of Italy">
       Music of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GiacomoPuccini.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="330" data-file-width="251" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/GiacomoPuccini.jpg/170px-GiacomoPuccini.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9b/GiacomoPuccini.jpg 1.5x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GiacomoPuccini.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Giacomo_Puccini" title="Giacomo Puccini">
         Giacomo Puccini
        </a>
        , Italian composer whose operas, including
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/La_boh%C3%A8me" title="La bohème">
          La bohème
         </a>
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Tosca" title="Tosca">
          Tosca
         </a>
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Madama_Butterfly" title="Madama Butterfly">
          Madama Butterfly
         </a>
        </i>
        , and
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Turandot" title="Turandot">
          Turandot
         </a>
        </i>
        , are among the most frequently worldwide performed in the
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_important_operas" title="List of important operas">
         standard repertoire
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
         <a href="#cite_note-242">
          [239]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
         <a href="#cite_note-243">
          [240]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      From
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_folk_music" title="Italian folk music">
       folk music
      </a>
      to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_classical_music" title="European classical music">
       classical
      </a>
      , music has always played an important role in Italian culture. Instruments associated with classical music, including the piano and violin, were invented in Italy, and many of the prevailing classical music forms, such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Symphony" title="Symphony">
       symphony
      </a>
      , concerto, and
      <a href="/wiki/Sonata" title="Sonata">
       sonata
      </a>
      , can trace their roots back to innovations of 16th- and 17th-century Italian music.
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy's most famous composers include the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Renaissance_composers#Italian" title="List of Renaissance composers">
       Renaissance composers
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Pierluigi_da_Palestrina" title="Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina">
       Palestrina
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Claudio_Monteverdi" title="Claudio Monteverdi">
       Monteverdi
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Baroque_composers" title="List of Baroque composers">
       Baroque composers
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Scarlatti" title="Alessandro Scarlatti">
       Scarlatti
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Arcangelo_Corelli" title="Arcangelo Corelli">
       Corelli
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Vivaldi" title="Antonio Vivaldi">
       Vivaldi
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Classical_era_composers" title="List of Classical era composers">
       Classical composers
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Paganini" title="Niccolò Paganini">
       Paganini
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Gioachino_Rossini" title="Gioachino Rossini">
       Rossini
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Romantic-era_composers" title="List of Romantic-era composers">
       Romantic composers
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Verdi" title="Giuseppe Verdi">
       Verdi
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Giacomo_Puccini" title="Giacomo Puccini">
       Puccini
      </a>
      . Modern Italian composers such as
      <a href="/wiki/Luciano_Berio" title="Luciano Berio">
       Berio
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luigi_Nono_(composer)" title="Luigi Nono (composer)">
       Nono
      </a>
      proved significant in the development of
      <a href="/wiki/Experimental_music" title="Experimental music">
       experimental
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">
       electronic music
      </a>
      . While the classical music tradition still holds strong in Italy, as evidenced by the fame of its innumerable opera houses, such as
      <a href="/wiki/La_Scala" title="La Scala">
       La Scala
      </a>
      of Milan and
      <a href="/wiki/Teatro_di_San_Carlo" title="Teatro di San Carlo">
       San Carlo
      </a>
      of Naples, and performers such as the pianist
      <a href="/wiki/Maurizio_Pollini" title="Maurizio Pollini">
       Maurizio Pollini
      </a>
      and the late tenor
      <a href="/wiki/Luciano_Pavarotti" title="Luciano Pavarotti">
       Luciano Pavarotti
      </a>
      , Italians have been no less appreciative of their thriving contemporary music scene.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="334" data-file-width="500" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg/220px-Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg/330px-Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg/440px-Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Luciano_Pavarotti" title="Luciano Pavarotti">
         Luciano Pavarotti
        </a>
        , one of the most influential tenors of all time.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italy is widely known for being the birthplace of opera.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.co.uk_244-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-books.google.co.uk-244">
        [241]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_opera" title="Italian opera">
       Italian opera
      </a>
      was believed to have been founded in the early 17th century, in Italian cities such as
      <a href="/wiki/Mantua" title="Mantua">
       Mantua
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Venice" title="Venice">
       Venice
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.co.uk_244-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-books.google.co.uk-244">
        [241]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Later, works and pieces composed by native Italian composers of the 19th and early 20th centuries, such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rossini" title="Rossini">
       Rossini
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Vincenzo_Bellini" title="Vincenzo Bellini">
       Bellini
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Donizetti" title="Donizetti">
       Donizetti
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Verdi" title="Verdi">
       Verdi
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puccini" title="Puccini">
       Puccini
      </a>
      , are among the most famous operas ever written and today are performed in opera houses across the world. La Scala operahouse in Milan is also renowned as one of the best in the world. Famous Italian opera singers include
      <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Caruso" title="Enrico Caruso">
       Enrico Caruso
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Bonci" title="Alessandro Bonci">
       Alessandro Bonci
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Introduced in the early 1920s,
      <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">
       jazz
      </a>
      took a particularly strong foothold in Italy, and remained popular despite the xenophobic cultural policies of the Fascist regime. Today, the most notable centres of jazz music in Italy include Milan, Rome, and Sicily. Later, Italy was at the forefront of the
      <a href="/wiki/Progressive_rock" title="Progressive rock">
       progressive rock
      </a>
      movement of the 1970s, with bands like
      <a href="/wiki/Premiata_Forneria_Marconi" title="Premiata Forneria Marconi">
       PFM
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Goblin_(band)" title="Goblin (band)">
       Goblin
      </a>
      . Italy was also an important country in the development of
      <a href="/wiki/Disco" title="Disco">
       disco
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">
       electronic
      </a>
      music, with
      <a href="/wiki/Italo_disco" title="Italo disco">
       Italo disco
      </a>
      , known for its futuristic sound and prominent usage of synthesisers and
      <a href="/wiki/Drum_machine" title="Drum machine">
       drum machines
      </a>
      , being one of the earliest electronic dance genres, as well as European forms of disco aside from
      <a href="/wiki/Euro_disco" title="Euro disco">
       Euro disco
      </a>
      (which later went on to influence several genres such as
      <a href="/wiki/Eurodance" title="Eurodance">
       Eurodance
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Nu-disco" title="Nu-disco">
       Nu-disco
      </a>
      ).
     </p>
     <p>
      Producers/songwriters such as
      <a href="/wiki/Giorgio_Moroder" title="Giorgio Moroder">
       Giorgio Moroder
      </a>
      , who won three
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award">
       Academy Awards
      </a>
      for his music, were highly influential in the development of
      <a href="/wiki/Electronic_dance_music" title="Electronic dance music">
       EDM
      </a>
      (electronic dance music). Today, Italian pop music is represented annually with the
      <a href="/wiki/Sanremo_Music_Festival" title="Sanremo Music Festival">
       Sanremo Music Festival
      </a>
      , which served as inspiration for the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurovision" title="Eurovision">
       Eurovision
      </a>
      song contest, and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Festival_of_Two_Worlds" title="Festival of Two Worlds">
       Festival of Two Worlds
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Spoleto" title="Spoleto">
       Spoleto
      </a>
      . Singers such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_pop" title="Traditional pop">
       pop
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Diva" title="Diva">
       diva
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Mina_(singer)" title="Mina (singer)">
       Mina
      </a>
      , classical crossover artist
      <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Bocelli" title="Andrea Bocelli">
       Andrea Bocelli
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grammy" title="Grammy">
       Grammy
      </a>
      winner
      <a href="/wiki/Laura_Pausini" title="Laura Pausini">
       Laura Pausini
      </a>
      , and European chart-topper
      <a href="/wiki/Eros_Ramazzotti" title="Eros Ramazzotti">
       Eros Ramazzotti
      </a>
      have attained international acclaim.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">
       Cinema
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Italy" title="Cinema of Italy">
       Cinema of Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lion_of_Venice.svg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="412" data-file-width="800" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lion_of_Venice.svg/220px-Lion_of_Venice.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lion_of_Venice.svg/330px-Lion_of_Venice.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lion_of_Venice.svg/440px-Lion_of_Venice.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lion_of_Venice.svg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Lion_of_Saint_Mark" title="Lion of Saint Mark">
          Lion of Saint Mark
         </a>
        </i>
        is the symbol of the
        <a href="/wiki/Golden_Lion" title="Golden Lion">
         Golden Lion
        </a>
        award from the
        <a href="/wiki/Venice_Film_Festival" title="Venice Film Festival">
         Venice Film Festival
        </a>
        , the oldest film festival in the world and one of the most prestigious and publicised.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
         <a href="#cite_note-245">
          [242]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The history of Italian cinema began a few months after the
      <a href="/wiki/Auguste_and_Louis_Lumi%C3%A8re" title="Auguste and Louis Lumière">
       Lumière brothers
      </a>
      began motion picture exhibitions. The first Italian film was a few seconds, showing
      <a href="/wiki/Pope_Leo_XIII" title="Pope Leo XIII">
       Pope Leo XIII
      </a>
      giving a blessing to the camera. The Italian film industry was born between 1903 and 1908 with three companies: the Società Italiana Cines, the
      <a href="/wiki/Ambrosio_Film" title="Ambrosio Film">
       Ambrosio Film
      </a>
      and the Itala Film. Other companies soon followed in Milan and in Naples. In a short time these first companies reached a fair producing quality, and films were soon sold outside Italy. Cinema was later used by
      <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">
       Benito Mussolini
      </a>
      , who founded Rome's renowned
      <a href="/wiki/Cinecitt%C3%A0" title="Cinecittà">
       Cinecittà
      </a>
      studio for the production of Fascist propaganda until World War II.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
       <a href="#cite_note-246">
        [243]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      After the war, Italian film was widely recognised and exported until an artistic decline around the 1980s.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_film_directors_from_Italy" title="List of film directors from Italy">
       Notable Italian film directors
      </a>
      from this period include
      <a href="/wiki/Vittorio_De_Sica" title="Vittorio De Sica">
       Vittorio De Sica
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Federico_Fellini" title="Federico Fellini">
       Federico Fellini
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Leone" title="Sergio Leone">
       Sergio Leone
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Pier_Paolo_Pasolini" title="Pier Paolo Pasolini">
       Pier Paolo Pasolini
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Luchino_Visconti" title="Luchino Visconti">
       Luchino Visconti
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Michelangelo_Antonioni" title="Michelangelo Antonioni">
       Michelangelo Antonioni
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Dario_Argento" title="Dario Argento">
       Dario Argento
      </a>
      . Movies include world cinema treasures such as
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_dolce_vita" title="La dolce vita">
        La dolce vita
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Good,_the_Bad_and_the_Ugly" title="The Good, the Bad and the Ugly">
        The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Bicycle_Thieves" title="Bicycle Thieves">
        Bicycle Thieves
       </a>
      </i>
      . The mid-1940s to the early 1950s was the heyday of
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_neorealism" title="Italian neorealism">
       neorealist films
      </a>
      , reflecting the poor condition of post-war Italy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
       <a href="#cite_note-247">
        [244]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
       <a href="#cite_note-248">
        [245]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      As the country grew wealthier in the 1950s, a form of neorealism known as pink neorealism succeeded, and other
      <a href="/wiki/Film_genre" title="Film genre">
       film genres
      </a>
      , such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sword-and-sandal" title="Sword-and-sandal">
       sword-and-sandal
      </a>
      followed as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spaghetti_western" title="Spaghetti western">
       spaghetti westerns
      </a>
      , were popular in the 1960s and 1970s. In recent years, the Italian scene has received only occasional international attention, with movies like
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Life_Is_Beautiful" title="Life Is Beautiful">
        Life Is Beautiful
       </a>
      </i>
      directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Benigni" title="Roberto Benigni">
       Roberto Benigni
      </a>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Il_Postino:_The_Postman" title="Il Postino: The Postman">
        Il Postino: The Postman
       </a>
      </i>
      with
      <a href="/wiki/Massimo_Troisi" title="Massimo Troisi">
       Massimo Troisi
      </a>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Great_Beauty" title="The Great Beauty">
        The Great Beauty
       </a>
      </i>
      directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Paolo_Sorrentino" title="Paolo Sorrentino">
       Paolo Sorrentino
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy is the most awarded country at the
      <a href="/wiki/Academy_Awards" title="Academy Awards">
       Academy Awards
      </a>
      for
      <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" title="Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">
       Best Foreign Language Film
      </a>
      , with 14 awards won, 3
      <a href="/wiki/Academy_Honorary_Award" title="Academy Honorary Award">
       Special Awards
      </a>
      and 31 nominations.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">
       Sport
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Italy" title="Sport in Italy">
       Sport in Italy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Italia82.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="524" data-file-width="832" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Italia82.JPG/220px-Italia82.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Italia82.JPG/330px-Italia82.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Italia82.JPG/440px-Italia82.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Italia82.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">
          Azzurri
         </a>
        </i>
        at the
        <a href="/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1982 FIFA World Cup">
         1982 FIFA World Cup
        </a>
        (one of the four won by Italy).
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The most popular sport in Italy is, by far,
      <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
       football
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
       <a href="#cite_note-249">
        [246]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italy's
      <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">
       national football team
      </a>
      (nicknamed
      <i>
       Gli Azzurri
      </i>
      – "the Blues") is one of the world's most successful team as it has won four
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">
       FIFA World Cups
      </a>
      (1934, 1938, 1982, and 2006).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
       <a href="#cite_note-250">
        [247]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italian clubs have won 48 major European trophies, making Italy the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_UEFA_club_competition_winners#By_country" title="List of UEFA club competition winners">
       second most successful country in European football
      </a>
      . Italy's top-flight club football league,
      <a href="/wiki/Serie_A" title="Serie A">
       Serie A
      </a>
      , ranks as the
      <a href="/wiki/UEFA_coefficient" title="UEFA coefficient">
       fourth best in Europe
      </a>
      and is followed by millions of fans around the world.
     </p>
     <p>
      Other popular team sports in Italy include
      <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">
       volleyball
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">
       basketball
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Rugby_football" title="Rugby football">
       rugby
      </a>
      . Italy's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italy_national_volleyball_team" title="Italy national volleyball team">
       male
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Italy_women%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Italy women's national volleyball team">
       female
      </a>
      national teams are often
      <a href="/wiki/FIVB_World_Rankings" title="FIVB World Rankings">
       featured among the world's best
      </a>
      . The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_national_basketball_team" title="Italian national basketball team">
       Italian national basketball team
      </a>
      's best results were gold at
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurobasket_1983" title="Eurobasket 1983">
       Eurobasket 1983
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_1999" title="EuroBasket 1999">
       EuroBasket 1999
      </a>
      , as well as silver at the Olympics in
      <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics" title="Basketball at the 2004 Summer Olympics">
       2004
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Lega_Basket_Serie_A" title="Lega Basket Serie A">
       Lega Basket Serie A
      </a>
      is widely considered
      <a href="/wiki/European_national_basketball_league_rankings" title="European national basketball league rankings">
       one of the most competitive in Europe
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">
       Rugby union
      </a>
      enjoys a good level of popularity, especially in the north of the country. Italy's
      <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_rugby_union_team" title="Italy national rugby union team">
       national team
      </a>
      competes in the
      <a href="/wiki/Six_Nations_Championship" title="Six Nations Championship">
       Six Nations Championship
      </a>
      , and is a regular at the
      <a href="/wiki/Rugby_World_Cup" title="Rugby World Cup">
       Rugby World Cup
      </a>
      . Italy ranks as a tier-one nation by
      <a href="/wiki/World_Rugby" title="World Rugby">
       World Rugby
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Italy_men%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Italy men's national volleyball team">
       Italy men's national volleyball team
      </a>
      winning three
      <a href="/wiki/FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship">
       World Championships
      </a>
      in a row 1990, 1994 and 1998 an three silver medal in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Olympics" title="Olympics">
       Olympics
      </a>
      1996, 2004, 2016. Italy has a long and successful tradition in individual sports as well.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bicycle_racing" title="Bicycle racing">
       Bicycle racing
      </a>
      is a very familiar sport in the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
       <a href="#cite_note-251">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italians have won the
      <a href="/wiki/UCI_Road_World_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_road_race" title="UCI Road World Championships – Men's road race">
       UCI World Championships
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/UCI_Road_World_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_road_race#Medalists_by_nation" title="UCI Road World Championships – Men's road race">
       more than any other country
      </a>
      , except
      <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">
       Belgium
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Giro_d%27Italia" title="Giro d'Italia">
       Giro d'Italia
      </a>
      is a cycling race held every May, and constitutes one of the three
      <a href="/wiki/Grand_Tour_(cycling)" title="Grand Tour (cycling)">
       Grand Tours
      </a>
      , along with the
      <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_France" title="Tour de France">
       Tour de France
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Vuelta_a_Espa%C3%B1a" title="Vuelta a España">
       Vuelta a España
      </a>
      , each of which last approximately three weeks.
      <a href="/wiki/Alpine_skiing" title="Alpine skiing">
       Alpine skiing
      </a>
      is also a very widespread sport in Italy, and the country is a popular international skiing destination, known for its ski resorts.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
       <a href="#cite_note-252">
        [249]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italian skiers achieved good results in
      <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">
       Winter Olympic Games
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/FIS_Alpine_Ski_World_Cup" title="FIS Alpine Ski World Cup">
       Alpine Ski World Cup
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/FIS_Alpine_World_Ski_Championships" title="FIS Alpine World Ski Championships">
       World Championship
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">
       Tennis
      </a>
      has a significant following in Italy, ranking as the fourth most practised sport in the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
       <a href="#cite_note-253">
        [250]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_Open_(tennis)" title="Italian Open (tennis)">
       Rome Masters
      </a>
      , founded in 1930, is one of the most prestigious tennis tournaments in the world. Italian professional tennis players won the
      <a href="/wiki/Davis_Cup" title="Davis Cup">
       Davis Cup
      </a>
      in 1976 and the
      <a href="/wiki/Fed_Cup" title="Fed Cup">
       Fed Cup
      </a>
      in 2006, 2009, 2010 and 2013.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Motorsports" title="Motorsports">
       Motorsports
      </a>
      are also extremely popular in Italy. Italy has won, by far,
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Grand_Prix_motorcycle_racing_World_champions#By_country" title="List of Grand Prix motorcycle racing World champions">
       the most MotoGP World Championships
      </a>
      . Italian
      <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Ferrari" title="Scuderia Ferrari">
       Scuderia Ferrari
      </a>
      is the oldest surviving team in
      <a href="/wiki/Grand_Prix_motor_racing" title="Grand Prix motor racing">
       Grand Prix
      </a>
      racing, having competed since 1948, and statistically the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_Grand_Prix_winners_(constructors)" title="List of Formula One Grand Prix winners (constructors)">
       most successful Formula One team in history
      </a>
      with a record of 224 wins.
