     </p>
     <p>
      Historically, Italy has been successful in the
      <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">
       Olympic Games
      </a>
      , taking part from the
      <a href="/wiki/1896_Summer_Olympics" title="1896 Summer Olympics">
       first Olympiad
      </a>
      and in 47 Games out of 48.
      <a href="/wiki/Italy_at_the_Olympics" title="Italy at the Olympics">
       Italian sportsmen
      </a>
      have won 522 medals at the
      <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">
       Summer Olympic Games
      </a>
      , and another 106 at the
      <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">
       Winter Olympic Games
      </a>
      , for a combined total of 628 medals with 235 golds, which makes them the
      <a href="/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table" title="All-time Olympic Games medal table">
       fifth most successful nation in Olympic history
      </a>
      for total medals. The country hosted two Winter Olympics (in
      <a href="/wiki/1956_Winter_Olympics" title="1956 Winter Olympics">
       1956
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics" title="2006 Winter Olympics">
       2006
      </a>
      ), and one Summer games (in
      <a href="/wiki/1960_Summer_Olympics" title="1960 Summer Olympics">
       1960
      </a>
      ).
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion_and_design">
       Fashion and design
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_fashion" title="Italian fashion">
       Italian fashion
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_design" title="Italian design">
       Italian design
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HK_TST_Peninsula_Hotel_Hong_Kong_Salisbury_Road_Prada_shop_window_Oct-2012.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="1936" height="201" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/HK_TST_Peninsula_Hotel_Hong_Kong_Salisbury_Road_Prada_shop_window_Oct-2012.JPG/150px-HK_TST_Peninsula_Hotel_Hong_Kong_Salisbury_Road_Prada_shop_window_Oct-2012.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/HK_TST_Peninsula_Hotel_Hong_Kong_Salisbury_Road_Prada_shop_window_Oct-2012.JPG/225px-HK_TST_Peninsula_Hotel_Hong_Kong_Salisbury_Road_Prada_shop_window_Oct-2012.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/HK_TST_Peninsula_Hotel_Hong_Kong_Salisbury_Road_Prada_shop_window_Oct-2012.JPG/300px-HK_TST_Peninsula_Hotel_Hong_Kong_Salisbury_Road_Prada_shop_window_Oct-2012.JPG 2x" width="150"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HK_TST_Peninsula_Hotel_Hong_Kong_Salisbury_Road_Prada_shop_window_Oct-2012.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Prada" title="Prada">
         Prada
        </a>
        shop in Hong Kong.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Italian fashion has
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_Italian_fashion" title="History of Italian fashion">
       a long tradition
      </a>
      , and is regarded as one most important in the world. Milan, Florence and Rome are Italy's main
      <a href="/wiki/Fashion_capital" title="Fashion capital">
       fashion capitals
      </a>
      . According to
      <i>
       Top Global Fashion Capital Rankings
      </i>
      2013 by
      <a href="/wiki/Global_Language_Monitor" title="Global Language Monitor">
       Global Language Monitor
      </a>
      , Rome ranked sixth worldwide when Milan was twelfth.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
       <a href="#cite_note-254">
        [251]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Major Italian fashion labels, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Gucci" title="Gucci">
       Gucci
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Armani" title="Armani">
       Armani
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Prada" title="Prada">
       Prada
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Versace" title="Versace">
       Versace
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Valentino_SpA" title="Valentino SpA">
       Valentino
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Dolce_%26_Gabbana" title="Dolce &amp; Gabbana">
       Dolce &amp; Gabbana
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Missoni" title="Missoni">
       Missoni
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Fendi" title="Fendi">
       Fendi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Moschino" title="Moschino">
       Moschino
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Max_Mara" title="Max Mara">
       Max Mara
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Trussardi" title="Trussardi">
       Trussardi
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ferragamo" title="Ferragamo">
       Ferragamo
      </a>
      , to name a few, are regarded as among the finest fashion houses in the world. Also, the fashion magazine
      <a href="/wiki/Vogue_Italia" title="Vogue Italia">
       Vogue Italia
      </a>
      , is considered one of the most prestigious fashion magazines in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
       <a href="#cite_note-255">
        [252]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Italy is also prominent in the field of design, notably interior design,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Architectural_design" title="Architectural design">
       architectural design
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Industrial_design" title="Industrial design">
       industrial design
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Urban_design" title="Urban design">
       urban design
      </a>
      . The country has produced some well-known furniture designers, such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gio_Ponti" title="Gio Ponti">
       Gio Ponti
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ettore_Sottsass" title="Ettore Sottsass">
       Ettore Sottsass
      </a>
      , and Italian phrases such as
      <i>
       "Bel Disegno"
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       "Linea Italiana"
      </i>
      have entered the vocabulary of furniture design.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
       <a href="#cite_note-256">
        [253]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Examples of classic pieces of Italian
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_goods" title="White goods">
       white goods
      </a>
      and pieces of furniture include
      <a href="/wiki/Zanussi" title="Zanussi">
       Zanussi
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/Washing_machine" title="Washing machine">
       washing machines
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fridge" title="Fridge">
       fridges
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Insight_Guides_2004_p.220_257-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Insight_Guides_2004_p.220-257">
        [254]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the "New Tone" sofas by Atrium,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Insight_Guides_2004_p.220_257-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Insight_Guides_2004_p.220-257">
        [254]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the post-modern bookcase by Ettore Sottsass, inspired by
      <a href="/wiki/Bob_Dylan" title="Bob Dylan">
       Bob Dylan
      </a>
      's song "
      <a href="/wiki/Stuck_Inside_of_Mobile_with_the_Memphis_Blues_Again" title="Stuck Inside of Mobile with the Memphis Blues Again">
       Stuck Inside of Mobile with the Memphis Blues Again
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Insight_Guides_2004_p.220_257-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Insight_Guides_2004_p.220-257">
        [254]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Today,
      <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">
       Milan
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Turin" title="Turin">
       Turin
      </a>
      are the nation's leaders in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Architectural_design" title="Architectural design">
       architectural design
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Industrial_design" title="Industrial design">
       industrial design
      </a>
      . The city of Milan hosts
      <a href="/wiki/Fiera_Milano" title="Fiera Milano">
       Fiera Milano
      </a>
      , Europe's largest design fair.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wiley.com_258-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-wiley.com-258">
        [255]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Milan also hosts major design and architecture-related events and venues, such as the "
      <i>
       Fuori Salone
      </i>
      " and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salone_del_Mobile" title="Salone del Mobile">
       Salone del Mobile
      </a>
      , and has been home to the designers
      <a href="/wiki/Bruno_Munari" title="Bruno Munari">
       Bruno Munari
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Lucio_Fontana" title="Lucio Fontana">
       Lucio Fontana
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Castellani" title="Enrico Castellani">
       Enrico Castellani
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Piero_Manzoni" title="Piero Manzoni">
       Piero Manzoni
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259">
       <a href="#cite_note-259">
        [256]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
       Cuisine
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">
       Italian cuisine
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Italian_food.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Italian_food.JPG/220px-Italian_food.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Italian_food.JPG/330px-Italian_food.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Italian_food.JPG/440px-Italian_food.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Italian_food.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Some of the most popular Italian foods:
        <a href="/wiki/Pizza" title="Pizza">
         pizza
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Pasta" title="Pasta">
         pasta
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Gelato" title="Gelato">
         gelato
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Espresso" title="Espresso">
         espresso
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Modern Italian
      <a href="/wiki/Cuisine" title="Cuisine">
       cuisine
      </a>
      has developed through centuries of social and political changes, with
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Roman_cuisine" title="Ancient Roman cuisine">
       roots
      </a>
      as far back as the 4th century BC. Italian cuisine in itself takes heavy influences, including
      <a href="/wiki/Etruscan_civilization" title="Etruscan civilization">
       Etruscan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_cuisine" title="Ancient Greek cuisine">
       ancient Greek
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Roman_cuisine" title="Ancient Roman cuisine">
       ancient Roman
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_cuisine" title="Byzantine cuisine">
       Byzantine
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Jewish_cuisine" title="Jewish cuisine">
       Jewish
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
       <a href="#cite_note-260">
        [257]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Significant changes occurred with the discovery of the
      <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">
       New World
      </a>
      with the introduction of items such as
      <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">
       potatoes
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tomato" title="Tomato">
       tomatoes
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Bell_pepper" title="Bell pepper">
       bell peppers
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">
       maize
      </a>
      , now central to the cuisine but not introduced in quantity until the 18th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
       <a href="#cite_note-261">
        [258]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
       <a href="#cite_note-262">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italian cuisine is noted for its regional diversity,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
       <a href="#cite_note-263">
        [260]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
       <a href="#cite_note-264">
        [261]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
       <a href="#cite_note-265">
        [262]
       </a>
      </sup>
      abundance of difference in taste, and is known to be one of the most popular in the world,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
       <a href="#cite_note-266">
        [263]
       </a>
      </sup>
      wielding strong influence abroad.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
       <a href="#cite_note-267">
        [264]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_diet" title="Mediterranean diet">
       Mediterranean diet
      </a>
      forms the basis of Italian cuisine, rich in pasta, fish, fruits and vegetables and characterised by its extreme simplicity and variety, with many dishes having only four to eight ingredients.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
       <a href="#cite_note-268">
        [265]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italian cooks rely chiefly on the quality of the ingredients rather than on elaborate preparation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
       <a href="#cite_note-269">
        [266]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Dishes and recipes are often derivatives from local and familial tradition rather than created by
      <a href="/wiki/Chef" title="Chef">
       chefs
      </a>
      , so many recipes are ideally suited for
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Home_cooking" title="Home cooking">
       home cooking
      </a>
      , this being one of the main reasons behind the ever increasing worldwide popularity of Italian cuisine, from America
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
       <a href="#cite_note-270">
        [267]
       </a>
      </sup>
      to Asia.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
       <a href="#cite_note-271">
        [268]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Ingredients and dishes vary widely by
      <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Italy" title="Regions of Italy">
       region
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      A key factor in the success of Italian cuisine is its heavy reliance on traditional products; Italy has the most
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_products_with_protected_designation_of_origin" title="List of Italian products with protected designation of origin">
       traditional specialities
      </a>
      protected under
      <a href="/wiki/Geographical_indications_and_traditional_specialities_in_the_European_Union" title="Geographical indications and traditional specialities in the European Union">
       EU law
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
       <a href="#cite_note-272">
        [269]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_cheeses" title="List of Italian cheeses">
       Cheese
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Salumi" title="Salumi">
       cold cuts
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Italian_wine" title="Italian wine">
       wine
      </a>
      are a major part of Italian cuisine, with many regional declinations and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protected_Designation_of_Origin" title="Protected Designation of Origin">
       Protected Designation of Origin
      </a>
      or
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protected_Geographical_Indication" title="Protected Geographical Indication">
       Protected Geographical Indication
      </a>
      labels, and along with
      <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">
       coffee
      </a>
      (especially
      <a href="/wiki/Espresso" title="Espresso">
       espresso
      </a>
      ) make up a very important part of the Italian
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gastronomic" title="Gastronomic">
       gastronomic
      </a>
      culture.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
       <a href="#cite_note-273">
        [270]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Desserts have a long tradition of merging local flavours such as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Citrus_fruits" title="Citrus fruits">
       citrus fruits
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Pistachio" title="Pistachio">
       pistachio
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Almonds" title="Almonds">
       almonds
      </a>
      with sweet cheeses like
      <a href="/wiki/Mascarpone" title="Mascarpone">
       mascarpone
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ricotta" title="Ricotta">
       ricotta
      </a>
      or exotic tastes as cocoa, vanilla and cinnamon.
      <a href="/wiki/Gelato" title="Gelato">
       Gelato
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
       <a href="#cite_note-274">
        [271]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tiramis%C3%B9" title="Tiramisù">
       tiramisù
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
       <a href="#cite_note-275">
        [272]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Cassata" title="Cassata">
       cassata
      </a>
      are among the most famous examples of Italian desserts, cakes and patisserie.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
       See also
      </span>
     </h2>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Italy-related_articles" title="Index of Italy-related articles">
        Index of Italy-related articles
       </a>
      </li>
      <li class="mw-empty-elt">
      </li>
      <li class="mw-empty-elt">
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Italy" title="Outline of Italy">
        Outline of Italy
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
       Notes
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
      <ol class="references">
       <li id="cite_note-11">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-11">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_peninsula" title="Italian peninsula">
          Italian peninsula
         </a>
         is geographically located in
         <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">
          Southern Europe
         </a>
         , while
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Italy" title="North Italy">
          North Italy
         </a>
         can be placed partly or totally in
         <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
          Central Europe
         </a>
         . Due to cultural, political and historical reasons, Italy is a
         <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">
          Western European
         </a>
         country.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-79">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-79">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Official French maps show the border detouring south of the main summit, and claim the highest point in Italy is Mont Blanc de Courmayeur (4,748 m), but these are inconsistent with an 1861 convention and topographic watershed analysis.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-189">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-189">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         According to Mitrica, an October 2005 Romanian report estimates that 1,061,400 Romanians are living in Italy, constituting 37% of 2.8 million immigrants in that country
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
          <a href="#cite_note-188">
           [186]
          </a>
         </sup>
         but it is unclear how the estimate was made, and therefore whether it should be taken seriously.
        </span>
       </li>
      </ol>
     </div>

          <a href="#cite_ref-6">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.comune.campione-d-italia.co.it/" rel="nofollow">
           "Comune di Campione d'Italia"
          </a>
          . Comune.campione-d-italia.co.it. 14 July 2010

       <li id="cite_note-allempires.com-19">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-allempires.com_19-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.allempires.com/article/index.php?q=italian_colonial" rel="nofollow">
           "The Italian Colonial Empire"
          </a>
          . All Empires
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            17 June
           </span>
           2012
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           At its peak, just before WWII, the Italian Empire comprehended the territories of present time Italy, Albania, Rhodes, Dodecaneses, Libya, Ethiopia, Eritrea, ⅔ of Somalia and the little concession of Tientsin in China
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AItaly&amp;rft.btitle=The+Italian+Colonial+Empire&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.allempires.com%2Farticle%2Findex.php%3Fq%3Ditalian_colonial&amp;rft.pub=All+Empires&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AItaly&amp;rft.btitle=Report+for+Selected+Countries+and+Subjects&amp;rft.date=2013-04-16&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.imf.org%2Fexternal%2Fpubs%2Fft%2Fweo%2F2013%2F01%2Fweodata%2Fweorept.aspx%3Fsy%3D2008%26ey%3D2013%26scsm%3D1%26ssd%3D1%26sort%3Dcountry%26ds%3D.%26br%3D1%26c%3D512%252C941%252C914%252C446%252C612%252C666%252C614%252C668%252C311%252C672%252C213%252C946%252C911%252C137%252C193%252C962%252C122%252C674%252C912%252C676%252C313%252C548%252C419%252C556%252C513%252C678%252C316%252C181%252C913%252C682%252C124%252C684%252C339%252C273%252C638%252C921%252C514%252C948%252C218%252C943%252C963%252C686%252C616%252C688%252C223%252C518%252C516%252C728%252C918%252C558%252C748%252C138%252C618%252C196%252C522%252C278%252C622%252C692%252C156%252C694%252C624%252C142%252C626%252C449%252C628%252C564%252C228%252C283%252C924%252C853%252C233%252C288%252C632%252C293%252C636%252C566%252C634%252C964%252C238%252C182%252C662%252C453%252C960%252C968%252C423%252C922%252C935%252C714%252C128%252C862%252C611%252C716%252C321%252C456%252C243%252C722%252C248%252C942%252C469%252C718%252C253%252C724%252C642%252C576%252C643%252C936%252C939%252C961%252C644%252C813%252C819%252C199%252C172%252C184%252C132%252C524%252C646%252C361%252C648%252C362%252C915%252C364%252C134%252C732%252C652%252C366%252C174%252C734%252C328%252C144%252C258%252C146%252C656%252C463%252C654%252C528%252C336%252C923%252C263%252C738%252C268%252C578%252C532%252C537%252C944%252C742%252C176%252C866%252C534%252C369%252C536%252C744%252C429%252C186%252C433%252C925%252C178%252C746%252C436%252C926%252C136%252C466%252C343%252C112%252C158%252C111%252C439%252C298%252C916%252C927%252C664%252C846%252C826%252C299%252C542%252C582%252C443%252C474%252C917%252C754%252C544%252C698%26s%3DPPPGDP%26grp%3D0%26a%3D%26pr.x%3D9%26pr.y%3D12&amp;rft.pub=Imf.org&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

       <li id="cite_note-Milena_Sterio-28">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-Milena_Sterio_28-0">

          </a>

        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation book">
          Sterio, Milena (2013).
          <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-QuI6n_OVMYC&amp;printsec=frontcover&amp;dq=The+Right+to+Self-determination+Under+International+Law:+%22selfistans%22,+Secession+and+the+Rule+of+the+Great+Powers&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwi55M-kyqXNAhWpK8AKHe2sCPUQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&amp;q=The%20Right%20to%20Self-determination%20Under%20International%20Law%3A%20%22selfistans%22%2C%20Secession%20and%20the%20Rule%20of%20the%20Great%20Powers&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
           <i>
            The right to self-determination under international law : "selfistans", secession and the rule of the great powers
           </i>
          </a>
          . Milton Park, Abingdon, Oxon: Routledge. p. xii (preface).
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0415668182" title="Special:BookSources/0415668182">
           0415668182
          </a>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            13 June
           </span>
           2016
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AItaly&amp;rft.aufirst=Milena&amp;rft.aulast=Sterio&amp;rft.btitle=The+right+to+self-determination+under+international+law+%3A+%22selfistans%22%2C+secession+and+the+rule+of+the+great+powers&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D-QuI6n_OVMYC%26printsec%3Dfrontcover%26dq%3DThe%2BRight%2Bto%2BSelf-determination%2BUnder%2BInternational%2BLaw%3A%2B%2522selfistans%2522%2C%2BSecession%2Band%2Bthe%2BRule%2Bof%2Bthe%2BGreat%2BPowers%26hl%3Den%26sa%3DX%26ved%3D0ahUKEwi55M-kyqXNAhWpK8AKHe2sCPUQ6AEIHDAA%23v%3Donepage%26q%3DThe%2520Right%2520to%2520Self-determination%2520Under%2520International%2520Law%253A%2520%2522selfistans%2522%252C%2520Secession%2520and%2520the%2520Rule%2520of%2520the%2520Great%2520Powers%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=0415668182&amp;rft.pages=xii+%28preface%29&amp;rft.place=Milton+Park%2C+Abingdon%2C+Oxon&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         ("
         <i>
          The great powers are super-sovereign states: an exclusive club of the most powerful states economically, militarily, politically and strategically. These states include veto-wielding members of the United Nations Security Council (United States, United Kingdom, France, China, and Russia), as well as economic powerhouses such as Germany, Italy and Japan.
         </i>
         ")
        </span>

       <li id="cite_note-37">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-37">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          Egan, James (19 April 1981).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/19/travel/sicily-in-spring-a-flowering-isle-wreathed-in-antiquity.html?pagewanted=all" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          .
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">
            The New York Times
           </a>
          </i>
          .
          <q>
           ...the Temple of Concordia, the most massive and best-preserved Doric temple in Sicily.
          </q>
         </cite>

         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-78">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         The so-called Second Republic was born by forceps: not with a revolt of Algiers, but formally under the same Constitution, with the mere replacement of one ruling class to another:
         <cite class="citation journal">
          Buonomo, Giampiero (2015).
          <a class="external text" href="https://www.questia.com/projects#!/project/89429827" rel="nofollow">
           "Tovaglie pulite"
          </a>
          .
          <i>
           Mondoperaio edizione online
          </i>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AItaly&amp;rft.atitle=Tovaglie+pulite&amp;rft.aufirst=Giampiero&amp;rft.aulast=Buonomo&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.questia.com%2Fprojects%23%21%2Fproject%2F89429827&amp;rft.jtitle=Mondoperaio+edizione+online&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         – via
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Questia" title="Questia">
          Questia
         </a>
         <span style="font-size:0.95em; font-size: 90%; color: #555">
          (subscription required)
         </span>
        </span>

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AItaly&amp;rft.atitle=World+Wind+Energy+Report+2010&amp;rft.date=2011-02&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.wwindea.org%2Fhome%2Fimages%2Fstories%2Fpdfs%2Fworldwindenergyreport2010_s.pdf&amp;rft.jtitle=Report&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">

         <a class="external text" href="http://mdgs.un.org/unsd/mdg/SeriesDetail.aspx?srid=749&amp;crid=" rel="nofollow">
          Carbon dioxide emissions (CO
          <sub>
           2
          </sub>
          ), thousand metric tons of CO
          <sub>
           2
          </sub>

         (collected by CDIAC)

          <a href="#cite_ref-89">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Human-produced, direct emissions of carbon dioxide only. Excludes other greenhouse gases; land-use, land-use-change and forestry (LULUCF); and natural background flows of CO
         <sub>
          2
         </sub>
         (See also:
         <a href="/wiki/Carbon_cycle" title="Carbon cycle">
          Carbon cycle
         </a>
         )

       <li id="cite_note-106">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-106">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">

        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          L. Anwandter and P. Rubino (2006). "Risks, uncertainties and conflicts of Interest in the Italian water sector: A review and proposals for reform". Materiali UVAL (Public Investment Evaluation Unit of the Department for Development and Cohesion Policies (DPS) in the Ministry for Economic Development), According to
          <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Statistics_(Italy)" title="National Institute of Statistics (Italy)">
           ISTAT
          </a>
          figures analysed by the Water Resources Surveillance Committee (CoViRi),. p. 9.
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AItaly&amp;rft.au=L.+Anwandter+and+P.+Rubino&amp;rft.btitle=Risks%2C+uncertainties+and+conflicts+of+Interest+in+the+Italian+water+sector%3A+A+review+and+proposals+for+reform&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.pages=9&amp;rft.pub=Materiali+UVAL+%28Public+Investment+Evaluation+Unit+of+the+Department+for+Development+and+Cohesion+Policies+%28DPS%29+in+the+Ministry+for+Economic+Development%29%2C+According+to+ISTAT+figures+analysed+by+the+Water+Resources+Surveillance+Committee+%28CoViRi%29%2C&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AItaly&amp;rft.btitle=Ethnic+origins%2C+2006+counts%2C+for+Uruguay%2C+provinces+and+territories+%93+20%25+sample+data&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hotelsclick.com%2Fhoteles%2FUY%2FUruguay-DEMOGRAF%25C3%25ADA-5.html&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

       <li id="cite_note-203">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-203">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Text taken directly from
         <a class="external free" href="http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/country-profile/europe/holy-see/" rel="nofollow">
          http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/country-profile/europe/holy-see/
         </a>
         (viewed on 14 December 2011), on the website of the British Foreign &amp; Commonwealth Office.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-204">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-204">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         The Holy See's sovereignty has been recognized explicitly in many international agreements and is particularly emphasized in article 2 of the
         <a href="/wiki/Lateran_Treaty" title="Lateran Treaty">
          Lateran Treaty
         </a>
         of 11 February 1929, in which "Italy recognizes the sovereignty of the Holy See in international matters as an inherent attribute in conformity with its traditions and the requirements of its mission to the world" (
         <a class="external text" href="http://www.aloha.net/~mikesch/treaty.htm" rel="nofollow">
          Lateran Treaty, English translation
         </a>
         ).
        </span>
       </li>

        <span class="reference-text">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AItaly&amp;rft.aufirst=Alison&amp;rft.aulast=Cole&amp;rft.btitle=Virtue+and+magnificence+%3A+art+of+the+Italian+Renaissance+courts&amp;rft.date=1995&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=0-8109-2733-0&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=H.N.+Abrams&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">

         </span>
        </span>

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AItaly&amp;rft.atitle=A+taste+for+Italian+in+New+Delhi&amp;rft.aufirst=Amy&amp;rft.aulast=Kazmin&amp;rft.date=2013-03-26&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fintl%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F7ab87234-9214-11e2-851f-00144feabdc0.html%23axzz2dZCeLdLg&amp;rft.jtitle=Financial+Times&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-272">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-272">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          Keane, John.
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.bordbia.ie/industryservices/information/alerts/Pages/ItalyleadsthewaywithprotectedproductsunderEUschemes.aspx" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          .
          <a href="/wiki/Bord_Bia" title="Bord Bia">
           Bord Bia
          </a>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            5 September
           </span>
           2013
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AItaly&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.aulast=Keane&amp;rft.btitle=Italy+leads+the+way+with+protected+products+under+EU+schemes&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bordbia.ie%2Findustryservices%2Finformation%2Falerts%2FPages%2FItalyleadsthewaywithprotectedproductsunderEUschemes.aspx&amp;rft.pub=Bord+Bia&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

        </span>

       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Gnome-globe.svg/16px-Gnome-globe.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Gnome-globe.svg/24px-Gnome-globe.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Gnome-globe.svg/32px-Gnome-globe.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
       <a class="extiw" href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Atlas_of_Italy" title="commons:Atlas of Italy">
        Wikimedia Atlas of Italy
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <img alt="" data-file-height="256" data-file-width="256" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Openstreetmap_logo.svg/16px-Openstreetmap_logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Openstreetmap_logo.svg/24px-Openstreetmap_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Openstreetmap_logo.svg/32px-Openstreetmap_logo.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
       Geographic data related to
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/relation/365331" rel="nofollow">
        Italy
       </a>
       at
       <a href="/wiki/OpenStreetMap" title="OpenStreetMap">
        OpenStreetMap
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.ifs.du.edu/ifs/frm_CountryProfile.aspx?Country=IT" rel="nofollow">
        Key Development Forecasts for Italy
       </a>
       from
       <a href="/wiki/International_Futures" title="International Futures">
        International Futures
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>

            <tr>
             <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" colspan="2" style="width:100%;padding:0px;font-size:114%;">
              <div style="padding:0px;">
               <b>
                <a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">
                 Lat.
                 <small>
                  and
                 </small>
                 Long.
                </a>
                <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion">
                 <a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Italy&amp;params=41_54_N_12_29_E_">
                  <span class="geo-default">
                   <span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
                    <span class="latitude">
                     41°54′N
                    </span>
                    <span class="longitude">
                     12°29′E
                    </span>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                  <span class="geo-multi-punct">
                   ﻿ / ﻿
                  </span>
                  <span class="geo-nondefault">
                   <span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
                    41.900°N 12.483°E
                   </span>
                   <span style="display:none">
                    ﻿ /
                    <span class="geo">
                     41.900; 12.483
                    </span>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </a>
                </span>
                <span style="color:darkblue;">
                 (Rome)
                </span>
               </b>

           <table class="nowraplinks collapsible collapsed navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit">
            <tr>
             <th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col" style="background:#e8e8ff;">

                    <hr/>
                    <p>
                     <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                      1. All twenty-eight member states of the
                      <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
                       European Union
                      </a>
                      are also members of the WTO in their own right:
                     </span>
                    </p>
                    <ul>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Austria" title="Economy of Austria">
                        Austria

                        Belgium

                        Bulgaria
                       </a>

                        Croatia
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>

                        Cyprus

                      </span>

                     <li>

                     <li>

                     <li>

                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Germany" title="Economy of Germany">
                        Germany
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Greece" title="Economy of Greece">
                        Greece
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Hungary" title="Economy of Hungary">
                        Hungary
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">

                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">

                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">

                        Latvia
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Lithuania" title="Economy of Lithuania">
                        Lithuania
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Luxembourg" title="Economy of Luxembourg">
                        Luxembourg
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Malta" title="Economy of Malta">
                        Malta
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_Netherlands" title="Economy of the Netherlands">
                        Netherlands
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Poland" title="Economy of Poland">
                        Poland
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Portugal" title="Economy of Portugal">
                        Portugal
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Romania" title="Economy of Romania">
                        Romania
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Slovakia" title="Economy of Slovakia">
                        Slovakia
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Slovenia" title="Economy of Slovenia">
                        Slovenia
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Spain" title="Economy of Spain">
                        Spain
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Sweden" title="Economy of Sweden">
                        Sweden
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Economy of the United Kingdom">
                        United Kingdom
                       </a>
                      </span>
                     </li>
                    </ul>
                    <p>
                     <span style="text-align:left; font-size:85%">
                      <br/>
                      2.
                      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China">
                       Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China
                      </a>
                      , participates as "Hong Kong, China" and "Macao China".
                      <br/>
                      3. Officially the Republic of China, participates as "
                      <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">
                       Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu
                      </a>
                      ", and "Chinese Taipei" in short.
                     </span>
                    </p>
                   </div>
                  </td>
                 </tr>
                </table>

     <div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint metadata navbox" role="navigation" style="font-weight:bold;padding:0.4em 2em">
      <ul style="margin:0.1em 0 0">
       <li style="display:inline">
        <span style="display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap">
         <span style="margin:0 0.5em">
